column3: well, the food everywhere is quite good. It is also reasonable, but be on your guard. Even seasoned travelers get taking and this is what happened to me. Trying a new restaurant I walked in. It was a buffet and normally buffets have a great selection of food at reasonable prices. The bill was double the normal price and average, but tasty. This was my fault and I argued but to no avail. The country has changed immensely - constant harassment, theft, people walking around with the mono-pod for "selfies" will easily get their expensive phones snatched - an IPhone 6 costs $1k here - after 40 years of working living and studying in this country I have reached my limit. Women using the tram are "felt up", things stolen, pick pockets, over charged on taxis or you are told the "meter doesn't work" which is against the law, etc. The world of Turkish hospitality doesn't exist and hasn't for some time. You are not attacked like this in Greece even with its terrible economy.In Turkey expect it and it gets worse each year. It is impossible to enjoy the wonders of the country when tourism is more important - a few hours at a site and half the afternoon in a carpet store - many businesses now pay tour guides to their bring unwary tourists to their shops. Fewer and fewer don't do this. This adds minimum of 20% to the cost of an item. Carpets are now made in Afghanistan of China and NOT in Turkey and don't be fooled by the images of a weaver in a shop - if a piece is made in Turkey and they are rarely are now they are done in sweet shops in cooperatives that are terrible. The women weave 8 to 10 hours a day in terrible conditions with their children. So please be on your guard it is just not it use to be.

İstanbul was the capital city of 3 empires and because of that there are too many places to visit like Sultanahmet Square( Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia), Topkapı Palace, Dolmabahçe Palace, Basilica Cistern, Galata Tower, Maiden's Tower etc.
Plan at least 4 or up to 7 or more days, depending on your preferences (running through attractions or enjoying more slowly). Pricey, driving needs patience and courage.

column2: “One of best cities for fun in the world”
column3: Centuries of history mixed with eastern and western traditions all merged together into one city. You can see Byzantine ruins. Mehmed the Conqueror's mosques. Ataturk's wise hand and much more.

I was SO EXCITED for Istanbul. I had a long layover and spent a night with my friend who lives there. We saw all the tourist destinations, but I have to say the city was not what I expected. It's quite dirty. Like you throw your trash in the street so the garbage men will pick it up. There are stray cats, dogs, & more gypsies than I have ever seen in any other city. Also, I felt so unsafe the entire time I was there. Men grabbed at me on the street in the daylight while I was walking with my MALE friend. I mean, of course I am blonde and have had similar experiences in Paris and Italy, but men here were literally leering at me. I felt so uncomfortable for the rest of the trip.My one undeniable plus was the food. It was delicious and cheap. I cannot complain about that. Even though I only spent a day here, I doubt I would want to go back. Sorry, Istanbul, you let me down big time.

What can one say about the only city in the world that lies on two continents. The Bosphorus Strait that separates Europe from Asia, slices this city in two.It is a curious mixture of western and eastern cultures - heavily touched by Christianity and Islam.Worth seeing - the main must dos are the Sophia church and the Grand Bazaar.

One of the best trips I've ever decided to venture into. I had no idea what was in Istanbul and was sent there to participate in a professional development for my job. I decided to take some vacation time to see the city. WOW! That's the one word that will describe the wonderful city. There are some things that bothered me like children peddling for some change and the many vendors that are wanting to get you to buy rugs. Which BTW if you say "no" to them they will almost always say, "Why not!". It's their staple saying. It became a joke among my friends and I. So, why not visit Istanbul and buy some beautiful tile, a rug or two and maybe some leather purses. I know I did.

Have you been having a hard time find a reservation in your favorite Istanbul hotel lately? Maybe it is because April is the time of year that there are millions of tulips in bloom all over the city, and a beautiful city becomes a wonderland of colors. Many years ago tulips were treated as a wildflower in Turkey, and shipments of bulbs to Holland started that country's reputation for beautiful tulips. Sultanhemet will always be a unique and historical area, but the multitude of different colors complementing the historic structures is almost unbelievable. Bring your cameras.

This was a 13 day tour of Turkey. From the beginning to end it was perfect. Gate 1 is amazing. Everything is taken care of. Sure there are a few little hiccups, very few. The guide is very, very informative and very helpful. Itinerary busy but we saw a lot in Istanbul - all the major attractions including The Blue Mosque, Agia Sophia, The Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, Bosphorous, Topkapi Palace, etc. etc. Then to 5 other cities. Just Incredible. Turkey is a must for travellers. Felt completely safe.

column2: “Many visits and still loads to see”
column3: Istanbul is an amazing city. I've been there more than 5 times and always I can find new and different things to see. From the ancient to the contemporary you find anything. The food is amazing.
WE stayed in Taksim area- best location for good hotels that were not too expensive with access to all the attractions in Istanbul.
All to all, Istanbul was a very impressive city and many historical sites and the bazar specially impressive
My impressions is very good of this city, my visit has been short, and I regreat for this, you must have at least one week to visit important and interesting thing on europian and asian part of city.
Beatifull panoramic istanbul cityThis is cultural capitalBosphorus eleganceBeach expensiveGardens woodoHuman sexy
I don't like that you are chased by some sellers but except for that I am in love.It is a great city to explore
Vibrant,dynamic ,cosmopolitan with very friendly and polite people.Lots of thins to do and see. .....and to eat

column2: “we visited the Topkapi Palace and the city centre”
column3: I love the rich history of the place. Turkish delight was the best. also love the Promegranate juice freshly squeeze.

Very early start 4am flew to Istanbul from AntalyaVisit to Blue Mosque disappointing as we were unable to enter due to time restrictions.The visit to the Palace was outstanding and the exhibits were magnificentBoat trip on the river very good as was the dinner

This fascinating city literally straddles Asia and Europe across the Bosphorus. It is an amazing blend of cultures and history. The old city - the Constantinople of long past - is a vibrant, noisy chaotic area jutting into the Bosphorus, separated from modern Istanbul by the water of the Golden Horn. It is full of contrasts, from the beautiful former Byzantine church later mosque and now museum of Hagia Sophia, the underground ancient water cisterns, Topkapi Palace and Blue Mosque, to the Grand Bazaar, hawkers and souvenir stalls on every corner. Istanbul is dominated by the water that surrounds it. Ships and ferries abound and with the two major bridges link the European and Asian sides of Istanbul.

column2: “istanbul, the city of love and passion”
column3: Immersed in the beautiful of blue mosque,fall in love with Hagia sophia,travel down the basilica cistern and golden horn, everything made my heart flattered.something unforgettable to cherish upon. travel on 16september2014

Istanbul was the primary junction of the Silk Road from Asia to Europe. It has a great history and lots of interesting sights, sounds and tastes. You can cross a bridge connecting the continents of Asia and Europe. Very interesting.

A must place to travel good shopping great history the restaurants are excellent and the food is a delight plus you get more bang for your buck in the dollar exchange. you can bargain for everything in the market it is even expected. Loved Turkey the city of Istanbul and its friendly people.

column2: “World events place Istanbul between the East and West”
column3: We stopped over in Istanbul because we flew Turkish Airline to Africa. We spent three days in a VBRO flat. We took the bus or walked to the Bosphorus, The Blue Mosque, The Palace and the Hagia Sophia. Recent world history is seen on the streets with refugee families living on the sidewalks just outside of the old city. There are refugees from war torn Middle Eastern countries especially now Syrian refugees. It really brought the world events to a visceral consciousness for me and made me look for ways to help. Most tourists will not see this because they won't be walking in that area that we came on by accident. It did not deter from our awe at the historic places but it gave Istanbul new meaning for us as the place of refugees between the East and the West.

Nice people, nice historical sites. It is quite hot during summer (38 celcius). Although most of the historical sites/ museum/ attraction open at 9.00am, you might want to be there before 8.00am because after that it's already a long queue.

column2: “The Most Amazing City in the World!!”
column3: I have traveled to many places in my life and none have given me goosebumps the way Istanbul has I don't know where to start from the Prayer calls to the Cistern to the Fortress on the Bosphorus back to the Hagia Sophia and then to the Bizarre. Simply one to not miss, if its not on the top of your list it should be.

column2: “See the capital of the mystic east.”
column3: Istanbul is incredible. It was the seat of the eastern Roman empire.There are 11,000 restos, palaces, huge mosques and churches (mostlu opened to the public) Sights that you simply can't imagine without seeing them for yourself. You can take a whole day seeing the Great Covered Market in the okd city.

column2: “Nice place for lunch between Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace”
column3: The restaurant is located at a perfect place for lunch between Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace. The weather was beautiful so we sat outdoors. The view is spectacular especially across the Bosporus straight. My friend and I both had salads, which were very good and very fresh. Sitting outdoors between Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace led to very interesting people watching. Also the grassy area just beyond the cafe was perfect for an international cadre of pre-schoolers all inventing fun games without the benefit of a common language. Highly recommended especially for breaking up the day between two nice museums.
The Old City with it's beautiful buildings and interesting history.I love the food which is not overpriced.The people are friendly.

column2: “You could spend days and days here”
column3: This city is probably the most cosmopolitan city that I have ever been to. It has so must history and a must to see. Public transportation is excellent and can get you wherever you want to go; Restaurants, hotels and so much history make this city a wonderful place to travel to.

I think this is one of the most amazing cities that I traveled to. I usually do not want to return to a place but I would return here, in fact I am planning on returning to Turkey within the year. The people are so friendly and aside from the spice market they do not try to push you into buying things. The food is unbelievable! We tried several places and were not disappointed! The shopping is fantastic. Alcohol is expensive for the country. There are many tiny neighborhoods that are absolutely wonderful. The crowds were not bad for the amount of people around. I would highly recommend a trip here if you want to see a unique city!

The Perde Pilavi rice was really good. It was worth the ferry ride over from the European side. We like the place because of the food display you can see and choose what looks good and also talk with the cooks.

column2: “My 1st but not last trip to Istanbul”
column3: No one ever told us just how beautiful Istanbul really is.We stayed in the old city, a very central spot to see all the top 10 sites, Grand bazaar,Blue mosque, Hagia Sophis, Cistern, Arch. museum.etc.Do yourself the favor to take a boaround Istanbul.t trip whilst there. The Golden horn , the Bosphorus and the Sea of Mamara..It shows you the vast area a

Stay in Old Town, purchase a transport card as the local trams, ferries etc run frequently and allow easy access to all main attractions.Don't let the ever present carpet, clothing or other hustlers get you down, this is their livelihood and is an interesting aspect of the City.Look out for weird child and adult mannequins ( not live) in various clothing store windows and at front doors. Hilarious.Istanbul deserves it's acclamation as Destination 2014. Don't miss it!
so charming is the tourist spots, cuisine, weather and the people <3

column2: “Istanbul - an ancient yet very modern city”
column3: When I first went to Istanbul I thought it wuld be like a 3rd world city/country. How wrong I was. It is a modern city. But as an ancient history student, I fell in love with its ancient past, that of the hellenistic world, the eastern Rome of Constantiople, the glory of the Turkish empire. As it stands bewtween Europe and Asia, it is a fascinating city that reflects the past and still emulates the modern growth of the city.
Anyone who was anyone has conquered this place. You can see it all, ancient history, Hellenic, Roman, Byzantium, Ottoman, modern. WOW. This is my favourite city. Just go!!

We took a day tour from our cruise liner which took us through many dilapidated areas on the way to the city center. How sad that a city with so much history is in such disrepair. Among other things, we visited a carpet dealer and were given a hand weaving demonstration, which was awesome. The quality of their work is outstanding. The downtown area is newer and cleaner and not so obviously poor.
My trip to istanbul was short but incredible. I felt in love with that city. I advise everyone to go st leadt once in their lifes and visit that unrepeatable city.

great place to go, so much to see but also very hot. recommend the grand bazaar, but you will get hassled and there are pick pockets - so be careful!!!! the best leather goods OMG!!!!the city has heaps to offer on sites and attractions and they can easily be done either on foot or using the tram. Be wary pick pockets on the tram too. Taxis are also pretty well priced but you will get a education being driven in Turkey.............. dont scream i have warned you, enjoy the turkish people are mad on the road but fabulous people. Do try the local food, the grand bazaar has load of places to eat local foods, so yummy.and well priced.

The city has an amazing feel to it for all types of visitors a must visit place if bored with typical modern cities or continental foods. Tsis place is a traveler and foodie delight and charm in every season you visit.

I had always wanted to go to Istanbul and at least managed it in November 2013. I was there with a friend for 4 days and we had a wonderful time. The sun shone and the people were so friendly. They tried to get you to go into their shop/restaurant but no one was unpleasant. There are wonderful sites to see and it is very easy to get around.

Have staed in most World Class Cities and this was our 1st time here.Adored most things about it. Food, people, Hotels, Sites, (Dont miss the Dolmabache Palace near Bosphorous on Taksim Square side.Hyatt and Ottoman Imperial both EXCELLENT Hotels.

column2: “" A city not to be missed"”
column3: Istanbul is a fascinating city - a modern, bustling place steeped in history and with glorious monuments, sights, sounds, blend of cultures - that it is tragic so many visitors miss seeing and appreciating more than they actually see . The enormity of what should be included in a trip to this city is so huge that, unless you are a brilliant and intrepid researcher/explorer , you will need help and this company will provide it. I cannot stress how important it is to read as much as possible about the history and culture of both Istanbul and Turkey. Istanbul has always been the heart of the Ottoman Empire ( now modern Turkey ) and of world trade. It is a place of great natural beauty ( although this has been severely strained by modern expansion, building and industry ). A trip along the Bosphorus, to me, is essential. You will still get glimpses of the luxuriousness of the past. The palaces, museums, monuments are endless and everywhere. If you love to shop; you will be in paradise: especially in the Covered Bazaar and the Spice Market. I cannot recommend a planned tour highly enough.

I absolutely loved it! good food ,Great Prices! Super friendly People!It was easy to get around on the Ferries and on foot.I always found someone who spoke a bit of English if I was stuck. I never was approached by a beggar or an aggressive or desperate person.

The history,great food and the friendly Turks.3 days were to little and the Grand Bazaar a big dissapointment.The traders harrassed us and the one guy locked his door when we entered his carpet shop!When we tried to bargain the complained about their bad season but dont be put off by that.Walk the streets and enjoy the different smells etc.

if u have romantice meeting or new marred and visit this place will be nice but it is expensive and need to take boat to go there , u can find one boat who will take u to this place and many times come like groups and u can go to resturant there but for family not to much nice i think for lovers

Istanbul is one of the most impressive cities in the world. It's a combination of the ancient and brand new. All the people I encountered, in hotels, restaurants, points of interest, book stores, travel agencies and strangers on the street were helpful and friendly.

Istanbul has a population of around 12 million inhabitants, so you can only imagine how hectic life is. Everybody drives very fast and they all have what we call in Macedonia "a driving culture". Nobody gets too nervous while waiting in a long line of cars at the traffic lights and you'll never hear anybody beep their horn.The city lives and breathes in its duality. On the one hand, there's the old part of it full of places to visit, like Hagia Sophia or the Blue Mosque; then there is the old bazaar with interesting old-fashioned stores; "strange" restaurants where you can only find male guests (me and my mother-in-law were somewhat embarrassed that we were the only women it the place)On the other hand, there's the new modern city with astounding shopping malls, lively night clubs and sophisticated restaurants overlooking the port.It is a mixture of different cultures, religions and walks of life, but this is exactly what makes it special.
It's big, it's old, it has got a living history. It's also surprisingly clean with one of the world's best kitchens and a lot of beautiful parks.

well istanbull is a nice city to visit once but i would not go back. just the crowds really turned me off, and riding the tram is nothing short of pushing and shoving to get on the tram. there really was not any time where the tram was not over crowded. i spent 7 days there and really was way too much time in one city about 4 days should be enough time i did like riding the ferrys but they can be crowded during rush hour
beautiful city, definitely going back to learn more about it. Istanbul has everything from culture, old world, modern world, so many attractions!

Everywhere you go here you are being assessed by little greedy eyes on ways to part you from your money. There a lot of wonderful buildings and beautiful sights to be seen, but at every corner lurks someone wishing to make you trip as expensive as possible.I came here 15 years ago and found it to be a really good place to stay, now it is no better that all the other money-grabbing capitals of the western world.If you got full pockets then go, but don't be surprised if you visit the ATM more often that you thought you would need to.

It feels like home especially for the middle eastern people with the weather like Alexandria and the food like Syria you can never feel homesickness, but with a European taste of order and cleanness, try the bus, underground and the funny trip in “Funiclar” you have to try it; it only takes people from Taksim Sq. to Kabatas (1 train station) but for no reason you would feel happy when you take it and wish to do it more often.

column2: “A wonderful city between East and West”
column3: It is not just the suspension bridge over the Bosphorus that joins Europe to Asia, the culture and lifestyles in Istanbul are a delightful mix of East and West. Almost everywhere you go the ordinary Turkish people In Istanbul are welcoming and proud of their hospitality. The pavements overflow with places to eat and drink Turkish food. It is a huge success in the region to have found a way between religion and politics to create a city which seems welcoming to all. This is a tourist destination which still feels very different from home but not so different as to be uncomfortable. Officialdom does not do so well. Arriving at the crowded airport is not very pleasurable and so called Tourist Advice centres and ticket sellers at many museums lack customer awareness. Between this and the extravagant advances of carpet sellers you can be guaranteed a good holiday in Istanbul full of impressions and tastes and with plenty of souvenirs to take home.

Actually Istanbul is not a city but a complex areas related to History, Modernism, Fashion, foods, happiness, Blue deep waters and ... that make you a great DO to see them and gain the memory for a long time.But there is a few DOn't too!please DOn't Don't eat in open air restaurants beside streets!Those that many guys invite you (better to say PUSH) you to sit!I had many experiences regarding this kind restaurants (specially around Grand Bazar) Their food was Awful and the prices were as same as credible restaurants.

I loved the area I stayed Lallei which was 3 tram stops from Sultanahment District . It was cheaper in terms of eating out and quieter to be that bit out of the main district . The tram was easy and cost 3 TL per journey . Once in Sultanahmet everything was accessible I booked bus tour and boat cruise from there . Food and drink were pricey in this district . I loved the feel of sultanahmet . I especially loved the spice bizarre as it was Friday very busy with all the prayers and calling going on .The men are very strange . i think maybe gigilos - as a 45 year old women i was beseeched with unwanted attention . I couldnt stop to read of just people watch with out being approached . Had to be firm on the point of being rude . Also many stray dogs and cats every where and children begging .Be careful with prices and tickets i got caught out with a taxi fare and also bus ticket - they are very slippery

Getting an on arrival Visa for Indians was easy at Istanbul Airport. use Visa counter number 2 for Indians. takes not more than 15 minutes as there is a bit of to and fro and a walk about. Great service.

These are the cons that have occurred to me my family and friends in Istanbul.1)Shoe Polisher conA shoe polisher drops a brush in front of you. When you give it back, he pretends to want to thank you by polishing your shoes, only to be charged €50 for them.2)The non-existent hotel scamA friend booked a hotel for 26 delegates for a conference at the "Yesil Studio Hotel"Serdar I Ekrem Cd Building 44,Istanbul 34430,Turkey,Even up to the day of arrival the contact was offering a free upgrade- only to find that on arrival that this hotel does not exist! The contact suddenly stops answering the phone. (Big warning should have been, that there are no reviews of it on trip advisor!)3)Taxi conUsually the taxi fare between the Istanbul convention & Exhibition centre should cost 11 Turkish Lira.Outside the convention centre a taxi was waiting. He said that there were people protesting in Taksim square en route to the hotel, and that he needed to go via the motorway. When asked how much it cost - said that it was on the meter. His command of English was good, and he said his wife was in hospital as she was just about to give birth, so he was on his way there straight afterwards. He did not stop in front of the hotel (due to risk of getting caught on CCTV) and asked for 56  Lira. I protested but gave him a 50 & a 5 Lira note. The taxi driver swapped the 50 note for a 5 lira note, so had to give him additional money- quite simply because I wanted to get out as quick as I could.Istanbul is full of SCAMMERS, and it's own nationals have created negative publicity for itself. The hassle and stress it caused to report these to the police and embassy is not compensated by the many worthy historical sites.  I cannot recommend this place to visit, as it is just not worth it.

We stayed in the Sultanhamet district of Istanbul and used the Tram 1 for transportation. On our first day we bought a travel card which costs 7 Turkish Lira and then you credit the card with any amount you choose. We took advice from the Turkish Travel Planner and credited 20 Turkish Lira. This coverd us for 10 journeys on the tram, - this meant we saved just 3 Turkish Lira, but it was so convenient not having to keep buying tokens. Its solid like a credit card, so easy to store and use. You just pass the card over the screen at the turnstile - once for each person and thats all. We bought the card from a kiosk just above the tram stop in Sultanhamet. They spoke English. The trams run every few minutes, so if you miss one you dont have long to wait. Its a great way to get down and back from the waterfront at Eminonu and for visiting sights like Karakoy, Galata Tower, Grand Bazaar (plus Sulymaniye Mosque), Chora church for example. It also means you dont have to argue with taxi drivers and worry about being cheated by them.

We have been to beautiful and interesting Istanbul twice since 2009, most recent (April 2012). Here are some invaluable advice about PRICES when you eat out.The restaurants located on the Galata Bridge across the Bosphorus offer interesting variation in food and drinks, especially fish and vegetable dishes. However, DO NOT allow yourselves to be cooerced into any restaurants with promises that they are cheaper than the others and can offer you special deals on meals -BIG con trick!!!.ALWAYS, ALWAYS, check the prices of every item you order and DO NOT just pay at the end of your meals without double checking the bill. There is a culture among many of the restaurant operators to double charge and add things to bills you did not order. They also tend to summaries items and round off prices. It is a deceptive practice.ALSO: NEVER, NEVER, let your credit/debit cards leave your person. If you have to pay by debit/credit card, follow the waiter to the paypoint, or let them bring the machine to your table.Finally, if you try many of the non-tourist areas where locals visit for eating, you are bound to get better value for money and quality in food. For example, the restaurants located on street side (not the side facing the sea) of the Kumkapi Fish Market. And , do not readily accept the recommendations of restaurants and gift shops offered to you by your hotel front desks. More than likely, there are tie-ins and commission involved.Other than that, enjoy ISTANBUL!!!

column2: “Great trip to Buyukada or the other name Princess island”
column3: Were a large group and wanted to go to Princess Island and in Turkish it is called Buyukada, and didnt want to with a tour complany as it would of been very expensive.We were staying in the Sirkegi Area, and we all took the tram at 2 turkish lires to KABATASH ferry station, looked for the sign of boats going to BUYUKADA, bought another token at 4 turkish lires, got on the ferrie boat, with 4 stops, first Kadikoy, on the Asian side and then on to all the islands which are 4 in a row, last is Princess island, it took about one hour and 15 minutes.When we got off, it was truly a sight for sore eyes, very beautifull, we all walked to the square, to get on a carriage ride, which takes you around the island, and 4 guests can get on one carriage ride, it is a fixed rate of 60turkish lira about 25euros, we had a grand tour of all the island as there are no cars at all on the island and this is their taxi system. At one point where they stop so you can have a drink, if you want to walk up the the very old St George monestary, they will ask you for an extra charge of 20 turkish lira as they wont wait for you to walk up and back which will take about 20 minutes up and then back. We gave them the money, even though we thought this was cheating as we really wanted to see the monestary and was worth it.It took about one hour to go around the island, if you dont stop, when we got back to the square, even though it is winter there were many touristic shops for souverniers, and restaurants open.We had a lovely lunch along the harbour front, and took the ferrie back to the city.There are many ferries from Kabatash throught the day, and you really save money, I mean with the tram and ferrie ticket 14 turkish lires about 6 euros, you will truly enjoy this excurtion, and you will not be dissappointed.

column2: “Backpackers Travel Shuttle Service Sultanahmet to Ataturk Intl Airport”
column3: We were nervous about picking a good company to shuttle myself, my 2 daughters (2 and 4) and my wife back and forth from the Ataturk Airport to our hotel in Sultanahmet.... But these guys were great! They provided water for us, free of charge, were very punctual, both from the Airport and picking us up for the return trip from our hotel. The vans were very clean, they had car seats for our kids, drove safely and didn't waste time. Very impressed with service and would recommend to any families travelling to Istanbul. BTW, I picked the company because Atilla answered my initial email inquiries quickly, in excellent English, and answered all my questions, unlike three other companies I contacted.

First off, Istanbul is an extremely busy Tourist Hot Spot. Last year almost 4.5 million people visited. Up 15% from the previous year. Hoards of people everywhere standing in line waiting to see what you want to see, walking the streets, sitting in the parks, everywhere. Sometimes it looks like people are being herded like cattle with little flags waving in the air. Still want to go, then by all means do. Why did I choose Istanbul? Well I had put the name on a little piece of paper along with other places that I wanted to visit and tossed them into a bag. I then shook the bag and Istanbul came up. I began planning over 2 yeasr ago of where to stay and what to do while I was there. I would be gone for a month. (Istanbul, Selcuk, Ephesus, Rome and Israel) were my destinations. After arriving at the Atarak Airport around 11:30pm. I was greeted by a Turkey Travel Planner.com Escort to take me to my Hotel. (Read my review on Hotel Agan). Beginning early the next day, after a very hearty buffet breakfast, that was free, I was off and exploring the sidewalks outside the hotel. (I want to know where the ATM, laundry, market, Post office and the Banks are located after soon arriving at my destination. The fun began. The sun was out, nice and warm, with blue skies. I headed towards the Aya Sophia along the Istiklal Caddessi (Caddessi=Avenue) and noticed a very long line. I decided not to visit, and kept on walking along the Caddessi. First off, an Australian Woman (Julia) approached me and began a conversation. She then invited me to her shop. My first Carpet and Jewelry place. I listen to her brother-in-law talk about the many types of carpets, drinking Hot Apple Tea. This would be the first of many carpet sellers that would approach me throughout my stay. You need to know that these men and young boys are almost relentless in their wanting you to come and see their carpets. You will have to decide how you want to handle it. They may approach you while you are just resting on a bench somewhere or right on the street. It would be well to remember that this is their livelihood. Still it can be quite annoying at times. Other than the Carpet hawkers, I found that I had a great time wondering the many streets, (didn’t get lost even one time as I usually do) finding items to buy and eat. I enjoyed the “Doner” sandwiches that are just about everywhere on the street. These are little grilled meat and vegetable sandwiches with a flat bread. They can be a little dry because there was no secret sauce poured on the ingredients. Cheap, about 4-6 Lira. Roasted corn vendors are everywhere and people seem to be eating them like there is no tomorrow. I tried one and mine was not cooked all the way and I ended up tossing it. As I traveled along the Cadessi, I would stop and look at the items on sell, like the ceramics, magnets and key chains. Everyone is selling the same things and the prices from one vendor/shop can vary by several lira. I noticed that the small shops along the side streets often sell the same items way less than on the main street where all the tourist are. Example: little ceramic bowl I was able to pick up for 1 lira when the same little bowl went for 3.5 lira in the store along the main Caddessi. I recommend buying your little souvenirs at the little side places if you have several people to buy for. A note about the ceramics: I was told that they are safe to eat off/out off since they are made there in Turkey. I was still hesitant about buying any until I met Julia (New Moon Silver Shop in Selcuk ), who told me that they are safe to eat from since her cat eats out of one that she showed me. Since there is so much to see and do, you can become overwhelmed at what to see and do next. I made a little tentative list before leaving home of what I wanted to see and do. I did do the Aya Sophia (20 Lira)and the Blue Mosque (Free). A warning about the Aya Sophia. If you are going to the upper level, be very, very careful as the cobblestone walk-way can be slippery. There are no hand rails, but going down there is. Please no heels. Took one of those Hop on-Hop off City Tours that I really enjoyed. There are several of these in the main courtyard in front of the Aya Sophia costing about 50 lira. Well worth it because you can get off and explore and get back on the next one coming. Ran out of time to do the Bosporus Cruise and found the Grand Bazaar to be disappointing. It was a crowded madhouse with everything that you saw on the streets, magnified a thousand time more. I heard that there are 20 different gates in entering the Grand Bazaar. I found an easy one and waked in and straight ahead as far as I could go then turned left and went as far as I could go and then headed back. I did shop at one place that had Jewelry pieces that I was looking for. I did enjoy the Spice (Egyptian) Bazaar though they had the same items. It did not feel as crowded, though there were hordes of people. After leaving the Spice Bazaar I turned right and then right again and beganI walking along the side streets taking in the sights, sounds and smells of the fresh fruits, vegetables, sausages, olives, cheeses and so much more. What was interesting to me were the many little shops that have items that you just don’t see everywhere. I came upon a Scarf and Jewelry Shop that I simply went nuts in buying scarves and necklaces like I was bound for glory. The prices were so inexpensive. (10 Lira for a necklace that back in the states would have been at least $20-25). After leaving the Bazaar, i sa along a ledge drinking soda and people watched for a couple of hours. I never tire of watching people. Istanbul can be owverwhelming with so much to see and do. Enjoy what you do see and can do and leave the rest for another visit. By then you very well may want to get that carpet.

I had been to Turkey twice before, on business both times. This trip was however pure vacation. I would like to recommend Veni Vidi Travel to anyone traveling to Turkey. I organized my family trip to Turkey (four of us) through Veni Vidi, working with Bulent. I cannot say enough about the service and amenities we received from Veni Vidi. They arranged our stay in Istanbul at the Rast Boutique Hotel. Great location, we paid extra for deluxe rooms, incredible views of the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia from our balconies (stay in rooms 501, 502), reasonable breakfast, great location in the heart of Sultanhamet, not luxurious but lovely, convenient, pleasant. Veni Vidi sent us an excellent guide, saw the standard sites. We then went to Cappadocia (also arranged by Veni Vidi). We loved it, another great guide, hotel Gamirasu was hands down the most magical hotel I have ever stayed at. Veni Vidi checked with us at every step of our trip, its guides and hotels were terrific, service was exceptional, transfers worked like a dream. I recommend this agency to anyone who wants a wonderful trip to Turkey.Also, make sure you see the church at Chora and the Suleyman (sp?) Mosque. Not on the tour, we went on our free day.Enjoy this wonderful, beautiful country.

I was concerned. I had read a lot on line about dressing conservatively, and traveling in a Muslim country for the first time and solo seemed to be pushing the envelope a bit.All my anxiety and concern were unneeded. Turkey is an amazing country, Istanbul a modern city and the outlying areas of Cappadocia, Pamukkale/Aphrodisias, Selcuk/Efes and Kas/Demre not only accessible, but also beautiful and welcoming.Istanbul could have been a week to two week adventure in itself. I stayed in the old part of the city - about a 10 minute walk to either the Hagia Sophia or the Blue Mosque. The city metro system from the airport was easily navigable (with a transfer $1.50), and dropped me just a short walk from my hotel (which was easy to find - after three helpful directives all in a different direction). The next morning, the tourist assistance booth was my first stop.Topkapi Palace is so worth the time to tour (closed on Tues), along with Hagia Sophia (also known as Aya Sophia) closed on Mon, the Blue Mosque, Bascila Cistern, Chora Church, Grand Bazaar and Spice Market.Street side restaurants, whirling dervish performances (which you can view from the street), a city bus tour, time along the Bosphorus and Golden Horn - all are amazing.I must admit that I went to the Turkish Baths TWICE. When you are backpacking- this luxury was worth it - about $45 for the bath and massage -- a yummy soapy respite.I spent three days in Istanbul including nearly a full day at the end of my trip at the Archeological Museum near Topkapi Palace. The only word I can find for Istanbul is amazing.

For all the talk about Turkey being a friendly country we found just the opposite. We visited four locations across the country and found the people to be stone-faced and cold. The only time they were friendly was when they were trying to sell us something. Many of the vendors were so aggressive they were rude and at times a bit scary. In general we did not feel safe near the Blue Mosque and in the Spice Market. If you go there keep your eyes wide open and don't travel alone. I recommend avoiding Turkey at this time of unrest in the region.

I have been to Istanbul many times for both business and pleasure. It is truly one of my top three favorite cities in the world.It reminds me of Rome in the scope of it's history and archeological wonders. It also has the same balance of grit and glamour as Rome. It is not antseptic like a some northern European hubs, but not nearly as rough as I envisioned it before I visited.It's location and history show in everything. With European glits and Asian exoticism, the cities contrasts are what make it so enchanting.For food, you can eat at restaurants as sophistricated as any in Paris or London, or choose a local hole in the wall that could be one of the best places you'll ever eat at. The cuisine is spectacular! Try all of the mezes, Borek ( a pastry stuffed with assorted things), Pide ( like a pizza/calzone, kind of...), Mante (Turkish dumpling with yogurt sauce), Adana Kebap, and the Pastirmi ( Turkish Pastrami). And don't skip desserts! Any of the filo-type dishes, mastic pudding, and Helva are my favorites.The ancient sights in Sultanahmet are breathtaking. The Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, and Grand Bazaar are filled with tourists, but worth the crowds. In the same area, visit the Basilica Cistern. I believe it was an underground resevoir in the Byzantine era. The columns are beautiful and the atmosphere indescribable. So peaceful and calming amidst the city's chaos. Topkapi Palace is another must see. It is a testament to the Ottoman's power, wealth and influence.It might be worth it to stay in Sultanahment for a couple nights, but don't spend all of your time there. It can be congested and is more prone to have people trying to rip off tourists. Beyoglu is a better option. A big portion of the city's better restaurants, shopping, places of interest are located there. At least for visitors, yet it still is very authentic and local. Just stroll around the streets from Istliklal Cadessi to the water. Visit the Istanbul Modern. Eat at a busy restaurant on the Bosphorous. And take lots of pictures! The architecture and natural beauty will blow your mind!

column2: “Shuttle service for Istanbul airport by Backpackers Travel”
column3: We needed to get from Ataturk airport to our hotel and back again, the hotel had their own shuttle service which We requested, but after 5 emails and no reponse I was not confident they would arrive to pick us up.I found Backpackers Travel via google and gave them try:- they confirmed via email within an hour, on a Sunday- As promised, a employee was waiting with sign at airport arrival.-Van that they picked us up in was new, clean and very comfortable.Even better they had flat rate for 4 people (including luggage), this turned out to be about 3 times cheapers then the Hotel service.use them and get away from the hassle of taxi's, public transport and get to your hotel relaxed and ready to enjoy the city.

what a great city this is, look one direction your in Europe the other Asia, the other middle east. it is a location that offers everything. Blue Mosque truly stunning. staying in the old area gives you great walking access to all the must go sites. Tip for entry into Sophia is go early and try to miss the holidays, can be very busy

Istanbul is really my favourite place in the world, its my 2nd home, i wish it was my 1st...The city is beautiful, the people are sooo friendly, you cannot imagine!I was there again for the 13th time from 9 - 7 june. The weather was nice, there were some evenings and 1 day with a lot of rain. But never mind, the temperature stayed nice.I have seen a lot of things that i didnt see before and i am looking forward to my next stay... because i will always come back to Istanbul!!

I loved this city, it is rich in history, the old palaces, Dolmabache, Topkapi, Hagia sofia, blue mosque, and the system they put in place where it is extremely easy for a tourist to visit all the touristic places, and then go from there to Taksim square where the night life is.If you go there you must see the princess Islands and take your time walking in the streets of each, they have beautiful houses and nature.Istanbul is a very tourist friendly city, I was surprised, unlike many European cities, even the police are friendly. However; you have to bargain a lot and be careful at some places because they will charge you more than the average price, since you are a tourist.One set back is the residential area and the trip to the airport, avoid the rush hour it is terrible.Stay in the old city center...

Istanbul is the perfect place to go all year long.in the summer the weather is sunny and beautiful, in winter, it gives you just the right amount of coolness with a lot of rain and some snow.it's full of historic places to visit, and clean safe streets for long walks, and huge malls for a non-ending shopping days.the prices overall for everything there are moderate, if not cheaper than every where else.it's a must visit!

info@istanbulairportshuttle.comwww.istanbulairportshuttle.comI would like to thank Istanbul Airport Shuttle for the perfect service!Istanbul is a wonderful town. I stay there regularly for some days and fly with different airlines. Once I was looking for a cheap trasfer from Sabiha Goekcen Airport to the City Center.I found with www.istanbulairportshuttle.com a perfect way.The transfer costs only EUR 10.--/way and the friendly staff is waiting at "arrivals" even when the plane has a delay.The transfer is from the Airport to the Hotel and from the Hotel to the Airport.. The pick-up was on time (or some minutes earlier).I would like to thank Mr Baki Utku Uner for this excellend service!Kind regards Martin Haselmeier

If you want to visit a city with a vibrant pace, stunning vistas and an active street life, Istanbul could fulfill your dreams. While currently rather expensive, the city has a great public transportation system and does offer a number of free concerts, etc., and lots of sidewalk cafes. Istiklal Street will wow you at night--after 10 pm--with its crowds. Look up to the higher floors for the restaurants. Taksim Square is the hub, but don't forget the Blue Mosque and other historical sights. This is a great town to see the East and West meet.

We went to Istanbul on a 4-day City break. Unfortunately we landed at an airport on the Asian side of Bosphorous (very industrial) one and half hours from Istanbul and were in heavy traffic all the way into the city - not a good introduction. Would opt for Ataturk Airport on European side next time. We saw some of the major sites - the Blue Mosque, Agia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, the Basilica Cistern, Spice and Grand Bazaars, and had an afternoon cruise on the Bosphorous - all of which are an absolute must. Istanbul is a city of 14m people and therefore extremely crowded. The traffic is horrendous and we were stuck on a tour bus for over 2 hours while the driver endeavoured to take us back to our individual hotels - better to walk. Restaurants and Lokantas are wonderful and plentiful - great food. Didn't see any nightlife as we were too tired after walking our socks off, but there seems to be a lot of nightclubs and restaurants along the Bosphorous and there are a few floor shows including one at the Galata Tower on the Asian side. I would recommend Istanbul, but if you don't like crowds or traffic jams better avoid.

Agia Sophia, Blue mosque, Top Kapi Palace, Basilica Cisterns, Basaar... and many other mosques and the Bosporus. Visited in winter and summer time as well. Main sites are very close to each other, 5-10 min walk. You can walk even to the asian side via Galata bridge, the view is nice from the bridge. Or you can take the tram or ferry (buy the token in advance from a machine) The best view of the Marmora see and Bosporus is from the Topkapi palace. Blue mosque is open late (10pm) and adviced to visit late afternoon while in the morning the queue is very long and so full of tourists inside. After 9pm it was so silent and atmospheric. My favourite was the "dancing fountine" between Agia Sophia and Blue mosque which is changing the colours at night. I loved the night walks, maybe more attractive than daytime. Restaurants are good and inexpensive. I was disappointed about the Basaar, double prices and too many people.

Our week-end in Istanbul was great! We've visited a lot of mosque and walk along Marmara sea.The city itself is a great experience, full of colours and sounds, a mixture of culture, people and smells :)Istanbul stick to my heart because of its fresh fish eaten on the seaside, fresh fruit juice all over the city, the shops with great prices ;) and beautiful architecture.

I visited Istanbul earlier this year and stayed for a week though my stay was planned to take no longer than 3 or 4 days but I fell in love with this city. Its the most dynamic city Ive ever been to! The weather was great even though it was february, the people are beyond nice and freindly and the views are truely breathtaking. The city is known to have an amazing location as a part of it is in europe and the other is in asia which gives the city a great mix of cultures and traditions the link between the two parts is one of Turkey's longest bridges and beneath it ofcourse is the mediterranean. What I liked the most about Istanbul was how it blended the great history of the Ottomans with the beat of a modern city. The city is filled with ancient palaces and castles filled with the treasures of it's kings and museums as well, two of the greatest mosques in istanbul are haga sofia and sultan ahmet which are both on the must visit list in the city .The city is known for it's great shopping centres and malls with really affordable prices which makes it a shopper's heaven. The bottom line is : you have to visit istanbul and feel the soul of this amusing city !!

Istanbul is a nice city ,a mix of modernity and tradition. By and large people are nice and helpful .English is not spoken very much but you can get by with few words. Public transport is good. Metro is overground and tokens are available in token machine close to Metro station. Taxi drivers can take you for a ride, do not depend on the meter ,negotiate first. It cost 2 turkish lira per Km +2.50 lira on meter down .Vegetarian food is available on the street restaurents. Generally bread is served free with meals. Turkish type vegetables ,and rice (pilaf)are available . Eggplants /Brinjals are common vegetables. However do no expect too much of taste. Italian dishes like Pizza and spaghatti are also available as their are lot of Italian restaurents. Be careful about the toppings on spaghetti. Prices are between 8-15 lira per dish depending on the restaurent. Some restaurents have rotis being made in front of you . Turkish tea is offered without milk. You can ask for lemon. It is very good and cost between 0.75 lira to 3 lira. By and large with little bit of search vegetarians can survive

When you arrive at Ataturk Airport, a major airport on the European side of Istanbul, it is best to take the metro. Taxi drivers tend to ask too high prices for 20 km along the walls of the old part of town. Better to the metro to Aksaray to carry, you can change to the tram in the direction Byazit-Grand Bazaar, Sulthanamet-Blue Mosk and hayah Sophia, Ğuhane-Palace and Serkiçi station and Eminünü, the port is always busy piers, where ferries depart to Haydah Pasah. This station is also worthwhile for a visit to one of the suburbs combined. This is a less touristy area where the national bus terminal just a stone's throw away there. The chaotic atmosphere to this less touristy side shows the real side of Istanbul where you see, unlike Sulthanamet the Blue Mosk, Byazit the Grand Bazaar will have less problems with the Turkish population is really your money. Behind Sulthanamet is Cancutterantan to Ak Deniz, another name for the Mediterranean. Here, in comparison with other places in the city, affordable hostel like Orient Hostel, where your evening a magnificent view of the setting sun, the sea far to the horizon is filled with thousands of lights at sea and the mountains are along the coast, where the Bosphorus and the Golden Horn along the Mediterranean in streams. Taksim Street is accessible via the Galata Bridge, which gives a spacious view of the Galata Tower. It is also possible to the old Tünel to take, but if you feel the need to get past the Galata Tower to walk is worthwhile to use the many small streets to Taksim street to walk, ask a random passerby to Taksim Caddessi - the Turkish word for street-going. It comes with many Scottish and crooked stairs up behind you have a view of the Galata Bridge. Take the ancient tram which only a few stops, and through a variety of stops, a five or six, to a square go. You will also find much nightlife, where many Turkish young people.

Some travelers may wonder if Istanbul is a suitable destination for a solo female visitor and I am here to say with no reservations that it certainly is.On a recent 10 day visit I felt perfectly safe day and night and never had to fear any form of harassment or crime. That's not counting the solicitations of the carpet touts, of course, but everyone is subject to that. The biggest challenge is finding your way around as not many people speak English and there are few signs to help you. So wear comfortable shoes, carry a very good guidebook, practice your Turkish pronunciation and be prepared to ask passersby and the vendors at the newsstands lots of questions to get help finding your way. The public transportation system, including the ferries, is excellent and cheap, and the food is delicious. The setting is stunning and so are the architectural wonders. As in any big city the traffic is heavy but most of the time the drivers seem to obey the rules. Be sure to go to a hamman to experience a Turkish bath.

column2: “The best Hamam i had in Istanbul”
column3: I stopped over at Istanbul on my return from Europe for a night. The highlight of my overall visit was to experience what exactly Hamam Bath is all about and it was amazing experience for me.Çemberlitas Hamami in the centre of the city was told to me as the best one and it turned out to be excellent. The ambiance, the staff and the systematic treatments with real knowledgeable masseurs made me relaxed and rejuvenated.Its little costly than other Hamams i.e. around 100 TL or equivalent to 47 Euros for 2 hours session. Freshly served Juices, various unique kind of hamam merchandise shop were also very good.

A very nice city with great historical and cultural sights, it is an expensive city to eat out in with the food being of average quality so take your time in choosing a good restaurant. would recommend the SultanAhmet district and the Topkapi and Dolmabache Palaces.Taxi's are a rip off and they drive pretty badly more akin to a roller coaster ride than a car journey so be warned, we used Backpackers Travel to arrange our transfers they are a very courteous and professional company saved us having to travel in the local cabs and the price they offered was very reasonable.The service in Hotels vary, I stayed at the Holiday Inn in Topkapi which was not as friendly or as accommodating as I am used so moved to the Crowne Plaza Haribye which was an altogether more pleasant experience

Exceelent 5 days in Istanbul. A lot to see and as long as you can cope with crowds; particularly if you get to sites late morning; you will enjoy the city and all it has to offer. We stayed in Sultanhamet and were within 15 mins walk of all the sites in this part of the city. Sites elsewhere were also easy to get to either walking using public transport (we did need a bit of help the first time we used it but after that it was relatively straight forward).The food was fine although in general, the food was tastier and more interesting in the pricier restaurants. You can eat very cheaply in Istnabul without any probs. Alcohol is expensive, althoughf freely available. Freshly squeezed organge -really tasty as is the icecream (try modo or karakoy gulluoglu in byoglu). Baclava etc very tasty but i could feel it settling on my waist.

Be aware of the taxi drivers that are not parked at the hotel you will be staying. Those "private" drivers are usually unfriendly, do not speak english and like to overcharge. This is a big problem that is well known in Istanbul. Otherwise a beatiful place to visit. Make sure to take the public river cruise. it is only $16.75 for a four hours round trip, it leaves in the morning from the old city to the black sea.

Turkey is an amazing experience. A perfect blend of Europe & Asia not just in a geographical sense but literal sense. Modern Europe and warm Asia, would be one way to describe it.Fortunately I had read up a lot about Turkish History and various empires it went through over last 2000 years. Hence I could enjoy the sites very well and appreciate the background.Walking through the ruins of Ephesus was an exhilarating experience. To imagine that 1800 years ago there were live human beings in this wilderness and there was a WELL PLANNED city here was unbelievable.Sites of Cappadocia are truly surreal. One almost expects Harry Potter or Wizard of Oz to peep out of one of those volcanic rocks.It would be unfair to not add that the entire experience was made very pleasurable by our extra efficient travel agency. Yuki Tours was extremely efficient and all arrangements was like clockwork. The hotels were very comfortable, locations were excellent. Dedeli Konak in Cappadoccia was truly a cave hotel. The rooms seemed as if carved out of a cave - small and basic but totally functional and cozy. The terrace restaurant offers a nice view of the old city. In Istanbul my pick up to airport did not arrive. I called Mr. Ibrahim at 5 am and within ten minutes he had organised a transport for me. Great job.

I was sitting on a bench in Santorini witnessing the most spectacular sunset of my life. But my thoughts were of Istanbul. It has been 3 days now and I wanted to go back. Like the sunset itself ....all the anticipation and waiting and then gone in an instant.I arrived without incident until I looked for my name among the millions of conventioneers. I was hoping my driver was either of significant height or carrying a really long stick. It was because of the unsolicited help of a university student with a cell, that found the connection and lead me to my ride. He just smiled and welcomed me to Istanbul. It was not to be the last time I would experience the warmth and accommodating nature of Turklish hospitality.Get to know the local people who are as interested in you as you are in them.The drive from the airport provided more encouragement. The remains of the Tulip Festival were still evident. Although shattered and faded, it allowed me to imagine what must have been. And then the water. So blue. It looked right. It smelled right. I was where I was meant to be.I choose not to linger on all the "must sees". I did as many as I could. All marvelous. The grandeur of the Blue Mosque diminished by a mere child of 3 with a heavy Brooklyn accent, holding the hand and looking into the eyes of a much older version of himself and saying, "Look grandpa, rocket ships". A moment not captured on camera, but in my brain.Behind the mosque I discover the wonderful Arasta Bazaar. Certainly more intimate and less stressful than any other. Unique jewelry, art and fashion beyond the reds and oranges and blues of the pashminas at all stalls. There were subtle pastels, prints and authentic fabrics. The pure silk and cashmeres sumptuous to the touch. I purchased a baby pink that carried me through an unusually brisk week.The Hagia Sophia beyond expectation. Magnificent not only for its culture and content which certainly lives up to it's reputation, but for its incredible gift shops. High quality memorabilia at fair prices. The cookbook I want is still there. Perhaps I need to go back and pick up a copy. It also is across the street from The Cistern.Dark, cool, damp, eerie and wonderful. Medussa's head as much a mystery as the size and age of the countless carp swimming at your feet, surviving and thriving in this subterranean environment. You become aware of the sounds of dripping water competing with the subtle classical music. It was chilly that day, and cooler underground. What a delightful 20 minute escape from the heat of the city in July and August.Three steps out again into the sunlight and into my first, and only, carpet tout. His name was Errol. As he explained, he was named after Errol Flynn, had 3 children and one on the way, had cousins in both Texas and Chicago (I was wearing a UT sweatshirt and Bears visor) and that, of course, I had the most beautiful eyes he had ever seen. I am a good judge of character and knew we were in for some fun now. He said that for only 20 minutes with his UNCLE he would hold my shoe bag at the Blue Mosque, give me a "quickie" lesson on Islam, buy me lunch and walk me back to my hotel. He was gorgeous, I was hungry. What else do you need to know. We had a fabulous curried kabob as I repeated over and over again that I was NOT IN THE MARKET FOR A CARPET. He grinned, my heart melted and we went to see UNCLE. Located in a very upscale center, I chatted with buyers from Buenos Aires and Switzerland. Then out came that tea! Not apple this time, but a delicious cherry, that I found out later is available in tea bags at the Spice Bazaar.Nearly 15 minutes had passed before out came the carpets. But only 3. Each more magnificent and pricier than the previous. Then came out the prize - the Big Kahuna - that sent my head spinning. I am a designer and this last rug was the deepest dark cherry ever. It begged to be showcased in some breathtaking condo on the Bosphorus!I did leave unscathed in about 30 minutes. They were so polite and asked me to give then a recommendation.Errol showed up at the hotel the next morning offering breakfast, because of those beautiful eyes, and oh by the way did I reconsider the carpet. We shared a good laugh as I waved bye to Errol enroute to his next mark.Another day for me and it was the biggie. The 1.5 hr Bosphorus cruise was the highlight and most memorable day for me. There was a wicked cold wind that day. The festive, ornate decorative boats reminded me of Thailand. Charm, beauty and vivid local color everywhere, chestnuts, fish sandwiches, screaming speakers announcing arrivals and departures,children laughing, lovers embracing, water splashing, cameras clicking, hot tea, homes, monuments, war ships and cruise ships, tulip trees in bloom, brown Ottoman houses on hillsides, schools, mosques, forests, towers and a biting cold wind that made the warmth of the inside seats welcome and hats and pink pashminas necessary.It will be memorable always. Not to be missed, must be experienced, and shared.The Grand Bazaar a bit intimidating but manageable and appreciated more by me for it's history, construction and domed ceilings. Fun and frenetic. The Spice Bazaar calmer,less pressure and more unique. I still don't know if it was a suggestion, a solution or a compliment to be constantly reminded of the big sale that day on Viagra. I packed a bag with sesame nuts, roasted pistachios, grilling mixes, Iranian saffron and apple tea. All packaged and shrink-wrapped for easy transport home. I would have been so happy that day to just bake a 4o-clove garlic chicken with some of the herbs available all around me.It is midnight on a Tuesday in Taksim. Around me are political speeches and demonstrations in behalf of Libyan freedom fighters. Young men banging on drums and singing like a scene from LesMis.There is also hot steamy Turkish folk music that stimulates and electrifies grinding out from the countless bars. Dishes clanking, raki flowing, designer shops, evil-eye bracelets, rings, earrings and salt & pepper shakers, ceramic bowls, Gucci handbags, CROCS, gelato shops and of course, those chestnuts! I left at 1:30 am and there was no sign of let up. I was also traveling alone and at no time did I feel scared or threatened.A big challenge presented in Kadikoy on the Asian side. A pleasant ferry ride of 30 minutes to reach a vibrant market area. Time was running out and after a great lunch at the famous Ciya restaurant, I toured the food stalls. Giant berries along side mysterious fish and there it was! A giant hairy appendage sticking out from a sand-filled bucket challenging all for identification of body part. Foot? Shank? Still makes me laugh today at the possibilities. This is also where I bought a box of a confection which melted in your mouth and disintegrated like cotton candy. It had subtle flavors of pistachio or almond and certainly gave the local lokum a run for the money. I didn't have the time to explore any further the other great shopping areas of the city. Maybe next time,My regrets other than underestimating the depth of this city are few. I never made it inside Topkapi, or to Ortakoy, to a sporting event or concert. Never went to Istanbul Modern or to a meyhane or to any of the many neighborhoods I studied, or foods I anticipated. I wanted pistachio meatballs and red lentil soup, if for no other reason than to compare to that of ISTANBUL restaurant in the heart of Houston.The days and nights just ran out. However, if I had stuck to a more rigid itinerary, I may have missed sketching at the foot of the Blue Mosque at sunrise,or watching school children playing soccer and eating a simit at the same time in the Topkapi gardens where I sat barefoot on yet another pashmina, capturing these memories.I followed the advice of a friend and spent my very first night on the Galata Bridge as soon as I arrived in the late afternoon. Here I felt the pulse of the city. You've followed this account now to the end. Please google Elton John "something about the way you look tonight Utube lyrics. Can a favorite love song be directed to a river? For me it moved my soul like nothing has in 15 years.So now I understand after 5 months planning, how you regulars feel: a privileged traveler in a special landI need to thank everyone on this board who contributed to months of planning. To cinti-attorney who also has helped me with the Greece leg of this trip, to Busy-retired who has coached me endlessly and to Enigma whose resources are brilliant, patience amazing and love of this city contagious. I miss you guys already and I've still got 7 days in Greece before I fly home!

column2: “Turks are Very Friendly and Hospitable except for....”
column3: ...the staff at the Tourist Information Office. They were uninterested in answering questions, resented having to take time away from their computers screens (soccer?) , and in general acted like they would enjoy their jobs except for the tourists. Anyway, we got all our questions answered in a very nice way by the staff at the Hotel Dersaadet (see my review)

It is amazing place. Please do not travel in Istanbul by Taxi. You won't get feel of place , people , Culture. Either Walk or take a tram. It is very simple geoghaphically. Try food from all small joints. Try to go to islands . There are many .I love Turkey & I want to see the houses below the ground .. away 1500 kms from Istanbul.This is one of the best destination .... Oh , one more thing. Do not miss Sufi Culture .. see Rumi dance .....

The most friendly people, one of the cleanest cities. Cheap but still classy. There are not many historical sites to visit and those are overpriced but it worths the fact that you meet another culture and you see the point where East blends with Europe. The center of the city is beautiful yet there is a lot of traffic and the drivers are reckless. It is not easy to get lost but if you do a local will definitely help you in every way he can. Bosporus is romantic and so the tulips all around the city. Nightlife is great,everyone is up till morning all the week. The shops especially those with Turkish products are classy,cheap and of good quality however try to avoid big brands because they are more expensive than normal. Make sure you will taste everything,it will cost you nothing and give you great pleasure. Overall you should visit this city.

column2: “Istanbul: lovely, cosmopolitan, European but beware the dreaded taxi!”
column3: Istanbul was a surprise and even though unexpected it was certainly enjoyable. A surprise as I had preconceptions of a strongly Middle Eastern influenced city but what I actually got was a sophisticated, tourist centric, 'weekend break' European city. Maybe a little disappointing from a cultural perspective but a delight in many other ways. It is easy to get around, the people are very friendly, it is relatively 'safe' and the ancient buildings are awe-inspiring. The only downside for our trip (and a small one relatively) was the typical taxi experience. We caught a taxi as a last resort to get to the Chora church in the quickest time (as it was close to closing) and he played the 'you didn't give me enough money' trick as with an incredible slight of hand he made a 20TL note turn into a 5! Even when you are looking for it, it is extremely cunning. The public transport around Istanbul is very easy to use (clear signs and many English instructions) and very cheap (1.65TL for the bus, 1.75 TL for the train and tram), although traffic is very congested if you catch the bus, so we didn't need to repeat this taxi experience more than once. Istanbul was an easy 'long weekend' destination with most of the sites within walking distance. I would recommend staying in the 'Old Town' of Sultanahmet and if you wish to have a lively night out, jumping on the tram and funicular railway to head across the bridge. A couple of other points: the Blue Mosque was intensely packed with tourists and we found that many of the other Mosques were more authentic, peaceful and just as lovely, just smaller; the Harem at the Palace was an amazing place - the tiling! Wow!; costs for eating were not as cheap as you would imagine and drinks were quite pricey. But again - we had a lovely stay so enjoy!

What an amazing city. Beautifully kept streets, friendly people, lots to see & such a mix of old & new. People were more western than I expected which made it a pleasant suprise. Attractions were great particularly Hagia Sophia & Topkapi Palace & Gulhane Park was lovely. If you get the chance a cruise down the Bhosperous is a must & a trip to the Grand Bazaar (although visiting the 4000 shops was too immense a task for us!).We really enjoyed our trip & would most definately go back

Our Mediterranean cruise cancled our trip to Cairo and in its place we docked in Istanbul. We did not book a tour. We deceided to go on our own. The people had a very hard time understanding english. Even trying to get a cab to take us to the Grand Bazzar was a challange. We found the vendors in the Bazzar to be somewhat friendly and some were down right obnoxious. Trying to return to the cruise ship was another challange. On the day we docked their was a presidential cycling gettogether and the traffic was just about at a standstill. Maybe if we did take a tour of Istanbul we would have a different outlook, but just doing your own thing from the dock did not make Istanbul a place we would ever return to.

We went to Turkey in April, 2011. We had booked flight tickets and nothing else. What a fabulous time we had. Ideal for back packers. Try to find a hotel near a tram station, which then connects you to all the must-see places around the town (Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophi, Bosphrous Cruise, Ferry to Princes Islands, etc, etc)We also made a 2 day trip to Cappadoccia organised by the backpackers travel agency. They were efficient, professional and kind. We loved the hotel they booked us into and the 2 days were well spent in Cappadoccia. The overnight bus rides were comfortable, safe and smooth.I must make a note here that although it was quite a shock to realise how little English the locals actually spoke, they are extremely kind to tourists. We got along everywhere catching trams, buses, ferries and were guided along by lovely strangers. Thank you Turkey for a beautiful time.

I have just returned from an Easter weekend break in Istanbul where I spent 5 days. I first visited this city in 1987 and had not been back since then- So I was amazed at the transformation of this beautiful city into the modern metropolis it is now. I visited all the main attractions including the Blue Mosque, Haghia Sofia, Topkapi and Dolmabahce palaces, the bazaars (grand and spice) and even got time to go to two of the utterly charming and totally car free, Princes Islands (Halki and Prinkopi) one day on a privately hired boat. The food was wonderful wherever we went and was similar to Greek food but tastier (sorry Greece-but you know it's true) We stayed at the 4 star Inn Pera Hotel near Taksim Square which was very clean and modern, if a little too hot (temperature constantly maintained at 23c in the room-unable to change it) and a bit noisy-we had a side room thankfully on the 6th floor. The general area is 24/7 noisy so always get a back or side room. The staff were excellent especially the Turkish-Canadian girl on the front desk-top notch! The buffet breakfast was extensive and great value. The main shopping street, Istiklal Caddessi is about 2kms long with a tourist tram running down the centre. They have cleverly placed all the bars, restaurants and outside tables in the alleyways and streets running off this main street to enable the people to stroll along undisturbed day and night. The sheer numbers of people (especially on the weekend) is unnerving at first but the promenade is a must do. At the southern end of the street there is an underground Funicular called Tunel which costs 2.50 turkish lira (Euro 1,25) and you can descend right down to the Bosphorus and the Galata bridge which leads to the old city opposite. The Funicular was constructed to ferry passengers up the steep incline(hill) which is between the Galata bridge and Istiklal Caddessi shopping street. Believe me the hill is so steep only the very fit should try it. The old city is still charming and like a village with all the main attractions nearby accessible on foot.The people we came across were on the whole really lovely with only a few exceptions. One top tip is that there are government run restaurants where alcohol is not served (so they are popular with the religious families) which serve the best food at very reasonable prices. We were taken to one (by a local Turkish acquaintance) on the ring road around the old town with views to die for and it was one of the best and cheapest meals we had.The only major mistake we made was to go to the top of the Hotel Marmara right on Taksim Square to see the panoramic view and drink a cup of apple tea. The bill came and two teabags with two cups of hot water cost 28 turkish lira!!! (14 Euros!) I went down to reception and complained at the blatant rip-off. The manager smiled and asked me to write in. I would recommend this city as a city break to anyone. Try to learn a few turkish words before you go as many people who might serve you don't speak English-but you can always point! Top tip is to ask the young people around you- they often do speak English and are always willing to help. The city is being renovated and spruced up all over and is wonderfully free of graffiti (one of the worst things about Athens at the moment-every wall is sprayed on in the centre) It is spotlessly clean and the police are out in force -we saw no trouble on any street while there. It is not expensive and although not cheap generally the food can be very cheap if you know where to go. It was the best city break I have had in years.

Went away for a four day break. Stayed in Byzantine Hotel and Suites (see separate review), which is excellently placed for all major sites. The inhabitants are very friendly and courteous, but the ever present invitation to eat or buy may be a nuisance to those not used to Middle Eastern customs. My advice - a polite 'No thank you' is enough.Istanbul is built on hills and if one wants to walk, like my wife and I did (old and partly arthritic), then it can be tiring, but the metro and the tram with low flat fares are easy to find one's way around. We spent at least five hours each day walking the sites and managed it well, so it can be done by anyone. There are slopes everywhere, but beware of the odd irregular step that can suddenly appear on the pavement. Mainly, beware of taxis that give way to nobody!!!Food is varied and suits all tastes. It is easy to find an all-in and satisfying meal for 15 Turkish Lira that includes a main meal with salad and vegetables plus a drink, though the selection of drinks varies and can be restrictive.The sites are never to be forgotten and although you may see a mosque on every corner, each is worth a visit - if possible, as all are different in its own way. Saint Sofia, the Blue mosque and the little Sofia being the obvious not-to-miss ones. The Topkapi Palace is an obvious must and the grounds themselves are worth seeing.To relax, sit in one of the many parks and open spaces, such as the seats round the fountain in the Sofia Gardens

We didn't have enough time here, as there is so much to see, do and experience. On arrival at the Airport don't forget the Visa window before lining up for Immigration. The cost varies but US Dollars / Euros are best (no Turkish Lira!). Have cash ready as no cards are accepted and a 6-month validity on your passport is required.Getting from the airport to city can be done a number of ways, - taxi, train/tram, bus or private transfers.Check the prices and times for all, as they range from very cheap to expensive. We used a private transfer to the hotel and taxi back to the airport.It costs more if you stay near Taskim Square across the bridge.The weather (unseasonable snow) was our biggest obstacle in March but it didn't defeat us walking round the old part of the city - the Sultanemet.Most tourists choose to stay in this area, as it is so close to all the major tourist sites, restaurants and the Bosporus.Istanbul has been the capital of three Empires - Byzantium, Roman (under Constantine) and Ottoman (now modern Turkey).Everywhere you look, there is evidence of these civilisations along with the modern Turkey that is seen in many districts.We walked most of the old city seeing the Hagia Sofia (our top pick), Topkapi Palace, the Underground Cistern, Blue Mosque, Archaelogical Museum (outstanding) Ortakoy area along the Bosporus and just wandering around with a map to keep us from getting lost.It is hilly with quite steep roads and alleys to climb (going down was easy!)As the weather was so bad we couldn’t experience any cruising on the water and the ferries were bobbing around like corks in the rough conditions.However they still had hundreds of commuters going from one place to another!The Grand Bazaar is interesting to visit, however we didn't buy or haggle for anything. Be wary of a possible scam….someone dropping large Euro notes and walking off.We didn't stop after we saw it on the ground, just kept on walking.Don’t know why they do this but we were not going to find out.No one else picked it up either…even the locals.Up from the waterfront area and the many fish restaurants is the Spice Bazaar. We found this more interesting and colourful than the Grand. The Turkish Delight here comes in various flavours and colours and is one of the best buys in Turkey. We even got to taste a sample of each one before we bought the box.Pastries and Turkish Tea are also nice but you have to have a strong constitution for their Turkish coffee!The food overall is wonderful, just simple combinations of salads, vegetables and delicious meats cooked in various fashions. Turkish bread (usually gratis) is served on a large platter…. amazing!
