They treat you like honoured family members with superb customer service.This is a wonderful city so allow enough time to see all that is jammed on both sides of the Continents,There is so much to do and see that our three days here wasn't nearly enough.Two weeks for this ancient and modern city would just about cover it.We would certainly love to come back to discover more and the people are always ready to welcome you at any time.Enjoy your visit!

Arrived into Anaturk Airport around 8.30 at night, and took the metro to the Sultanahment district, where our hotel was located. We were two women travelling on our own and had no hassel.Sultanahment district is handy to get to coming from the airport, and for seeing Ayasophia, Bacilla Cistern, Grand Bazar, and the blue mosque and the Archaeology museum. This is also where one can book tours to get out of the city.However, at night it is not the place to eat or buy souvenirs. There is lots of hassel from the restuartants and shops while walking past. Food is expensive here and not very good.while a short hop, on the very good tram system. All journeys are 1.75 tl, and you are in th e Beyoglu district. Of if feeling energic walk across the bridge over the Golden Horn, and are there. Here there is no hassel, food, tea/coffee cheaper and of a better quality. The atmosphere is a lot more relaxed. From Taksim Square all the way down Takilzafer street, there are lots of side streets with very nice shops and restaurants. just walking around it to get the buzz is great.

Stayed in Sultanahmet district and monuments nearby were brilliant. Blue Moqsue, Sain Sophia and Topkapi palace can easily be included in the "must see" heritages of the world. Grand Bazaar was a disappointment with moderndays merchandise on display. The city is clean and modern though not intimidating like Shaghai. Found traders/hotel owners obsession with Euro irritating as one lands up paying extra.

column2: “One of my favorite cities to visit.”
column3: Istanbul is so rich in culture, history & art, and there are more than enough landmarks to see in a short amount of time. The food is wonderful, people are helpful & friendly, and haggling/bargaining in the Grand Bazaar is a must! Getting around the city by foot, taxi, bus, or local tram system is very easy, and Istanbul is great for the whole family as well. A couple other hi-lights include a cruise on the Bosphorus, and a traditional Turkish Bath!

Recently I had a chance to travel to Turkey with my two best friends.It was truly an outstanding and amazing journey. The trip we took from Istanbul to Izmir and Ephesus was exciting, awesome, hilarious and memorable.Istanbul is a vibrant and cosmopolitan city with a challenging, confusing and busy traffic. Walking is a must and therefore if you have never been there and only have limited time, getting lost while trying to navigate the city can be a hassle.There are plenty of historical sites, interesting districts and “uber-cool” neighborhoods that you will not be able to find unless you go with a local.If you are planning to visit Turkey on your own, do consider arranging for a car with a professional tour guide to accompany you. Not only will you save time getting from one place to another, but you will also take in more sights. And to see more places since you’re not wasting time maneuvering your way.We were lucky enough that the travel agency who arranged for our trip (Murad), introduced us to Numan Tasdogan, a professional local tour guide. Numan is not only knowledgeable and funny, but he is also sincere and polite. Aside from visiting the important “must see” touristic places as explained by the travel/guide books, he also brought us to local places, cafes and arts stores. As female travelers, we felt very safe with him, since we would never feel obligated to buy anything in the stores he took us to. We also got the inside stories of the amazing Turkish culture, their rich history and traditions, and got to understand more about how locals live from him. Numan gave us a window into the daily lives of ordinary Istanbul urban dwellers that would have been virtually impossible to experience had we traveled on our own.

Istanbul is like no other city in the world, two continents and rich of cultures. I don't even have to think twice to decide this magnificent city. Its old and yet its modern, all blended together perfectly.Visiting historical places its like no where else you can found in the world. Starting from beautiful blue mosque, the first picture that comes into people's mind when you mention Istanbul.The church, then mosque, then museum now also known as Hagia Sophia - prove that this city has a lot of story to talk about.Topkapi palace with all the collection of Ottoman empire to Prophet Muhammad's amenities are well conserved.Visiting Istanbul like you will get the whole package of everything, but one thing that I sad to see there is turk angora cats - such a small beautiful creature running around in the park begging for food.

Istanbul - what an amazing place, I dont know where to start there is so much to see, We stayed in a hotel in Sultanhammet, this is the old part of the city where all the major tourist attractions are located and they are all withing walking distance of each other. We started off by visiting the Blue Mosque, it is best to visit this and all the other sites early in the day as they get very busy. The Blue Mosque gets its name from the colour of the tiles, it is a stunning building free entrance. Our next trip was to the Aya Sofya (we visited one major attraction per day) entrance fee of 20TL. A beautiful mosque which was previously a christian church. Ther e are still a lot of christian artifacts. The domed ceiling is amazing. Next on our agenda was the Topkapi Palace 10TL a fantastic place with simply loads of treasures including the Topkapi Dagger and a huge diamond weighing 86 carats. Photography is allowed in some areas of the palace but not in the buildings housing the treasures. There are plenty of little cafes dotted around the ground with several souvenier shops. Best toi visit early morning to avoid the queues. The Basicala Cistern was next the entrance fee is 10TL be careful of slippy surfaces as this is underground as was where the cities water was stored, how on earth they built it I will never know. There are also several museums, we visited the Museum of Islamic Art in the Hippodrome - opposite the Blue Mosque (10TL). We took the tram (1.75TL) across the Galata Bridge and went up the Galata Tower (10TL) there is a panoramic view of Istanbul from the top with great photo opportunities. From the Tower we walked to the Pera Palace Hotel which has recently undergone a refurbishment. The rich and famous have stayed there including Ian |Fleming, Agatha Christie and Ernest Hemingway. We were treated to a tour by the Security Manager. What a beautiful colonial hotel. Coffee and cake were a must in the hotels patisserrie,well worth the £30 we paid. A stay in Istanbul would not be complete without a trip to the Grand Bazaar which is home to 4,000 shops - simply amazing, the choice of products on sale is super. To ensure you do not get lost be sure to take a note of the number of the gate at which you enter the hotel and that should be the one by which you leave it. There is an Egyptian Bazaar down by the Galata Bridge which is another must see. From this waterfront area you can board a boat for a tour of the Bospher5us (10TL) or watch the hundreds of fishermen catching fish from the bridge. It is best to wear a pair of shoes or trainers with a good sole as a lot of the streets are paved in cobbles and they can be very uncomfortable on the feet.

Istanbul is truly a great city, a beautiful showcase of cultures and civilizations, history and ideology one hand and modernity and progress on the other. Its a perfect vacation place for individuals, couples and familites. I was very fortunate to get a very pleasant weather in December. All in all, it was a perfect break for me. I wish to go there again......

Istanbul. There aren't enough words to describe how lovely this city is. There is something truly moving about being in such a religious city with architecture that dates back for centuries.My favourite part was just browsing the streets and soaking up the culture. Fresh pomegranate juice on the street, and apple tea around every corner. mmmmmm. I'm surprised why Istanbul isn't more of a spa-destination with such wonderful attractions.The locals are very very good at tourism. Everyone speaks English (which came as a huge shock), and most speak a lot of Russian, too. When shopping, expect all prices to be inflated by at least 30-50%. My husband and I walked into a shoe-store and were picking out a pair of leather shoes for him, and we were quoted 95 lira. The owner, not realizing that I follow a bit of Turkish (heritage speaker), quoted a Turkish gentleman 55 lira on the same pair of shoes -- and that, too, was an inflated price! We ended up settling on about 45L, but that gives you an idea of just how inflated the prices are! So don't be afraid to bargain.

We have just returned from a weekend in Istanbul. The hotel Grand Yavuz was an excelent one. Maybe the breackfast oasn,t so reach but we don,t eat very much so this was not such an inconvenient.But the town wa amaising. A lot of interesting to see : Blue Misque, Aya Sofia, Princes Island, The trip on the Bosforus.We loved very much Turkish cuisine.I think that if there was one day more it was the perfect trip.So, visit Istanbul, visit Turkye!!!

Picture this....sitting in the Sultan Pub enjoying an Efes Pilsen while the Blue Mosque does the Call to Prayer. After the faithful leave the tourists wander in to take pictures of the beautiful interior.Istanbul is that wonderful blend of east and west, ancient and modern. And it is so easy to get around - the tram runs close to nearly all the major tourist sites; ferries are easy to find + traffic, while congested, is well behaved. People are friendly, prices are reasonable, the food is excellent, there is plenty to see and do....what more could a traveller want?

I recently went to Istanbul with a group of travel agents for a 12 day FAM trip covering Turkey. The first full day we visited the mosques and the Grand Bazaar. Just steps from our bus I stumbled on the uneven cobblestones. I heard two loud pops and was down for the count! I laid on the street for just over an hour before the ambulance finally got there (traffic is horrendous in Istanbul)! People were so kind to me, giving me pillows and blankets. If you think taxis in Istanbul are crazy, you definately should take a ride to the hospital in the back of an ambulance! They took me to the ":American" hospital where no one spoke English except the ER doctor. The hospital was very modern and very much like our own hospitals. My left ankle was broken in two places and my right foot was fractured on the bottom. The doctor wrapped my left ankle to prepare me for travel to get home. I called my Sky Miles "connection", Paul, and by the grace of God he got me a first class flight all the way home. I spent the night in the hospital and at 3:30 AM the ambulance was back to take me to the airport for a 5:55 fight. When I was trying to check in I realized that my friend who helped me check in the hospital had put my passport in her purse insteasd of mine! YIKES! I called her at the hotel and she was there in 30 minutes by taxi with my passport. ALWAYS HAVE YOUR PASSPORT WITH YOU AT ALL TIMES. When I tried again to check in, the attendant said I couldn't travel alone in my condition. Thank goodness the KLM pilot and crew were checking in at the same time. The pilot stepped up and told the attendant that he and the crew would take care of me, that I was with them! I just wanted to cry from pain, frustration and joy that these people were so compassionate. Before he started to taxi, the pilot came back to ask if there was anything I needed. YEA! KLM! The entire trip was 19 hours including a 5 hour layover in Amsterdam with only 3 little pain pills. People were incredibly kind to me the whole way. From now on, I will always look at someone in a wheelchair differently and ask if I can help them in any way. I was never so glad to hear "Welcome to Gulfport, Ms. tonight"Now, go immediately to your closet and get those new "toning" tennis shoes and throw them in the garbage ASAP. Who cares if your legs look good if you're in a wheelchair for 3 months because you "fell off" those high sole shoes. They a very dangerous!!

I visited Istambul towards the end of summer. The best part of the city was its orderly traffic, excellent transport system, neat and clean roads and by lanes. The Turkish 5 course meal was a treat though for Indians its a little too heavy. The Marmara river gives a very pleasant look to both sides of the city. The european part lookes a bit advanced than the Asian side. Weather was pleasant in the evenings.

Visiting Istanbul is as you travel through a fairy tale.It has wonderful and beautiful buildings.Now in november at night is a special fog that cover the main streets and historical places and give them a magical touch.During the day as you are walking you can hear at the prayers.Also is ameizing to feel the energy of Sofia where once could share different religions for cult.Try something different an visit this special city.

We just returned from a week in Istanbul where we had the time of our lives. We've traveled to many places and this is one of the best we've ever been to. The sights are fantastic if you like history at all. There has been a settlement in Istanbul since the year 500 BC. There is little left of the early Greeks, but some of the Romans and a great deal of the Ottoman Empire which ruled from 1452 to 1923 remain to be seen. The mosques and palaces are mind boggling. Istanbul is a large city spread out at the edges of the Sea of Mamara, the Bosphorus, and the Golden Horn. This means lots of great seafood! Along with beautiful vistas, and great shopping, Istanbul is easy to get around, and full of friendly people (all of whom want to sell you something, preferably at 100% more than they would charge a native!) But don't let that discourage you, the people really are friendly and often helpful, and English is widely spoken. Public transportation is a breeze. I highly recommend the ferries. We had the time of our lives and plan to return.

We went to Istanbul with very high expectations and, maybe as a result, we were disappointed. We were there in october for 4 days, the weather was great, the hotel not bad, but on the advice we found on Trip Advisor reviews we stayed in the Sultan Ahmet area, the hub of all the tourist attractions including the Blue Mosque. The problem with staying in any tourist area is that you get Tourist prices, food, and hassling on an unprecedented scale....haggling, on the face of it might sound like great fun but, trust me, when it's for everything you might remotely be interested in, it becomes exhausting. i would advise anyone contemplating a trip there to stay in the Beyoglu area which is buzzy, young, fun, full of energy and so easy to get from to the Sultan Ahmet area, with either the free ferry, taxi which is cheap, or walking. You also get a wider and better selection of eating places. The little streets behind the Marmara Pera Hotel are bristling with great, noisy, fun restaurants that spill out onto the lanes creating a great atmosphere. If asked i would say take a Bosphorous boat trip; do go and see the Water Cistern, wonderful, dark, subterranean, classical music wafting round the fabulously red lit Roman columns; take tea at sunset at the Gulhana Tea Gardens and watch the sun set over the Bosphorous; go and have a drink one evening at the top of the Marmara Pera Hotel just to look back to the Sultan Ahmet area,lit up at night is stunning; Lunch at a little restaurant tucked away immediately inside and to the leftt of the Bosphorous entrance into the Spice Market, up some stone worn scruffy stairs,easily missed; have a fish sandwich from one of the quirky, gaudy little boats bobbing on the quay side next to the bridge for just TL3. DON'T take a bus trip..the criteria for the circuit must have been to find the ugliest, dirtiest route they could find; would say don't rush to see the Blue Mosque, what was blue about it? and once you've seen one Mosque you've seen them all; the Topkapi Palace was a series of empty rooms that went on and on with very little information about their functions, no dressing of them to fire the imagination; The Hagia sophia, was a sad, rather dirty, cathedral like edifice of no particular attraction and very little obvious ongoing maintenance. Oh i can hear the cries of 'shame' from the majority of Trip Advisor users, as i heard from friends who also visited this fabled city, But truly, if you go with an open mind and not expect too much, you might find that something you were looking for.

I stayed at Sultanahmet at 59 euros per room night for 3 days in hotel tulip house. Remaining 4 days in another place in sultanahmet in an appartment. Batik hotel experience was more good with breakfast and loads of attention. Owners were really nice and went out of their way sometimes to help. I would recommend following things:If you ike architecture, history, art and culture, then go to; Hippodrome, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Dolmabahce palace, egyptian bazaar, Bailica Cistern, Archeological museum of istanbul(one of the top 5 i would say!) Chora church / monastery and Grand Bazaar.If you are too bored of above routine, break it with a cruise to bosphorous, golden horn, drive along city walls, cable car to pierre loti, visit to mini ataturk and end up for a coffee and tiramisu at camlica hill.For shopping, music, culture, architecture, history, go to pera i.e. isteklal street.If it is winter and you are into arts and crafts adn low on budget, go to Bursa. If its summer and you love swimming, go to Black sea : sile and agva.When your feet are tired, you cant walk, you want something warm to soot your body go to turkish hamam in chambalitas. These are also made by sinan the architect and much more cheaper. Pluys the fact that they offer turkish bath the original way i.e. seperate!Dont forget to go to Hodja pasha in serkeci for turkish dances.Turkish coffee is exclusive, their butter milk is awesome, apple tea lifts your spirits, roasted chestnuts are lovely munchies and corn - boiled or roasted will make your luch and your day :) lentil soups with lemon juice and olive oil are yummy but if tum is growling, go to restaurant under bridge and eat a tangy fish sndwich.If ou are into shopping, then leather and capets are the best deals BUT KDV reimbursement is by 2 companie. I wasnt eturned money by one company as it was written in my receipt adn guy gave me only 11 leeras which was sort of an iunsult. Besides you dont get tax free shopping easily and tax free is certainly not like Thailand. Thisis one thing i hated about Turkey. I spent 700 leeras in shopping of leather and cosmetics and i got 25 leeras back whereas i paid 18% KDV i.e. GST. Plus the fact that you will not get KDV if you have shopped less than 120 leeras from one shop which is rediculous.

We had a terrible weekend. Pretty much a Carry On film in the making! Our experience of the organised tour by Senkron (The City Expert) was awful, the guide was truely going through the motions, we seemed to walk round and round in circles, the price which ostensibly included the entrance fees was probably more expensive than going it alone and the lunch at their restaurant was dreadful. Our hotel was brilliantly located in the Old quarter, but the penthouse restaurant was picturesque, the only draw back being the food! Lots and lots to do and the Topkapi palace should be given a full day in itself, interesting setting but the poor food experience and the hard sell at each cafe/restaurant mean we will not be rushing back.

I would say you just need 3 days to see all the sights, I stayed one week which was too long. It rained a lot in October so check the weather. Especially as when it rains the city stinks of sewage. Be very careful when you buy anything as the locals really try to rip off tourists. Before ordering in a kebab shop or taking a taxi ask them the price! When you go to a night club be careful. I saw Turks going into the clubs without paying and non-turks had to pay 30 lira. Be careful of the cloakroom attendants as they are independant from the club and charge you what they like! One of them charged me10 lira to leave my jacket and then asked for another 10 when I went to pick it up! I refused. Taxi drivers take the long route and charge what they like so be careful and make sure they turn the meter on when you get in the cab.When walking down the main street istikal cadessi, be careful for anyone who walks up to you and starts chatting; they are prostitutes and other shady people, keep walking and dont go with them. I heard many times they say 'Come to my friends bar'.I found the constant hassle a real turn off and for that reason I will never go back to Turkey which is a shame. But I understand its a very poor country with high unemployment and lots of desperate people who see tourists as easy pickings.The touristic sights are very expensive to get in, around 20 lira so make sure you bring enough money.A drink in a bar is around 20 lira, the local vodka made me sick but when I ordered Smirnoff they told me imported alchol is highly taxed and the price for a smirnoff and coke was 25 lira. You cant win really. Just enjoy your stay and try not to feel too ripped off.There is a bus from ataturk airport to town but in the rush hour it can take 4 hours so a taxi is better (around 30 one way).The traffic is horrendous and the whole city is constantly gridlocked so allow extra time to get to the airport.

column2: “A wonderful city with so much to offer!”
column3: We just returned from a weekend in Istanbul and stayed at Samir Hotel (right by the University and down from the Grand Bazaar) which was resonably priced, had a very good breakfast buffet that was included. The staff was wonderful and accomadating. We were only there for two full days (sat. and sun.) and then left Monday morning. Somethings not to miss:Grand Bazaar - closed on sundays. Loved the experience and we bought a decorative plate with the iznik tile design on it, a simple tea set and a couple of decorative pillow cases. Prices were reasonable. Be prepared for the guys to "lure" you into there store, it's just the way they do things and make sure you bargin with the price.Haghia Sophia - a must see! Beautiful, we did the self-guided tour with a head-set and took about two hours to enjoy it - it could last longer so be prepared.Blue Mosque - A must see! This was a quick trip, no cost and was beautiful. Ladies bring a scarf to cover your head and you must take off your shoes before entering.Hamam Bath / Süleymaniye Hamami: What an awesome experience. If you can, take an hour and half out of your day to experience this wonderful tradition! It was 35 euros and was unisex so my husband and I got to enjoy it together. Highly reccommend!!Topkapi Palace - was a nice visit, while your'e in istanbul, somehting you have to see. It can definately take up most of your day, but we toured it on our own with no tour/head set and was there for about two hours or a little more, could have been a lot longer if needed.Taksim Square - didn't spend a lot of time here as it's more for nightlife, but had to hit a Hookah Bar!For dinner we took the ferry across to the Asian side and had dinner with friends at a wonderful fish restaurant on the water.Had a wonderful time and can't wait to go back someday!!

I'd always wanted to go to Istanbul because it sounded somewhat mysterious and I thought it may be rather beautiful, but I was so wrong.It was filthy, the food was disgusting and there really wasn't much to keep us occupied.In fact we spent a lot of time in our hotel room waiting for it to be over. It was so squalid.

Istanbul is a fascinating city. There is both the old world culture from the Ottoman Empire as well as the technology and commerce of the new world. The people of Turkey are incredibly friendly and welcoming and go out of their way to make you feel at home. While in Istanbul I stayed in the Sultanahmet (the Old City) section of Ithe city. It was very convenient to all the sites you would want to see: The Blue Mosque, The Ayasofia, The Basilica Cistern, the Grand Bazaar, etc. There is much to do and see. The only down side I experienced was the constant pressure to look at all the goods for sale. You could miss all the sites if you spent all your time looking at Turkish rugs. I found that being very polite and friendly and spending a few minutes with the locals went a long way to being able to say "no" gracefully. But overall it's a wonderful city and I would love to go back some day.

My wife and I spent 4 days in Istanbul in April 2010. First time In Istanbul. Our tour guide, Abdil Bicer, made this our best tour experience ever. We saw all the top 10 sites and many that were off the normal tourist track.at a very reasonable price for guide, car and admissions. Adil is knowledgeable, personable and a lot of fun. We feel we have a new friend in Istanbul. Find Abdil and his brother Ozkan-- John & Betty Parker

column2: “What to see and do in Istanbul”
column3: My husband and I recently visited Istanbul. We took Frommer's guide to Turkey (borrowed from the library) which gave us lots of insights into what to see. Two places to visit are definitely the Basilica (Terebatan) Cistern, a great underground reservoir constructed by Emperor Constantine, and the Ayasofya (formerly Saint Sofia Church). Although the Ayasofya is now a museum there is unfortunately no information provided inside the bulding on any of the mosaics, etc., so our Frommer's was very handy -- and who would want to miss the 9th century Viking graffiti! We found the Queen Mother Mosque much more interesting than the Blue Mosque. The Grand Bazaar is greatly overrated and really not worth a visit. Two simpler things we enjoyed were walking across the Galata bridge ( we had mid-morning coffee in Asia and lunch in Europe!) and having fish in a big crusty roll by the river close to the Galata Bridge -- look for the rocking boats where the cooks keep their balance whle grilling the fish!The most annoying thing during our stay was the persistent, sometimes aggressive, sales pitches from vendors and restaurant staff.
My 3 year old son and I went on a trip to Istanbul, Turkey. I loved the architecture, walking around with the locals, eating the yummy food, and shopping in the huge markets.

Our first stop was Istanbul for 3 days/4 nights. It was a magical place. We saw all the important historical sites and enjoyed the delicious ethnic foods. We embarked on the Windstar motor sailing ship for a 7 day cruise that began with a sail through the Bosphorus, the Sea of Marmara and the Dardanelles which divide Europe from Asia. We sailed down the west coast of Turkey stopping in Kusadai with a side trip to Ephesus and on to Bodrum where the Knights of St. John settled while they ruled the seas during the Crusades. We also enjoyed stops at many Greek Isles: Rhodes (walled city), Santorini (impressive caldera) and Mykonos (beautiful green waters). We finished in Athens where we enjoyed our time at the Acropolis. The Acropolis is quite impressive as it sits atop a hill overlooking the vast city of Athens.While on the Windstar, we enjoyed the smaller cruise atmosphere. With only 130 guests on board, it was very relaxing. The rooms were large and tended to several times daily. The food was delicious and plentiful. Every crew member was a joy. They made our trip even more memorable. It was truly smooth sailing!What a trip! I'd highly recommend the Windstar Cruises and/or any opportunity to visit Turkey and Greece.

column2: “Shuttle service for Istanbul airport by Backpackers Travel”
column3: This was my first trip to the amazing, and beautiful city! So many historic sites to see. Blue Mosque, Trojan Horse, Thermal Pools in Pamukkale, Ephesus, Pergamon and Gallipoli Anzacs were places that took my breath away. 7 days was way too short! You need two weeks to experience Turkey to its fullest!!From the airport, I reserved a private car with Backpackers Travel (www.backpackerstravel.net ). Vehicle was very clean, and the driver was friendly and professional. I was offered free water and fruit during the ride. The fare was equivalent to a taxi from the airport. Backpackers services exceeded my expectations on all levels! Would definitely refer this service to my friend and family. I plan to use them again, when i return to Turkey!

Istanbul was absolutely beautiful.. The people were friendly and for the most part spoke English which made getting around easy if you needed directions. There is no need for a car rental here, the streets are small which makes driving a hassle and public transportation is abundant. We found the European end more enjoyable since it has more tourist spots (The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, and the Grand Bazaar). But if your looking for a cheaper meal or a good shopping area, you might want to take the train or ferry over to the Asian side.Beware of pushy salesmen. Though they may be friendly enough they are relentless and often don't take no for an answer. Also, though the grand Bazaar is beautiful to do some sightseeing, you are better off getting your souviners from the smaller private shops which are everywhere, they carry the same products at cheaper prices. Last thing... Don't forget to Haggle! They expect it, and you will always get a better price than the original.

The streets were wide, clean, bustling with people who went out of their way to help with directions. We were there the day after Ramadan finished so there were lots of people around, a real holiday atmosphere. We visited Topkapi and the Blue Mosque and although crowded, could comfortably move around. The Grand Bazaar was closed for the holiday, so we were not able to shop; the queue for Ayasofia made a visit there not possible. We ate well at The Han Restaurant, and thoroughly enjoyed our time in Istanbul. Be aware that you need Turkish Lire to buy tickets for these main attractions, some will take credit card, but not all. Euros not accepted.

column2: “be a traveler, not a tourist and enjoy Istanbul”
column3: Istanbul is a wonderful destination. Public transportation is easy. Food is wonderful and there are so many places so see.We stayed at the Olimpiyat in the old part of town. Great location, lots to do day and night. It is safe to walk around at night. The hotel is a good value; it is nothing fancy - clean, good breakfast and very helpful staff.

Just back from a great 2 week tour of only 8 people with Argeus Travel, with the first several days in Istanbul. Stayed in Sultanahmet within a 3 minute walk of the Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, the Topkapi Palace and a great bazaar. Istanbul is a fantastic city, mixing amazing Roman and Byzantine monuments with Ottoman mosques in the old city, exuberant youth, shopping and restaurants in the new city, with Asia just across the waters of the Bosphorus. This is a thriving, pulsating city that offers a wide variety of experiences at very reasonable prices. The shopping is great, the food surprisingly tasty and varied and the Turkish people are very hospitable. Don't miss the above sites, as well as the Basilica Cisterns, the church at Chora, a boat ride on the Bosphorus and a visit to the Dolmabahce Palace. Just off Taksim Square in the new city is a wide pedestrian boulevard (reminiscent of Las Ramblas in Barcelona) that was teeming with young people out for the evening. There were innumerable side streets filled with restaurants and people enjoying themselves. Argeus Travel were great hosts for the entire trip and our guide Erkut was terrific.

Istanbul is a fabulously interesting city. On the banks of the Bosporus, a vacation here can seem like many vacations at once. Istanbul has many fantastic sights to see (blue mosque, Turkish Islands along the coast) and has noticeable differences between the Asian and European sides.

I cannot say enough about the people the history and the food in Istanbul. There was nothing negative at all about our time there.We even extended our holiday an extra day to see more and left feeling like we could come back and see so much more.We were there for 5 days at the end of September The weather was perfect hot but not scorching, with a breeze.Hotel Uyan was excellent in sultanamet.Cafe mosiac was excellent dinner in sultanamet.The sights of the city were excellent with hardly any lines to speak of and you can audio tour almost everywhere and do it on your own if you like.Cant wait to go back

is it the place that makes a place; or the people that make the place?Feeling the magnitude of Istanbul. A walk of legends running thought you on a every step, at every turn of a corner, you expect to see the chariots racing.The aroma of food and sweets confusing the mind.The smell of the sea, the views of the opposite continents. The new and the old co-existing, where I as a traveller try to catch all of that in split seconds.The sunset glazing, where your head is either trying to follow the orbit of the sun itself or the shadows of the tips of the mosques and any high monument.Magic !!! at the crossroads of the world, and I happen to be there.And who better to be with your loved, your other halfLiving history of then, together with your love story of todayVisit Istanbul, and breath its life, as it can take you back and forth like a shooting star

Firstly, many thanks to all of you on the Istanbul Forum, who provided me with such good advice, you were better than my Lonely Planet guidebook.My daughter and I had planned a holiday on the coast, but decided to go to Istanbul first, and we were so glad we did. Such lovely people, and such a facinating city.Our first day was on 10/9/10, and after an early flight from Heathrow, we arrived at Istanbul about lunchtime and it took at least an hour getting through visa payment, immigration, collecting bags and getting some cash from the airport ATM. We were glad that we'd arranged a taxi pick up with our hotel, the Empress Zoe.The route into the city was not as crowded as I'd expected, and we were excited by the views of all the shipping coming into Istanbul. There were countless ships of all shapes and sizes out at sea.We arrived at the hotel by 3pm, and just dumped our bags, and went walking, in search of lunch. We were famished at that point, and just stopped at a restaurant where we had lamb casserole, spinich crepe, water, tea and the delicious pide bread, for 68TL. We took our time eating and just watching the world go by.We were so tired at this stage we went back to the hotel for a nap, and by 7pm, we were back out again and walked to the Aya Sofia, the gardens, the exterior of the Topkapi Palace. There were family crowds everywhere, all enjoying the late evening sunshine.We stopped for another meal, and walked around all the gardens again, but by 11:30, we'd had enough and returned for the night, and slept like logs. End of Day 1

Stay in the SULTANAHMET area - within 1km of the Blue Mosque there are numerous great hotels and you will be in easy walking distance of most if not all of the places to see including the Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace etc. and with the Blue Mosque as a focal point you cannot get lost.For airport transfer use The Backpackers Travel Agency, a service second to none & reasonble too. We also went on one of their tours around the Golden Horn & Bosphorus River trip that was also excellant value.As with any large city & Istanbul is very large be aware especially in the Bazaars & crowded places - keep your hands on your money, bags etc. The people are very friendly and do like to talk to you even if they are trying to sell you something most of the time. But they are not over bearing & you can have a bit of banter with out being rude & they will appreciate it & most of the time you will also get a cup of tea from them even after you have told them you dont want to buy anything - its all part of the experience of Turkey & its culture so enjoy.

Was at an international scientific conference in Istanbul this June. Time was limited for sightseeing, so two of my colleagues and I took a half day tour with Eda Sokmen, an official Turkish tourguide.What a difference it made to have a native take us around and allow us to enjoy ourselves as cognoscenti!!She really made the trip memorable for me!!Highly recommended!!

column2: “Heaven on earth for sealovers and foodlovers”
column3: Coming from Greece I am one of these people that feel really sad about the fact that Aghia Sofia isno longer a church as it used to for ages, but a museum instead. Still would revisit Istanbul because it is a lovable city. There are many places to eat cheap good food (like fish which is usually extremely expensive) as well as many markets to shop (i bought a case for my husband which is made of leather for 75 euros). Would definitely revisit.

1.WELL ORGANIZED FOR TOURIST2.GOOD TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM(TRAM-BUS-FERYBOT) atTourist Areas.3.Instead of 17 Million Habitans plenty secuirty.4.Too many Restaurant-Hotel-Night Club(FOR ANY MONEY BALLANCE)5.Too much to see....to litle to stay....

Stayed an entire week in Istanbul near the Hagia Sophia and then to Taksim Square. It was fun walking around absorbing all the wonderful sites and eating very sweet desserts!The best thing to do there is walk around, was a bit apprehensive to use the taxi's due to something I read about how they haggle you but I don't know if that is true or not since we took the T1 everywhere.

My husband and recently spent 2 weeks in Turkey 4 days of which we spent in Istanbul. After a very long transfer from SAW airport, the traffic was horrendous, we arrived at The Alp Guesthouse (see review). Sultanamet was a great location to stay in - walking distance to the Palace, Blue Mosque and the Aya Sofia. It even rained when we were at the Topkapi Palace not something I had planned for! Don't miss the Harem. Forget the cafe though - horrendously expensive, you get the same view above it. The Grand Bazaar was fascinating we went early and am glad we did. The Spice Bazaar, also great the sights and smells amazing but oh so busy - we went to both bazaars on a Monday. Had a short cruise on the Bosphorous - plenty long enough for us. The Galata tower views well worth it. In a city of so many people, amazingly we ran into a guy and a couple on 2 separate occaisions that we had met at Cooking Alaturka (see review). Am looking forward to going back now to see the sites I didn't see this time! We headed off to the Bodrum peninsula (Gundogan) for the rest of our stay (see review).

Istanbul is the perfect place to visit. the climate is excellent. there is lots of history and lots of romance.there are lots of bars and party places.the trendy restaurant scene is booming... great many choices!the shopping is good, bargains abound to trendy local brands and then the usual hot row of LV Prada.There is something for everyone here!

I am a woman who often travels by myself, so I carefully choose where I visit. I really was unsure of my decision to go to Istanbul by myself, but I was very pleasantly surprised. The city is amazing with incredible history and culture. I found it easy to get around and never felt unsafe. Many key points of interest were within walking distance of my hotel, which was very convenient. The people I met were quite friendly and helpful, and most spoke at least a little English. While the store owners could be a bit pushy, they are trying to make a sale and compete with many other shops, so I could overlook their persistence. I had a wonderful adventure, and I would recommend Istanbul to any world traveller.

Beware of taxis, took a 10 minute trip back to our ship in an official yellow cab. On arrival at docks driver pulled into layby, refused Lira, said it was old money (new from ATM). Then charged 37 Euro, grabbed money off my wife and threw change at her. When got back to the cabin on the ship, found a 50 Euro note missing. A 10 minute taxi journey had cost £80 !!!!.We were not the only ones fleeced we spoke to quite a few passengers who had been told Euros only.Used to like the Turks and have visited Turkey regularly, never again, thought the Lira was official currency.

Istanbul: We booked a private 2-half days tour with Ekol Travel. Great experience and I highly recommend them. They were professional start to finish. It is easy to book with them over email. They will answer any questions you have, and let you customize your tour if you want to add or substitute sights. Our guide, Hidayet Motuk (Hido), was excellent. He, along with our own driver, met us promptly at the ship. The vehicle was a clean, air-conditioned mini-bus. Hido’s English was great and he was extremely knowledgeable; even when sitting in some Istanbul traffic, he had plenty to share. Also, he moves fast! He will zip you around efficiently from place to place, and coordinate with the great drivers to make sure pick-ups at sites are fast. Hido also works independently, and can help with booking other tours, hotels, etc. He is a cool cat. You can request him via Ekol, or contact him directly at ekskursavod@hotmail.com, or Skype address hidayet_guide. We were able to see the major sites – Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Spice Bazaar, the Grand Bazaar. There is so much to see in Istanbul. And next time, we will leave some time for Turkish coffee and people watching! Both tour days ended with a presentation – Turkish carpets the first day, and pottery the second. These were low-pressure presentations. If you do not want to attend, speak up. If you don’t mind attending, I am sure the guides get some sort of kickback. We went into both, but only stayed a short time.

column2: “Great Tour Guide in Istanbul, Turkey - Sevinc at Travelium”
column3: First time to Istanbul and we had been recommended to have a guide to make sure we saw what we wanted and possibly more sites over our three day stay. Took this advice and our tour guide was Sevinc Kalik of Travelium. Sevinc was wonderful!. Our party include me and my two daughters (21+) so Sevinc was a hit to our traveling group as she knew all the standard places plus some real less visited treasures. Sevinc made 3 days of touring a pleasure. Servinc took us to the market and helped to the correct section and vendors we felt very comfortable in areas such as rugs, silk scarfs, candy/spices and tiles, making market trips efficient. She answered all the questions thoroughly with her great knowledge. Her English language skills were very good and she made good trip great. Highly recommend her company and specifically Sevinc. Happy Visitor.

Istanbul, Turkey is well worth a visit. But it is a very crowded and busy city, Once one has visited the historic buildings and markets it would be better to leave the place and there is a whole country and places to go to and relax of exert.Istanbul is not really Turkey. We had a very bad experience with a travel agency BACK PACKERS. They have a website and claim to arrange many tours and otherwise look after tourists. They arrange pick ups from and to Airports. They advertise this service with pictures of a luxury van and a well dressed driver. Our first experience was good. They delivered. The next experience which entailed drop off to the Airport was not so good. Instead of the luxury van they had an empty bus for us. It would appear that the bus was on its way to the airport on some other errand. The bus was very sub standard.We had a third experience. This was a pick up from the airport when we returned from the south coast to Istanbul. This was one of the worst experiences we have ever had in dealing with travel agents. We were met at the airport by a representative of BACK PACKERS who said the limo was on its way but was delayed. Please wait. We waited and waited. Each time, she assured us it was on its way. After one and a half hours they told us the limo had arrived. This turned out to be a jaolpy driven by a scruffy and rude driver. We were tired and got in this car. The driver lingered at the airport and suddenly two more passengers were brought to the car and we were asked to share the car with them. The private limo got reduced to a jalopy and then to share it. We refused to do so and after some more lingering and when the other passengers also saw through the scheme, he took off and drove us to our hotel after a fende bender on the way resulting from his erratic driving.The staff at this agency are well dressed and articulate one feels that this agency is professional and reliable. We found to be exactly the opposite.They arrange tours around the country and it appears that the Limo pickup is a bait to get tourists to book all those tours with them.

Two friends and I booked into the Inter Hotel (with a free transfer from the airport) and was happy with our rooms and especially with the area, which was two blocks away from the "Grand Bazaar".The shopping and the people were wonderful. Walking distance to the Blue Mosque and we organised a half day tour with Backpackers for a cruise along the Bosphuros and a walk through the Egyptian Market.Three days is sufficient but wished we could have stayed longer.

column2: “You can do the old city on foot in 5-6 hours”
column3: Depending upon your interest, it is possible to cover the old city by foot easily. Just reach the Sultanahmet sq fromanywhere in the city and then you can actually see everything around you.For Princess Island, catch the boat from the jetty and its very reasonable and easy to do this on your own. The Dolmabache palace takes lot of time (at least half a day and you need to walk a lot).Similarly you can easily reach Taxim Sq from anywhere on a public transport and then just explore as much as you want. Its fabulous, particularly the eateries et al.Be there till late in the evening, its worth the time spent.Manish Joshi

Fabulous destination for city break - it has everything, from incredible ancient sights, to a huge range of food, friendly feral cats, music , sights, sounds, and smells of figs, fish, fragrant blossom, and friendly helpful people. Of course, being a tourist can be irritating at times, with barkers trying to entreat customers into their restaurants, and everyone trying to sell something, from freshly squeezed orange juice fortune-telling rabbits (and hens). Wondeerful dancing at the Hodjapasha cultural centre, in an ancient hamam (bath house) - the most sinuous and extraordinary belly dance. Wonderful place

A fantastic city! Before going there had always thought of Turkey as a holiday destination for the beach and sea lovers, where you have cheap food and good shopping... After my visit to Istanbul, have completely fallen in love with that city- the incredible mix of cultures, history, nations, past and future. It is the city where you can find absolutely everything- magnificent architecture, a deep insight into the history, delicious food, very friendly people, shopping at the bazaars, rich night life etc. I would definitely recommend all my friends to visit this city, and I'm planning to come back there again.

I had the opportunity of lifetime to visit Istanbul and Cappadocia in May. I found the country rich in history and culture. It almost felt like I had stepped back into time and was able to live history once again given that most of it had been delicately preserved. I didn't do much guided tours and travelled with a friend who happened to have a knack for getting us thru the crowd frenzied city thru her internal gps. That said, I was struck by the lack of racial diversity in the city and often times found myself as an African American woman, constantly starred at and people would whip out their cameras to take my picture. It was quite off putting after about 5 days and quite frankly longed to return home back to the States. I was also particularly struck by how many times I was searched at the airport. Mind you my friend who was of a different race was hardly ever searched and had to rescue me on one occasion from the customs office when they thought that surely the passport I had produced was fake and he kept asking me for my green card. Say it ain't so, I thought. Unfortunately one to many of these experiences did not leave a fond memories of Istanbul in my mind. Although shockingly, I found the people of the Cappadocia on the other hand quite warm and welcoming.I would like to believe this is an anomaly, but would welcome comments from other travelers who happened to be a person of color to share their experiences. I would love to go back, but given my experiences, I am inclined to make it a one time visit.

column2: “The different types of service in Istanbul”
column3: I was recently in Istanbul for a few days with my girlfriend and we would like to share the conclusion of the experience we had a few times:If you are looking for good service and are keen on having some sort of conversation with locals, avoid the posh/fancy/trendy bars, restaurants and clubs. Stick to something simple, as this is how Turkey and its people really are.When we went to some of the expensive venues, service was very disappointing, cold, sometimes arrogant and even rude, while the service we got from the more simple places were the best - it was clear they were happy to serve us! In one occasion, where they could barely speak English, we were offered the (great Turkish) coffee for free, which was a simple, yet very nice gesture. Priceless, however, is the smile on the face of these people while they are serving us.

column2: “We had a wonderful time on our two tours in Turkey”
column3: We had a wonderful time on our two tours in Turkey. Both Erkan and Selda were wonderful and knowledgeable guides and we learned a great deal from them both. We appreciated that you came out in person to apologize for the misunderstanding regarding the time in Istanbul. I greatly appreciated how prompt you were in responding to e-mails and questions during the planning of our trip. Your reliability made the planning much easier and gave me great confidence.We have already recommended you to my wife's parents who are will be visiting Turkey on a cruise in October. I am sure you will hear from them soon.All the best,Brian Michelson

We visited this city on an overnight trip from Sunny beach, Bulgaria.The city is so full of culture and lot of historacle sites as well as modern. Makes a change now that there is no hastle on the streets although some try, police man the market to make sure this law is obeyed and enforce it, makes shopping more of a pleasure although they still have no marked price on anything, but still haggling. A guided tour is a must we were lucky to have a great man on ours knowledgable, and multi lingual we visited the blue Mosque, beautiful, sultans palaces, aboat trip on the Bosforose and plent of walking tours around the city.The only draw back on the trip was the legnth of time spent on the bus getting there and being rushed to as we had a full agenda of tours(costing extra)

I just came from Istanbul, Turkey. I had a great time, but I have some points to mention for those of you who want to travel to Istanbul for the first time.Being the person that I am I made a lot of research before going,planned an itinerary, printed out maps, talked to friends who have been there so as not to waste any time when I'm there.1. Get an Akbil (that's like an Oyster card in London) you can get it from main stations such as Taksim. You pay 6 YTL to get it (keep the receipt) then you can top it up with as much credit as you wish. The best thing about it is that you can use for the bus, tram, subway and ferry .If you ride twice within an hour and half you get the second ride half price :) Before you leave Istanbul you can return the Akbil and the receipt and you can take your 6YTL back. This has saved us a lot of money and time. Any ride using any transportation is 1.5 YTL2. A must see are:1) Dolmabahce palace (make sure you get there early, I stood in the queue for 45 minutes but it was worth it),2) Aya Sofia (it's best if you get a guide who will fill you in about the interesting history of it, haggle the price with the guide, depends on how many people you are.3)Topkapi Palace (though it wasn't organised as there are no signs telling you where you are and where to head to next and you stand in a queue not knowing what you're going to see)4) Blue Mosque5) Princess island especially Buyukada (the biggest and most popular island) and take a carriage for 50 YTL an hour and you split the money with the people who will take the carriage with you to tour the whole island, it is amazingly beautiful.6) Bosphorus cruise7) Visit Bursa City and take a ride with the cable car but be prepared to stand for long hours in the queue.8) Spice Bazaar.9) One of the tourist traps (based on many websites) is the Grand Bazaar they sell the same things as Spice Bazaar but with much higher prices. Take a look but buy from Spice Bazaar.3. Whatever you do DON'T take a taxi, they lie and cheat and they don't understand any language other than Turkish! I took a taxi and he misheard where I wanted to go then when I told him to take me back where he picked me up he said ok, but I ended up in a totally different place almost outside Istanbul, he charged me 60 YTL. I called for the police and they too don't speak except Turkish!! To make a long story short I only paid half the price for the taxi and a very decent man ,who happened to be a tour guide with a mini van, spoke Arabic and Turkish so he communicated with the police , driver and me. Then he dropped me off near my hotel.. He refused to take any money from him. He only gave me his card and asked me to recommend him for other people I know. His name is Mohammed Yasar his number is +905355100456 and his email is mehmet-turkish@hotmail.comGold bless him :)4. Make sure you learn a few phrases in Turkish as most people don't speak except Turkish, actually I found it easier to use some Arabic words than English, turns out we have many words in common.5. Check instructions with them and make sure they understand the price you're talking about. For instance somebody told me that a t shirt costs 50 YTL when he meant 15 YTL. So asked "do you mean one five or five zero?" or better let them use a calculator to show you the number.6. Haggle, haggle and haggle. For those who come from countries that don't haggle ,in Istanbul you should. That wasn't something hard for me :)Enjoy your stay there, it's a beautiful place and people are friendly, although most of them don't speak except Turkish but they really wanna help you and feel frustrated when they can't communicate. I used a lot of sign language just make sure it's not offensive!!

We spent 3 days touring with Seda Gunay Karaca of Travelium. She made the touring so easy in a very crowded city at the peak of tourism season. Seda has a very good knowledge of Istanbul, her history and all the sites we visited. Rent a car and driver for a day and visit Dolmabace Palace and sites in the new section of the city is highly recommended. Take a drive out to Anatolia if time permits. Having Seda with us made the touring a pleasure - bypassing the long lines at the ticket office, for one. This alone saved us hours. She took us to a great place for lunch near the Spice Market and even though it was crowded, she managed to get us a front row table for 5 with fantastic views of Istanbul.

I wasn't expecting to fall in love with Istanbul, but after staying there for ten days, I think it is my favourite city in the world. To say it is the place where East meets West is an oversimplification. East has been meeting West here for 4,000 years. So what has formed is a unique and compelling hybrid culture.I stayed in the Sultanamet district, where the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque are, and I would highly recommend that visitors stay here, because all these wonderful places are within easy walking distance. The steep, winding cobbled streets are charming and there are remnants of the different periods of the city everywhere you look. It feels very Eastern and Islamic. Public transportation is excellent and very cheap.The ancient monuments are definitely worth the price of admission, but don't miss the amazing Museum of Archeology in the grounds of the Topkapi Palace. Stunning and immaculately curated.Across the Galata bridge, you step into a different city. Great swathes of the architecture are 19th century rococo. Take the walk down Istaklal from Taksin Square, or ride the crazy little tram, and see the old crumbling cinemas with their poignant, crumbling European style facades. Don't hesitate to explore the little alleyways leading off from the grand boulevard. Every one of them promises something new and charming.According to the men I was traveling with, the Turkish Bath experience is over-priced and cursory, but for women, it's a fabulous experience that takes you back to a civic activity that began here long before the Christians or the Moslems arrived. It's a unique experience that is both startlingly historic and intimate at the same time. There's really nothing like it, as long as you're not overly modest.They say that a city is its people, and this is very true for Istanbul. Considering that it is constantly barraged by tourists, I found people to be consistently good humoured and charming. Very proud of their city and eager for you to admire it as well.Finally, don't go if you're watching your weight. This is, perhaps, the most delicious city I've ever visited. In 10 days I had only one mediocre meal. It's very hard to stop eating because everything is just so good.For such an ancient city, it's also very modern. The connectivity is great. $20 bought me a SIM card with 3G access which allowed me to photograph and tweet my whole visit, documenting it on a daily basis.The only drawback to Istanbul is that accommodation and food is a bit on the expensive side. Both are equivalent to London prices and, considering the average income in Turkey, this seems a little high. Nevertheless, it was worth every penny. I can't wait to return.

column2: “Watch out from a tour guide named Mr. Bes Bulent Simsek”
column3: Folks, just wanted to alert you of a professional tour guide in Istanbul...he is nice and polite but does not list his price on the front-end. I questioned him about his prices and he keeps skirting around...just make sure folks you are clear before going on tour how much he charges...I got a rude awakening with him. Just want folks to be safe in Istanbul.

A visit to Istanbul is a must! It truly is the crossroads between East and West.If booked in advance, you can find cheap flights from Europe to IST. Turkish Airlines has direct flights to many European cities.Things to do: go visit Sultan Ahmed for the crazy shopping experience, but remember to bargain hard! Also if you have time take a cruise along the Bosphorus, it is a great way to take in this vast city.The Four Seasons in Sultan Ahmed is really nice. The bruch there is simply the best I've ever had. It can be quite pricey but definitely worth a visit.Walk along Istiklal and you will find some wonderful Turkish restaurants that are reasonably priced and offer delicious food. For views of the city I recommend having a coffee at The Goethe-Institut which offers a beautiful panoramic view of the city.

column2: “nice bar in the center of the new town (near Taksim)”
column3: Just a few roads from Taksim down Istiklal str. you can find this bar. We haven't been long in the bar at the 3 floor but went to the top floor of the building where you can sit in a nice room, open to the street like a terrace, and have your beer (3,50 TL for the small one (0,3 l) and 5 TL for the large (0,5 l)). Not fashionable, but very friendly atmosphere.

column2: “The Perfect Mix Of Exotic, Chic, Old and New”
column3: I just returned from the most amazing trip in Istanbul which far surpassed my high expectations. The culture, nighlife, food, people, shopping and even the Turkish wines were all increadible. Most of the locales / sights that I visited were recommended by a friend from Istanbul who lives in NY.Here are a few simple suggestions that will help contribute to an equally wonderful experience:Stay at a hotel in the new part of the city (Besitas, Nisantasi, Taksim, Beyoglu, Ortakoy or any of the surrounding areas). You'll get tired of the haggling restaurant and shop workers in the Sultanhamet area + you'll want to concentrate your dining out and nightlife in these areas, as they're full of great restaurants, cafes, bars and night clubs that are frequented by locals and internationals. Taxis get quite expensive late at night, so it also helps when you're staying nearer to the nightlife. The tram is a quick and easy way to get in and out of the historic zone for sightseeing / bazaar shopping during the day. The W Hotel was my pick...very hip, great location and service. There are many other hotels in the general area to choose from. My trip would have been a totally different experience had I stayed and dined / gone out in the Sultanhamet zone where most of the tourists congregate.When in the historic zone (Sultanhamet) do not book a tour by the operator SHE TOURS. This was the only negative experience of my whole week long trip and everyone in our tour group was equally disappointed. If you go to a travel agency and they show you a brochure with SHE TOURS on it, do not book it. The travel agency that we booked through was called AHSLY TRAVEL, near the Four Seasons Hotel in Sultanhamet. They were very kind people, however the tour that they sold us, which was $65 Euro for the day, was not the tour that we received. There were many discrepancies between the agenda that we were sold and what the tour actually offered + the meal on the tour was horrible, the guide was very grumpy and not the most knowledgeable and they included a "surprise" visit to a leathergoods store, wasting everyones time trying to sell leather products.The only piece of advice from my Turkish friend that I did not follow was to tour the Bosphorus via the Ferry boats and just get on and off at different stops. This is a cheaper and much better option that I wish I had done instead of choosing the above "all day" tour by SHE TOURS, which included a quick stint halfway up the Bosphorus. If you do explore the Bosphorus via Ferry for a day, one recommendation of a place to stop for a delicious brunch in a beautiful setting is a restaurant called Sutis in Emirgan, which is north of the second bridge on the Bosphorus, on the European side. This brunch was such a memorable experience that my friend and I had to repeat on our last day.

I have just returned from a 9 days trip to Istanbul, it is an amazing city. Lots of historical places which are very beautiful like Aya Sophia, blue mosque, Topkapi palace and more, the city is clean, good transportation (tram, metro, bus, metrobus, taxi). The food is delicious, the weather is very nice. The only problem is that almost nobody speaks English

History, History and more history - Istanbul is best experienced if you take it easy and not be doing usual tourist rounds of places to see but , chill , sit around the sea side glaze at the past and enjoy the weather. Lots of antique feel to the city and its got some stunning views and the best part being its a city where no one interferes or bothers you. People in trams/trains/buses seldom talk or even say hello , no usual shop keepers trouble (some places but mostly ok) and some very busy streets with wonderfully fashionable people (Taksim street). Loads of cafes/restaurants and eateries (a bit too much) and sea side walkways / parks and historic monuments. Overall its a city were history is at ease and if you stay away from touristy traits, and spend time by yourself , very romantic.

column2: “Excellent Tour Company and Guide in Istanbul”
column3: Istanbul is an incredible city; it is cosmopolitan, yet old and charming.. We had two and a half days to spend there so we decided to hire a private guide to show us around. We went through Byzas Tours, arranging everything from the states (which was very efficient). We decided to do a cruise on the Bosphorus for the first day (great idea given the jet lag), and for the second day, we did a walking tour of the old city. On the morning of our first tour we were greeted by our guide, Ozer Sahin who was prompt, welcoming and had a great command of the English language. We spent two days with him as he gave us an insider's view of this exotic city. He was knowledgeable about the history from Greek and Roman times, through all the various Sultans, to the present. He was also wonderful with our two children, pointing out things that would interest them. We would highly recommend getting a private tour, going through Byzas and requesting Ozer!

My wife and I visited Istanbul from May 11th to 18th 2010. I had been before a couple of years ago and loved it and it's fair to say that my wife also fell in love with this great city.We stayed at the Hotel Ipek Palas in Sirkeci, Sultanehmet and all main sites were walking distance from the hotel, such as, Topkapi Palace, Aya Sofya, The Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern and the bustling port of Eminonu. We also walked to the Suleymaniye Mosque and the Grand and Spice Bazaars. Unfortunately, The Sulayminaye Mosque is undergoing restoration and is closed for 2010, but having visited it the last time I was in Istanbul, it is a beautiful mosque.We also went on a day cruise of the Bosphorus for 25TL each. We bought our ticket from Eminonu and that is where we left from. We did the round trip which took an hour and half, and ended up at Anadolu Kavagi, where we spent around three hours having lunch and a 30-50 min walk up to view the ruins of a medieval castle, with an breathtaking view once you reach the top. This is a good alternative if you don't want to spend the 50TL price for the cruise, which you will find in hotel brochures.We also took a tram to Kabatas to get to near the Dolmabache Palace, which, although we did not see from the inside, looked spectacular when we went past it on the cruise.You need a good half day and some more for visiting the Topkapi Palace. Not all sections were open due again to renovations, however, we did see the Harem section and also the sacred relics section, which was a wonderful experience. To enter the palace cost 20TL each and the Harem cost an additional 15TL each.We also caught the Tram to Istiklal Cadessi, the modern Istanbul, and although we walked to most sites, catching the tram was just as easy. This area was full of International high street and designer shops.One of the evenings we went to see a performance of the Whirling Dervishes. Although we were really glad we went to see it, at 40TL each, it is may be a slight expensive as it was only for an hour.Restaurants are plenty in Istanbul and we ate at Pasazade, which is Erboy Hotel's restaurant, and served delicious Ottoman style cuisine with excellent service. We also ate at Ozler restaurant, which was near our Hotel and our final meal was at the Aruna Cafe, which is under the Galata Bridge next to a whole host of other cafes and restaurants. Four of our evenings were spent at Aruna Cafe, where we would finish the day with a coffee and Nargileh (water pipe), taking in the view of the boats and feeling the wind of the Bosphorus river, as well as watching the beautiful Eminonu Mosque in front of us. We also ate at a couple of local restaurants/cafes, which may not have been as fancy, but were just as nice and much cheaper. Having read reviews on here and being warned on some restaurants charging extra, we experienced this only once where upon looking at our bill we were charged for expensive water, which was provided to us, not ordered by us.People in Istanbul are very friendly, which enhances the experience and it is definitely a city we would like to visit again some day.Apart from a couple of showers on one of the days, weather was brilliant; warm and sunny.

If you are visiting Istanbul, be sure to check out an excitingly different restaurant - Djezzu - good food, attentive service, good music and excellent wine. This is a must visit, so different from all others in the area of Sultanhamet, near the Blue Mosque

Hi,I recently stayed in Istanbul for a week before travelling to Cappadocia and Ephesus. I arrived in the city with little idea of how to get around Turkey. The hotel I stayed in The Empress Theodora had some wonderful staff that recommended the travel agency up the road. Road Runner Travel was the place and after visiting several agencies along the way I went back to Road runner. The staff were very friendly they gave me advice on how to avoid carpet sellers and touts, how to protect myself and my property whilst travelling (although I have never felt safer than travelling in Turkey) The guys in Road Runner put together my itinerary and I discovered it was actually cheaper but with more inclusions than the other places I enquired at. They booked my hot-air balloon flight for about 40 Euros cheaper than others flying on that day, and their two Cappadocian tours were fully comprehensive and complete.I couldn't recommend these guys enough, they were friendly and honest and a pretty good price, I'm sure they made a profit but thats their job in the end.

column2: “Shuttle service for Istanbul airport by Backpackers Travel”
column3: I heard the cabbies in Instanbul were known to hustle you, and somehow my wife found this group Backpackers Travel. They took us to our hotel and we liked the service so much we had them take us back. It was very easy to contact them by email and by phone. I strongly recommend them. You can get them at transfer@backpackerstravel.net.

My time in Istanbul and Turkey was an unforgettable experience."Aussie Travel" Agency located in Sultanhamet was very helpful and organsied a trip around turkey for us at a very good price.I recommend travel to Turkey.
Excellent weather , nice, friendly & warm people, fantastic history, out of world locations. Highly recommended for anyone interested in history, adventure,shopping and entertainment.

column2: “shopping, nightlife, cuture trips, everything for every age”
column3: we travelled with 3 friends. our main aim was to see some museums, cultural events, nightlife, experience the local food and city travel.we stayed in sultanahmet area very close to historical sites in an hostel. it was a very budget stay but staff and enviroment was nice. we had no negative experience.there is taxim and grandbazaar for shopping.very easy to access with public transport or walking.at nights we have been in taxim near tunel area. where all the pubs and most famous clubs are located.local people were friendly and we very much enjoyed our stay in stanbul.we have been on june and it was very hot and sunny. they adviced may was the best time.

We've just returned from Istanbul and must recommend our amazing tour guide, Lale Kosagan. We were in Greece and Turkey for 12 days and the highlight of our vacation was the day spent with Lale. We opted for a walking tour of the old city of Sultanahmet and saw many of the major sights. Lale's knowledge and stories was mesmerizing and we could have stayed with her for hours more!! I highly recommend her tour company for tours in Turkey. You can search the boards for Kagan Kosagan or Lale Kosagan and be directed to them.We stayed at the Sari Konak and it was all the good things that you read about on these tripadvisor boards. Great location and good value! Don't miss a turkish bath at Cemberlitas! You won't forget it!

column2: “Shuttle service for Istanbul airport by Backpackers Travel”
column3: Used excellent Shuttle service offered by Backpackers Travel from Sabiha Gokcen (SAW) to Taksim( Eur 50), and from Taksim to Ataturk (IST, Eur 20). Relaible & quick service. We were 2 hours late exiting SAW after Blu-Express lost our bags but our driver was waiting patiently for us. Slight premium to regular yellow taxis (quoted TL 90 [ approx Eur44] for Taksim->SAW) but deifintely worth it. Will definitely use these guys next time we're in town.

column2: “Shuttle service for Istanbul airport by Backpackers Travel”
column3: We were very happy with transfers from and to airportThe staff and the drivers were very polite, professional, offered us snacks in the car. The cars were very clean and comfortable. Both drivers came on time. We appreciated drivers not smoking and even asking if the radio music is OK with us. The value for the money was great ( 35 euros round trip). We'd certainly recommend these services to others. Thanks to ther excellent service our trip to Istanbul was very smooth.

We stayed in Istanbul for 6 nights and enjoyed every moment of it!To start with: where to stay as a tourist - Sultanahmet. Look no further. There are lots of good boutique 3*-4* hotels in Sultanahmet. Staying in Sultanahmet, you will be truly able to explore the city on foot - and that is where the beauty of this city lies. Its a city that will do full justice to a pair of good walking shoes! Its either uphill or downhill, with cobbled streets, narrow streets with history at every nook and corner, literally.The main sights not to be missed are: Blue Mosque, Hippodrome and the Obelisk, Hagia Sophia, Underground Cistern - all can be finished in 1/2 day provided u are not slowed down by crowds. Try and visit the Mosque at prayer time - its magical!The Topkapi Palace will take a little more than a half day - don't miss the Harem section. The treasury section and the section on Faith are superb too!The Istanbul Archaelogical Museum is adjacent to the Topkapi palace and can be done on the same day, provided u are quick looker of museums. If Archaelogy is your passion, even a day will not be sufficient to see the archaelogical collection, far wider then the one at the Louvre.We visited the Prince's island and loved it. The experience of the ferry, the views from the top of the mountain, the houses are truly worth the visit.If you have the time, I would always suggest taking the Long Bosphorus Cruise (instead of the short one) of the public ferry. The climb up the Yoros castle is tiring but the views from the top are truly worth it! Infact, the 3 hour halt is just about sufficient to enjoy the views from the top and grab a great fishy meal!If you have the time, visit the Dolmabache Palace for its very Versailles like feel and the grandeur. Galata Tower top will give you lovely views of the city. No you dont have to climb the Tower - there is an elevator to take you there!The Yeni mosque (at Eminonu) next to the Spice Market is worth a visit too. We went to the Mosque of Suleimiyan, but unfortunately it was still closed for restoration.Since, we were travelling with our 7 year old son, we visited Miniaturk, and he loved it. Its across the Golden Horn. We even went as far as the Dolphinarium, but walked away as the thought of seeing a dolphin show in a closed stadium which did not look too large was not appealing to us, after having visited similar shows at Hongkong and Singapore.The Grand Bazaar is large but overrated - maybe I felt that way because I come from India, where we are used to seeing such Bazaars. The Spice market was interesting and full of enticing smells. Interestingly, there is a street behind the Spice Market, where we found one of the best shops for buying our dry-fruits and nuts.In Istanbul, you will get good food everywhere - and its most expensive at Sultanahmet. The moment you step a little away from main Sultanahmet street, you will see the prices come down by as much as 50% - 60%.We thoroughly enjoyed the beautiful coastline with its rolling patches of green and the Promenades at the Golden Horn and on the Kumpaki side.The tram is super-efficient and the best way to get around in historical Istanbul.A visit to the Asian side is warranted if you have the time. We did and got to see a very different side of the city. We stopped by at this place called "Khunchungu", where we got the most amazing view of the Galata Bridge, sipping some Elma (Apple Tea) and Turkish Coffee!The Turks love their food and so did we. Try the Doner Kebabs, doner rolls, mezze, gozleme (turkish pancakes), Lamachun (like our thin-crust pizzas topped with meat, veg), Pide (turkish boat-shaped pizza), Elma (turkish apple tea), turkish coffee, and Sutlac (the rice pudding). Awesome!Istanbul maybe a mega-city but at its heart - its as Mediterranean as it can get, with its cobbled streets, cafe's and the air which says "time has stopped"!!

column2: “Entering Turkey and Istanbul Staying in Asia Visiting Europe”
column3: First trip to Turkey (Istanbul) so after three days I thought I would write a short advice column for those less "Turkey Traveled than I".For US/UK/CAN/EU citizens forget about advanced Visa Applications. Upon landing in Istanbul look around (to your left or right) and you will see a kioks with the words VISA in white on a blue background. There you can purchase a 30 day multi pass Visa for $15 or 10 Euro.We stayed (are staying) on the Asia Side (on business but here for the weekend) at the Marriott Asia. The question "how to get downtown to the Sophia Hagia and Blue Moscow" is a difficult one given Istanbul's Horrific and Terrible Traffic (never never never think about renting a car for a down town trip!).The answer is to take a water TAXI from the Asian side. Get a cab to take you to the Asian Water Terminal and for 1.5 Turkish Lira (at this point about $ 1.10) you can take a breath taking (overused but appropriate word) trip across the straight to downtown Istanbul with the pleasure of seeing the Blue Mosque, the Sophia Hagia and Faith Mosque slide into view.Once at the dock, cross under (never over or accross unless you want to get killed) the busy street using the tunnels (combination tunnel and Turkish Bazaar) and then walk following the tram tracks which will take you directly to the Blue Mosque and the Sophia Hagia.If you engage in ANY conversation or answer ANY question from a "friendly Turk" beware- whether you know it or not you have just entered into a negotiation about a) buying a tour, b) buying a rug, c) buying some glazed potterry, c)" visiting my restaurant for the absolute, I promise you, best meal in all of Turkey". There is nothing dangerous at all- because you are visiting, after all the land of haggle and negotiations.NEVER NEVER NEVER NEVER pay full price or even 80% price for ANYTHING except a) cab, b) the amount posted on a menu and c) the hotel bill. I would NOT settle for anything LESS than a 50% discount.
