Of course you will have to leave the shop after your last offer and have the merchant chase you down the street.Wandering around Istanbul is a true pleasure with the calls to prayer the haggling and hubbub and the resaurants with no alcohol but "would you like me to bring a Fanta flavored Hookah pipe for you to smoke?".Must seesa) Blue Mosque (women can get a scarf at the Mosque NO shorts or legs)b) Faith Mosque (same as above)c) Palaced)Sophia HagiaOkay I admit I did something I swore I would never ( a self proclaimed do it myselfer)- I took the half day taste of Turkey Gray lLine tour for $ 25 (60 Lira). Nice way to get oriented in this chaotic place!More later on restuarants and hotels.Cia

We spent 4 days in Istanbul and 4 days in the Cappadocia region of Turkey in May 2010. We found the people very friendly, the sites interesting and the activities exceptional. Rina at Insight Travel did an excellent job of getting us just what we wanted in terms of accomodation, flights and car rental. She also offered us some very valuable advice. I would definitely recommend Insight and will use them on my next visit.Mark

What a beautiful, international city! We had one day to tour after a 12 day cruise. Our guide, Lale Kosagan, KSG Tours and Travel Services, met us at the ship, transferred luggage to the hotel, then took us on a walking tour of the city. Lale gave us a wonderful, historical tour of the Blue Mosgue, the Castle of the Sultan and the Harem, Hagia Sophia Museum, lunch at a local spot, Turkish Carpet place, coffee shop, and the Grand Bazaar. Wow, so much to see, we'll have to return for the rest!

column2: “Be aware of taxi drivers in Istanbul”
column3: When taking a taxi in Istanbul be aware that the 50 Turkish Lira paper money looks like the 5 urkish Lira paper money. If you give the driver the 50 - pay attention that he is not changing it fast to 5 and tells you that it is not enough.

Just left Istanbul after our third visit. What a fabulous city! We stayed at the Aruna Hotel in the Sultanahmet district so ideally placed for some of the main attractions. Ask for a room at the back of the hotel as the rooms at the front are noisy.Our highlights are the Hagia Sophia, Dolmabahce Palace, Basilica Cistern, just walking about soaking up the atmosphere...This time, we booked two excursions through the hotel with Senkron Tours. The first half day excursion was excellent - Dolmabahce Palace and a trip to the Asian side. The second half day trip was a cruise up the Golden Horn, the Bosphorus and a stop at Maiden Tower.Up until the end of the boat tour, we loved it and we would recommend it highly however our guide kept mentioning a fashion show at the end which was strange as it wasn't stated in the brochure. Anyway, after we got off the boat we were driven to a leather shop on Kennedy Caddesi, a long walk back to Sultanahment. We had to endure an embarrassing fashion show of leather and fur (can't believe that people still wear fur) with a sales pitch after.There were 13 of us on this trip and we all felt embarrassed, angry and awkward. We should have objected but I don't think any of us really believed it was happening. The guide sure blew his tip!The excursions were good but if you do book your excursions in Istanbul with Senkron Tours make sure you ask if there is an added 'extra' you weren't anticipating.

column2: “great experience with Argeus Tourism and Travel”
column3: Thanks to Argeus- Chickworld was able to give an ideal Turkish Experience to the group of 20 women from India. It was a wonderful trip taking in the best of Istanbul and Cappadocia.It was hard on me initially to decide on an agent to take care of all our needs- a group of 20 women all travelling for the first time to Turkey, with various interests, tastes and inclinations. After a long research on various Travel websites and blogs , I decided to work with Argeus- and I strongly believe that it was a wise decision. From the time of planning, booking hotels, flights, meals etc, Mehmet from Argeus, was fantastic- his response to my emails were as prompt as could be and the options as desired by me were carefully looked into. After arrival in Turkey, from the point of luggage handling at the airport right till the point of departure we were well looked after. Our guides were good, the details on our itinerary were carefully planned, the places for all our meals as wanted by me, were looked into by them, and changes as we moved on, were met with without complaints. Accounts were meticulously handled .We have had a wonderful trip to Turkey, and I am thankful to Argeus for its efficiency and service. It is indeed a beautiful country, with so much to offer that it leaves one with enough oppurtunities to return. Whenever I do, I will surely use their services again.

Istanbul is a nice city , live at night and the most thing to do there is Eating and Shopping, lol. ..i think ladies must love this,you can transport there by this bus the called Dolmus(pronounce dolmosh) or metro and tourists bus for those who wanna see the city and it's historical places,like masque or Ataturk palace,all around the city is Doner kebab which was delicious the famous one was in Taksim square, from taksim square u can go to Istikbal street(hope spell it right),there are so many shops, tattoo shops are available too and at the end of the street u reach to the sea,there is an island which you can go with your tour and have fun there,so many shopping centers in the city which i can't recall the names,but one of them was bigger than the others and i bought so many things from there,you can try Ayran ( turkish non alcoholic drink which made from yogurt),i must warn you the hotels in Istanbul are not anything like hotels in the southern areas of turkey ,when they say it's 4,it's 3 stars,if you wanna have fun and relax , go to beach i recommend Antalya , Bodrum , Kusadasi or Marmaris ,Istanbul is pretty much for shopping or museum or cultural monument ,(in kusadasi or bodrum there are also cultural monument too ),hope i could help u.i'm gonna put some photos soongood luck all

We where in Sultanahmet and got into a taxi to the Spice Market. It was very busy and the driver wanted us to hurry and get out of the taxi. He was offered by the front seat passenger and took a 50L note. Then proceed to rave how he had no change we had to give him the correct money. As there were three of us we managed to find the correct money in small change. He started moving the taxi and we scrambled out. He took off. We realised straight away that he had not given us the 50L note back. On trip back to hotel another driver tried the same thing. We made him give our change before we gave him the note we were paying with. Apparently this is a scam that some of the taxis are playing at so be aware. We talked it over with our hotel staff and next time got one of their taxis.PS we loved Turkey and can't wait to go back.

We have just returned from a girl's 5 day trip to Istanbul, We had a very comfortable stay at a budget Star Hotel near Taksim square. The rooms were clean and comfortable but perhaps a little small for double occupancy although we had all opted for singles. We would have liked tea and coffee making facilities in the rooms but there was a mini-bar instead.The staff were very helpful particularly Ali, the hotel manager who helped us organise trips to turkish bath and evening shows on a Bosphorus boat trip and the famous Galata Tower. Every morning they organised taxi's for our shopping trips and found us reputable drivers who charged a fair price. Unlike our return journey where drivers asked for triple or double the fare and twice dropped us in Taksim square and told us to walk the rest of the way because they couldn't find our hotel (even though we had it written dowm for them) or complained that heavy traffic wouldn't allow it! Overall we had a great time .We did everything we had planned to do and enjoyed it tremendously. We were sad to come home and look forward to returning someday soon.

column2: “A treat for the senses; great value city break”
column3: We had a whistle stop couple of days in Istanbul so packed in as much as we could, booking only recommended restaurants and cafes online to ensure the best seats in the house.Before arrival I would highly recommend you print a map of your hotel – Istanbul is vast with double the population of London and a maze of unmarked streets. The taxi drivers are all in training for the Turkish grand prix and the ride from the airport is usually pretty hair-raising!Once in the city, the tram service is frequent, efficient and dirt cheap at 1.50TL per token. It runs until midnight and stops are well placed.If you are an animal lover I’m afraid you will have your heart strings pulled in Istanbul – the streets are awash with stray Turkish Vans and dogs looking for a friend. This time I came prepared with a box of cat biscuits from which regular handfuls were dispatched, especially in the evening when the streets start to slow down. Should you need to restock (grocers do not sell cat food) head for the area of the Spice Bazaar behind the New Mosque. 7TL will buy you a kilo of cat biscuits, although they would probably prefer a kebab...Be prepared for enthusiastic salespeople who are keen for you to try their food or see their wares. They are friendly and even happy to provide directions to other restaurants – go with the flow and don’t be intimidated.There’s plenty to see in historic Sultanahmet but I would recommend avoiding the overcrowded expensive tourist spots in favour of some hidden gems. Sure, Aya Sofia is immense and beautiful, but there are plenty of beautiful working mosques that still have the mystique which ebbed out of Aya Sofia long ago and are happy with a donation. Topkapi palace is no Versailles, aside from the hoards of tourists, pricey entrance fees and long queues. Instead walk in the wonderful (and free) Otopark that surrounds the palace and take tea overlooking the Bosphorus. Another awe inspiring destination is the Basilica Cistern (10TL), an incredible ancient underground water tank which provides cool and calming respite from the hot streets of Sultanahmet above.The Grand Bazaar is enormous – don’t be overwhelmed. The shops are of a muchness and sell the same merchandise throughout. Pick what you like and start haggling! I found similar goods at better prices at the wonderfully fragrant Spice Bazaar (the rents are much lower than the Grand Bazaar). A must is Hazer Baba, home of the famous tea tins (apple, pomegranate, sour cherry, lemon...) and the juiciest Turkish Delight. Dig in and try plenty of squares before making your purchase (it’s a bit like pick-your-own).There are many hawkers on the banks of Golden Horn offering various cruises. Bypass them all and head for the Turyol terminal by the Galata bridge. A constant stream of ferries shuttle back and forth between the continents for a shoestring 1.50TL; climb up to the top deck for the best views of the Dolmabahce Palace and Sultanahmet.Food wise a meal on a terrace in Sultanahmet is a must. As a fish eating vegetarian I would recommend Dubb Indian restaurant in Sultanahmet for great view and tasty food, Namli delicatessen at the Spice Bazaar for a cracking takeaway meze (cross the street and carry it onto the boat to dine in style) and the Fes Cafe in the Grand Bazaar for hot cheesy tosts (toasties) which are best slavered in gloopy pomegranate syrup. Also recommended is Hafiz Mustafa at the Spice Bazaar for baklava so sweet it makes your teeth throb and Mado Ice Cream Palour next to Sultanahmet tram station for a better dessert selection than the restaurant you ate at (ever). Street food including freshly squeezed pomegranate juice and doughy simit sesame rings are excellent value too.To relax hunt out a secluded tea garden for a glass of Turkish or apple tea, a game of backgammon and a water pipe. For about 10TL you can spend a happy hour puffing away on fruit flvoured steam (I like apple or orange). As five non-smokers we all enoyed the experience so give it a go! I also recommend a Turkish bath – we went to Suleymaniye Hamam, one of few mixed Hamam, so great for couples and families. The staff are lovely and made us feel at ease.Istanbul is now one of my favourite cities and I can’t wait to go back to explore the other banks. Hotels, food, transport and shopping are incredibly good value. What a place!

Istanbul, TurkeyDate: 25/3/2010 for 7 days.Nice City, unique culture compaination.Best things:1.) I stayed in a FLAT & it was amazing. great location behind Istiklal street & very near to Taksim square.The company was very professional (www.flatsinistanbul.com)2.) Sweets & chocolates were amazing & cheap.3.) Bakery from "Simit Sarayi" is amazing & cheap. it a chain, this shop is everywhere.4.) Princes Island was very beautiful. (take a ship from “Kabats”, it is much cheaper).5.) Aya Sophia.6.) Sultan Ahmet Mosque (blue Mosque).7.) Sutlane Ahmet area. (nice but expensive shopping area)8.) Dolmebache Palace.9.) Topkapi Palace.Bad things:1.) Rude people (comparing to Egyptians).2.) Rare English spoken people even in the touristic places !!3.) EXPENCIVE SHOPPING (comparing to Egypt).Tips:1.) If you are 2 persons take a taxi (affordable) if more you can take a van, it is the most convenient (20 Euros for 4 persons).2.) Live near to Taksim Square (central station for metro & buses) or in Sultane Ahmed (Nice authentic Area).

Anyone wanting to eat first-class Turkish meze,baklava, turkish delight and snacks in charming, hygienic and atmospheric shops should visit Namli Pastirmaci for delicatessen food, and the shop 50 metres from here for pastries & turkish delight.From the Asian side of the Galata Bridge,at Karakoy,follow the waterfront towards the Seabus Pier for 300 metres & ask for Namli in Hasircilar Cadessi. You won't be disappointed, especially if you try a selection of the mezes lined up for you and eat them on the premises, or take the away in sealed/vacuumed containers to eat as a picnic...delicious eating and very good value.Not a tourist haven yet but it will be...friendly staff, tremendous food and a really pleasant shopping experience.

What if all you have done in your life is assume paris is romantic? What if you realise marketing plays a big role in false conception?This is my opinion on Istanbul, a city so beautiful and romantic, the busy streets of grand bazaar, istiklal kadesi's clubs and the wonderful waterfront of ortokoy.If only better known to the world and better marketed this is the place to go to.Regards,

I never thought that my this year first holiday destination i.e. Istanbul shall be so awesome. We landed in the midst of worst weather ever one could for hope for a holiday. However luckily the onward destination proved to be the most lovely experience. We flew to Cappadocia to visit the world's natural heritage site and found to be quite amazing. Istanbul was snowing in Jan. But the city charm and cosmopolitan culture does not let you go away. The Bhosphorus bridge hold you in a spellbound spectable of connecting two continents with asian and european landscape and cultural diversity at its best. One should try to visit this city in May to October to be able to enjoy the best. Being well connected to Europe...an onward journey can also be planned to be able to utilise and spend the moneys worth.

March 2010. Returned from Istanbul last night, had a fantastic 4 night stay, which we think was perfect for a first visit. We saw the 'big four' Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque and the Cistern, visited The Grand Bazaar and took a ferry across the Bosphorous to the East side. They are all, we think essential things to do, except maybe the ferry trip. We just wanted to get on the water and were interested in seeing what the East was like.Enjoyed the Palace and the Harem, very interesting, especially the Harem. Not too busy and although some of you might think this is terrible we were happy to just view the objects in the glass cases over people's shoulders - only stopping if there was something we were particularly interested in, as the queue moves at a snails pace with people not paying full attention, chatting etc. We were only there for about half a day doing things this way, although you could quite easily spend a day there, there is certainly enough to see. It was okay for us though because it wasn't too crowded and we certainly didn't rush things!The Blue Mosque is beautiful, especially we thought from the outside - be careful you can only visit at certain times of the day due to prayers. We noticed that several female visitors didn't cover their heads as requested and although we are not religious felt this was disrespectful!The Basilica Cistern is very atmospheric, quite expensive I suppose for what it is but like nowhere else we have ever been and it does cost so much for the upkeep of old buildings that weare happy to pay and to have seen it.The Hagia Sophia was our favourite. It took our breath away - although not at all ornate. You must go up to the galleries. It is a slope up there, not steps so much easier to climb. You will get an idea of the sheer scale of the place and see the colours of the ceiling.We were lucky enough to be within 10 minutes or so walking distance of all 4 main sights - do make the effort to see the Palace/ Hagia Sophia/Blue Mosque area at night - it is well lit, and the buildings are floodlit. You would have to be made of stone to not be bowled off your feet. They are all very close together (10/15 mins slow walk). Fantastic it will be etched on my mind forever.The Bazaar - what can I say? All you expect and more. The architecture of the place is spectacular and the atmosphere fabulous, even if you are not interested in shopping.We used the metro and tram to get from the airport to Sultanahmet where we were staying - so easy and very cheap, gives you an idea of the scale of the vast city. It is very easy to find your way around, we used the tram again to get to the public ferry in Eminonou to travel to the East side. There is lots of development over there - the place will we think be unrecognisable in a few year's time as the plans are quite amazing. At the moment it is quite scruffy with nothing really to see, but the ferry ride was great, and we enjoyed a walk along the edge of the water - we don't regret going as it was nice to have half a day away from the hustle and bustle and experience yet another side of Istanbul.Throughout our experience of Turkey is that the people are extremely warm and friendly and would do anything to help. Would visit again in a shot and cannot recommend it enough.

column2: “Istanbul Tips for what they are worth”
column3: If your accommodation is near a tram line, use them. Pre-booked taxis asked around 50 Euros from from Ataturk Airport to Beyazit and we were told it could take 90mins. So we gave the Light Railway and tram a go. It cost us each 3TL or just over one Euro (you need two tokens or Jetons each), and were there in 40 mins. With what we saved by not using the taxi to and from the airport we effectly paid for our first two nights accommodation. The system is really easy and there are automated machines at most stops for tokens. It is efficient and clean but can be crowded and apparently it is a favourite haunt of pick pockets. We stayed in the Niles Hotel (see reviews) which is off the main street so a little quieter, only having the one mosque on the corner. Opposite is the excellent Karadeniz Restaurant which serves excellent cheap food and will bring it to the hotel if you fancy a late night kebab and about 7TL.A Cruise up the Bosphorus - They can be expensive if booked as a tour. If you just want to go up the Bosphorus for short look there are boats such as the Turyol ferries that do a 3 hour non-stop round trip for 10TL which is a steal. They go every hour from just west of the Galata Bridge. Trams take you to the departure point. It seems quite normal for people to bring their own food for the trip and there's plenty on offer nearby.Turkish Delight - the best is supposed to come from a shop called Ali Muhidin Haci Bekir on Hamidiye in Eminonu. They've been making it there since 1777 and presumably by looking at it. I never thought sweet makers could look and act so miserable. Across the road on the corner is a coffee and sweet shop Hafiz Mustafa, where the cashier smiles and gives free samples of chocolates. Try the chocolate coated coffee beans, by the time we'd finished we had to pay on credit card. You can pay as much to sit down for a coffee or snack as you would back in the UK but generally you can spot some little cafe nearby where locals are drinking, it's half the price and usually a more rewarding experience because they always offer tips on where to go.Beyoglu district - if your idea of going to London is to go to Oxford Street then then this is the place. Personally we couldn't see the attraction. The area around Balik Pasari however is good for reasonably priced restaurants (because students go there) and great food shops. Spices, nuts and dried fruits. Good if you are tired of haggling. We ordered fish and the waiter shouted across the street whereupon a mackerel came flying over the road from the fish stall opposite. Turn off the main street by the big fruit and vegetable store (Dudu Odalari Sk ?) and walk down to No 1 where the owner has made pickling an art form. The shop at No 3 also serves very good baklava. He boasts that he doesn't use too much sugar and only the best butter. No margarine.The Spice Bazaar - a bit more managable than the Grand Bazaar but the prices no different. However there are great food shops outside on the west side and Hasirsilar Caddesi. The dried fruit and nuts from there are about the best bargain in Istanbul. Only went in the Grand Bazaar once, however that is not to say you cannot find quality shops and good deals. After that we used the shops which lie just to the south (river side) of the Blue Mosque. It's much calmer, the quality is good and you can haggle just as fiercely as the bazaar.Turkish Bath - used the Suleymaniye Hammam which dates from the 16th century. It is recommended by locals and gets good reviews from Trip Advisor users, unlike many of the others. We booked on-line so that we could arrive, dump our luggage and go straight there to recover from the flight and it worked a treat. We paid exactly the price advertised (75TL each) and no add-ons except drinks. You can stay as long as you want. After two hours you could pour us out.Carpets - We've bought a few in the past in other countries and learned a little so I offer these tips. 1. Learn what the five different types of turkish carpet are and you have you got them on the back foot straight away, also you are 30mins nearer walking out the door, (try the internet or Rough Guide to Istanbul). 2. No one ever made a penny from investing in a carpet. Maybe their great great grandchildren did but only if they bought wisely in the first place. 3. There are no such things as "unwanted dowry pieces" unless they bear a blood stain. 4. Unless antique means older than last week then it's probably not. They tried to sell us one that was 50 years old but when I examined the ends where it was cut from the frame they were perfectly square. 5. You cannot easily, if at all, alter a hand-made carpet. We met a couple who had turned down a carpet simply because it was too big. The seller had asked them to come back in an hour and he would get it cut to size. She also knew tip no. 5. and told him what she thought of his "hand-made" carpets. She bears the honour of being one of the very few to have been thrown out of a turkish carpet shop. Generally it's easier to escape from Alcatraz. She was still laughing the next day.Check out the prices of anything you might be considering buying back home. I found even after haggling carpets cost about the same as in a department store in the UK. But as a UK resident I found that if it's cheap then it's probably a cheap carpet, and that went for most things, shoes, clothes even turkish coffee. Now Marrakesh.Of course you may be in the luxurious position of still having an economy and a currency that is not chasing the Zimbabwe dollar unlike we British.We used the Rough Guide to Istanbul and found it largely reliable and particularly good on sightseeing. Otherwise just dive in.

I visited Istanbul for five days in October 2009 and i already want to return. Why? It's got great historical sites, lovely views, great food and nightlife, extremely friendly locals, and is a bargain on top of it. What's not to like?In addition to visiting all the usual places, like Ayasofya, Topkapi, the Blue Mosque, the Chora Church, etc., here are some other things you should do:-Visit a hamam (Turkish bath): I went to Cemberlitas, and got the scrubdown of my life!-Get a glass of fresh pomagranate juice or orange juice from a street vendor - they will squeeze it right there!-Buy a cob of fresh-roasted corn-Buy a fish sandwich from the fish sandwich boats in Eminonu-Have a drink or dinner on the Galata Bridge at night-Go to a cafe to smoke a water pipe-Get an inexpensive sandwich and drink at a doner kebap shop-Eat Turkish pizza and have a yogurt drink-Take the funicular to Taksim Square and walk down Istiklal Caddesi-Get a drink and go to a mehane in Beyoglu-And, finally, walk, walk walk! There are so many amazing things to see that you will get to by accident simply from wandering around the streets (which are usually unadorned with street signs, by the way - you'll need a great map and an excellent sense of direction). That's the best way to see the city.

Arrived on EasyJet and used Backpackers to transfer from the airport. Excellent service approx £10 each. Istanbul is a fantastic place but nobody warned us about the uneven pavements, steps, huge kerbs and the need for walking boots so be warned! The sites are fantastic. We stayed in Sultanahmet and loved the close proximity to the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia, the trams and a huge choice of places to eat. There is so much to do and the ferries were fabulous and cost about 75p each way! The views from the Galata Tower were brilliant and we were amazed at just how big the city is. The people were really friendly and overall we thought it was excellent value for money. I would really recommend Istanbul to young couples or families with teenage children. I wouldn't take anybody requiring wheels as the terrain is less than perfect.

After months of planning and anticipation we are finally in Istanbul! Spent 5 wonderful days seeing all of the amazing sites while saving the best for last, a tour of the Bosphorus!-Paid 35 Euro each for Bosporus Boat Tour package #4 (half day)-Bus was 20 minutes late, tiny and packed full.-The city walls portion of the tour was as we sped by on the highway with the tour guide blabbering on about the importance of US being on time.-The Spice Bazaar tour was 65 minutes of independent shopping and then the bus was late again.-the Golden Horn tour was as we drove over Galata Bridge while the tour guide kept talking about how it was a draw bridge, no history or anything remotely informative.-Dropped off at the tour boat ramp were we waited 15 minutes for 3 more She Tours buses to show up, then 5 more minutes for the boat to actually arrive.-immediately set sail North at full speed while the same tour guide continued talking about whatever he could make up into a barely audible speaker.-as soon as we broke the shadow of the second bridge we u-turned and made full speed back to the boat ramp.-never got within 5-8 miles of the world famous Istanbul skyline. The Hague Sophia was a tiny blur on the horizon.-Stood around in the cold again for 10 more minutes waiting for the tour bus-and then we were all taken to a leather shop on the edge of town which is NOT an advertised portion of the morning tour.-when we mentioned this admission to the tour guide and questioned this unexpected stop and delay, his immediate reply was that we could wait on the bus! They had no desire to assist, help, apologize, or even acknowledge the fact that we were displeased with our treatment. I'm not even going to start on how rude they then proceeded to get.-They did return us to our hotel, but it was more of an attempt for them to "hide" us from the other guests.-We called the company and spoke with the manager/owner, a Mr. Gurek, who talked in circles for several minutes, offering zero assistance, not even an excuse. We asked him why his brochures give misleading info, why we were offered no assistance, and even when we asked for at least an apology, the only thing he would say is "we are number 1, we are number 1…!"-and why is the feedback section of the website inaccessible…?Please do not waste your money.

Beware of food prices. Although we had been recommended the fish restaurants under the bridge, we were hounded by staff all the way along. After selecting one, we were not given a menu, but shown a display of fresh fish. Even the skeleton was presented on the plattter (to fill it up). The bill for 4, incl one bottle of the cheaper wine, no coffees was £140. Left feeling hungry.Two portions of samosas and one nan bread with 4 tea and coffee was £30 one lunchtime.The 'belly dancing' show with a set menu at the Galata Tower was 80 euro a head, when the hotel had quoted 80YTL. This included transport and unlimited alcohol. The mini bus arrived 30 mins early, leaving us insufficient time to get ready, 3 G&Ts tasted like raki, so were left unfinished, the meal was very poor and the entertainment mediochre. The 'unlimited alcohol' was one glass of red and one glass of white wine each, as it was being poured by staff, as opposed to leaving a bottle on the table. We were told to leave before 11pm as the transport was leaving, no coffees,the bill (320 euros - almost £300) was very poor value. When we went to collect our coats, they asked us for 20YTL and money for photos thay had taken!! We refused.

column2: “Beware of the "Houdini" Cab Drivers in Istanbul!”
column3: Two girlfriends and I spent 10 days in Istanbul in November 2009 and our visit generally was a lot of fun, adventure and discovery.We attended a conference and then took a week to explore and visit the city. The tours were fantastic and it was wonderful learning more about the wonderful and rich history of this amazing place.I don't know if it was because we were three women travelling alone in a male dominated society but I want to warn other visitors to be careful of the taxi drivers. We were ripped off twice - in the same manner.Our hotel was a few miles from downtown Istanbul, so we decided to take a proper yellow taxi back to our hotel. The driver dropped us off in the dark beside roadworks, pointing to our hotel that was just around the corner and up a slight hill. When we tried to insist he we wanted to be driven right to our hotel door, suddenly he couldn't speak English anymore! To pay the fare of 37-Turkish lire, I accidentally pulled out a British 50-pound note (the coloring of the bills is very similar and the taxi cab light was rather dim).But before I could examine the money properly, the taxi driver snatched it from my hand, switched it with his own money then pretended I had only given him a Turkish 5-lire note! Each of us ended up chipping in the balance of what the driver claimed we owed - so he ended up much richer than he deserved!We then had to walk along the dark road to our hotel, about 5 minutes away. The second time we had to take a taxi, we first determined that the driver could speak and understand English. Then we asked to be dropped off near a footbridge,next to a bus stop about five munutes from our hotel. The driver got into the wrong traffic lane on purpose, claimed he could not get over to the right side, then pulled over in a dark layby near to a shopping centre that was also close to our hotel. This time, we were on guard and we handed over a Turkish 50-lire note that we had put aside beforehand. But as quick as a wink, the driver swopped the Turkish 50- lire note for a Turkish 1-lire note and argued that we had only given him a 1-lire note! Then he revved his engine and barely let us get out of the vehicle before speeding off onto the highway.We are absolutely convinced that this is a well-worn trick of some Istanbul taxi drivers. You get in their taxi; they chat away in English; they find a way to drop you off in the dark; they switch your money to rip you off and they suddenly they forget how to speak English! I should point out that we did not have any problems with the taxi from the airport to our hotel and when used the hotel shuttle when we had to go back to the airport.Our experience with these "Houdini" taxi drivers was the only really negative experiences in our trip. We resorted to using buses for the duration of our visit. It was much cheaper and more interesting to travel the way the locals do.We'd love to visit Istanbul again someday as there is so much to see there but we have already decided that if we have to take a taxi, we will hold on to our money with both hands to prevent the driver from snatching it and we will loudly tell him how much we have in our hand and how much change we expect before we let it go!

I travel a lot, so I'm not easily amazed, but Istanbul is a wonderful city with many beautiful places to sight see and offers as well great cultural venues and party time. I would really call it bridge in between civilizations.I met there by chance the following local person that offered me to be a guide and I would greatly recommend him if you are planning to get there:[--]

A Friday to Monday jaunt:First experience of T5 at Heathrow, very good, particularly on the return when we were in the car in the Long Stay car park 35 mins after the rubber hit the tarmac.BA flight - actually a bit of a pleaseure after several trips on low cost airlines, edible food although a scrappy old plane.Transfer to airport with Backpackers - professional and helpful.Four Seasons hotel Sultanhamet - a great hotel, but expensive. It's right in the middle of the action, great service, wonderful room and facilities. Apple tea in an urn by the front door!Key sights - Blue Mosque, a must see but only a short trip - 10 minutes inside does it, but worth seeing.Hagia Sofia - a humbling experience. Visitors thought they were in heaven when they came here in the dark ages and you can see why. The conception and execution are totally awe-inspiring and I could have sat inside for an hour just looking around (if Mrs Smith hadn't wanted to go to the Bazaar).Topkapi Palace - what an interesting place. Slightly chaotic in terms of a visit but we found the audio guide useful. Main palace is worth seeing and take the extra time (and money) to go into the Harem (living quarters for Sultan as well as his wives. Allow 3 hours for the whole thing.Restaurants - Hamdi - near the Bosphorous, very busy local restaurant - kebab speciality, good buzz, quality food, around £35 each incl half a bottle of wine (each).Kerakol - in the grounds of Topkapi, nice food but very quiet. Only 4 months old and still searching for clientelle (although it was in January).Grand Bazaar - allow 2 hours at least, longer if you actually want to but something! Try and get a map showing streets and areas for different shops before you start. Great experience.Spice Bazaar - mounds of spice and dried fruit, smells and colours to die for. Less than an hour needed though.Overall - great fun, but really cold (mid January) and we'll definitely go back in May or September to sample the Bosphorous-side restaurants and cruises.Mike Smith

column2: “Istanbul Turkey on Thanksgiving: One of my top five trips of all time”
column3: I found this e-mail I had sent family and friends after my trip to Istanbul:Hello everyone,I wanted to just give a quick synopsis of my trip to keep everyone updated.Let me start off by saying, it was an absolutely AMAZING trip!!!!! I keep telling everyone that there are two words that really come to mind when thinking about all of it - complex and overwhelming. And I don't mean this in a negative way. It is really hard to put the entire experience into words but I'll give you all some brief stories (or at least I try to).There were two parts to our trip. Both were on the European side, however on different sides of the river. This made the trip seem as if we went on two different trips. The first half was the Old World/tourist area. We were woken up every morning at 6am by the call to praise Allah from the billions of mosques surrounding us. The first day it was kind of cool, but it wore really thin real quick as we kept trying to adjust to the jet lag. The first day walking around I think Nora and I said two words to each other the whole time. There was so much to soak in that it made us speechless. The streets were really narrow, the entire area is hilly/mountainous and the drivers make cab drivers here in the US look like Driving Ed teachers. Because all the scenery and pictures are so nice I was really surprised at the tremendous amount of smog. After blowing your nose you'd find the tissue would turn black! It was even a little difficult to breathe the first day. There was a lot of congestion with the people, buildings, cars - everything was in excess. . . but still, it kept its charm. Moving on to the more positive, we did the Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, a cistern from the 6th century (that was really amazing), covered bazaar where we haggled for leather jackets (that was really fun, and exhausting) lots of eating of course, and just walking around. Forget having a map! Most of the streets did not even have signs, or any form of organization. We found ourselves just walking into cute little plazas and neighborhoods by surprise. It truly was an adventure. Because Nora's beautiful blonde hair and blue eyes stood out so much, we met people every five seconds. Almost every man asked us if we remembered them, asking what part of heaven we came from, along with a ton of other great lines we could only laugh at as they chased us down the street with their broken English. "Yes, please" seemed to begin every sentence.Our nice little boat trip up the Bosphorus that ended in the Black Sea was great! We got lost in a little fishing village only to find we had gotten off the wrong port where even fewer people spoke English. When we found our way back on track we ended up at the top of a mountain where the Genoa castle stood. The scenery was beautiful.The second half of the trip began on the opposite side of the river where the more modern part of the city was. This felt almost exactly like Europe. We stayed at the hotel across from where the Pope was staying, but never saw him. At this point, Nora began her work and meetings so I was pretty much on my own until the evenings. With the change in scenery and having only my dark features, the trip changed almost entirely. EVERYONE thought I was Turkish. This actually provided some great experiences for me. As I made my way to the Princess Islands, where the exiled people of the Ottoman empire were sent, I found myself completely unable to communicate with anyone other than all the stray cats and dogs that followed me around. I was pretty isolated.I found myself walking miles and MILES everyday, up and down the hills and mountains. I got to see a great antique district, where their antiques consist of Ottoman furniture, and one of the cutest little jewelry shops I have ever seen. A lovely Muslim woman who made every necklace in the shop invited me to sit with her, her sister and her grandfather to have lunch after I bought a couple of necklaces. She had turquoise, jade, onyx and every other stone you could imagine hanging from all the walls. The pieces were so beautiful but I couldn't imagine some of the extravagant pieces actually being worn any longer than an hour because of their weight.In the evenings, Nora and I had a great time! We went to several traditional and modern bars (one of which had an English cover band). I even went on a Turkish date, which entailed the movie “The Departed,” dinner at McDonalds and drinks at a bar.The highlight of it all, as some of you might guess, was the Turkish bath itself. I've gone to quite a few spas in my day, and though the massage itself wasn't the best massage I've ever had, the entire experience really made me feel as if I were a princess. They take such care of every inch of your body as they exfoliate, wash and massage. I felt like a little girl in a gigantic bubble bath.Well, I hope this wasn't too long of a story, but more details will come with our conversations. I hope everyone had a great Thanksgiving and I'll talk to you all soon!

column2: “Great city, east and west at once!”
column3: Istanbul is a truly bridge between east and west! It s a modern city but still carrying its history and culture in the new era... Breath taking!My husband and I spent about a week in this beautiful city and wish to come back one day, because there is still a lot to see and discover..What we loved the most was just to walk in the street and hearing the prayers from the mosques during the day.The city never sleeps and the people are friendly and have a lot to share.The food is lovely and you can always find food wherever you are!We suggest not to spent all your time in Sultanahmet, that is the most turistic aerea because of the Aya Sofya, the sultan palace and the Grand Bazaar. We tried to see other parts of the city and were very happy, especially because due to the concentration of the turists, Sultanahmet has become very expensive, especially the food. If you f.ex. go to some besides streets in Taksim (the shopping area full of young people), you can easily find better restauarants with reasonable prices where locals are eating, too!Tips: Always ask for the price before buying or ordering food, unless the prices are already shown!And before buying something we suggest to have look around and compare the prices, if you have the time to do that!

We traveled to Istanbul from 27th to 31st December with our 2 boys 12 and 15, here are some of the things we experienced:Weather was cool, nice for walking although it did pour wit hrain one day.Stayed at the Sikeci Konach in Seraglio point district.Tip: Make sure you find out which days museums. mosques and palaces are shut.Day 0: Arrived in the evening and ate at arestaurant called Imbat on a local rooftop. Very nice food, mederately expensive. Worth a visit.Day 1: Topkapi Palace. 20TL per adult, free for children 12 and under.Palace is very large with a huge anount to see. We worked around it in a clockwise direction. No real queues although fairly busy. Harem is an extra 15TL per adult, free for child. Worth a see.Next walked to Grand Bazaar, stopping for coffee on the way. Takes about 30 minutes to walk from the Palace, although quite hilly.Grand Bazaar is absolutely huge and very easy to get lost in. There are many different things to view and buy with the obligitory haggling which is fun. During our visit it poured with rain but as this is totally inside it was ok, other than the electricity failed and so most of the vendors brought out candles which actually made it seem a lot like it would have originally.Next walked down steep hill in the rain to the Spice Bazaar, about 20 minutes away. You can smell the spices from afar.This place was absolutely packed, mainly from people sheltering from the rain. We about a lot of turkish confectionary which is delicious.Finally back to hotel in rain - very wet.Tried a Turkish bath in the hotel - absolutely great.That evening went to Seasons restaurant in the 4 Seasons hotel. Lovely food, but very expensive and no atmosphere.Day 2: Woken up early by call to prayers that are piped regularly across city.First to Archaeological Museum close by. This place is a must see if you like that kind of thing. They have an awesome collection that could take a long while to look through, though not with 2 teenage (almost) boys.Next a short walk to the Blue Mosque in the sun (no more rain). Met by a huge queue and nearly put off, however moved very quickly and were in in about 20 minutes. Remeber to dress appropriately for Mosques, scarfes for ladies and shoulders covered. No shorts. Shoes off. Inside the Mosque is one big huge room with fantrastic domed ceilings. Doesnt take long to see though.Next a quick walk around the hippodrome next to the Mosque, then a cab across the Golden Horn to Taksim square.Tip: Cabs are VERY cheap, well worth usingWalked from Taksim through shopping district to Galata Tower. Fairly short queue to go up in lift. Views from top are stunning.Walk back across Galata bridge where literally 100's of fisherman stand all day catching what look like sardines.Back to hotel with quick drink on the way.That evening ate at very swanky restaurant Mikla on 18th floor of hotel. Very expensive, but very good. Tried some Turkish wine which was almost acceptable :)Day 3: Walked down to Bosphorous ferry to take the all day ferry trip up the Bosphorous. This is the trip that all the guides suggest, however we were dissapointed and would have gone on a smaller boat i we had known what it was like.......We arrived about 10am for the 10.35am trip. This is too late if you want to get a seat on top. In fact you probably need to get there an hour before, and even then it wont be worth it because so many people crowd onto the boat that all you can see are peoples backs unless you are one of the luck few. We ended up standing for the 1 1/2 hour trip and it felt like being on a crammed London tube. Not nice.At the end of the line, 6 stops later everyone piles off and climbs a hill to an old castle which has great views down the Bosphorous and out to the Black Sea. Then you have lunch in one of the local restaurants and back on the ferry. The trip back is much better s many people have left by then, although at this time of year its pretty cold. At least we got to see the sights on the way back.That evening we ate Rami. Nice atmosphere overlooking Blue Mosque, with traditional Turkish food. Wine was awful.Trip was pretty good all in all and would recommend Instanbul for a short trip.

column2: “Istanbul: West and East meet in beauty and peace”
column3: After 35 years of wanting to visit...I was able to take in a 5 day whirlwind that mixed some organized tours with lots of self-tour...hiking and enjoying the hospitality and splendor of what was and is the most special of cross-roads.Stay in Sultanamet (I was at the Deniz Konek) and take in the views, the history and the subtlties of food and drink.
I visited Turkey Recently and stayed in Istanbul for 5 days.. The site seeing is great...Alot of walking...Very safe for Travellers.. The Grand Bazaar is a Must visit..

Sixty Two years old and finally made it to the Magical Istanbul. What an amazing place, we stayed at the Hotel Historia, in the historic part of Istanbul, and daily walked everythere, talked to everyone and ears of corn in the street. Everything about this place is unbelievable, just wished I had experienced it when I was in my 20's. So I say to every senior person out there, pack your bags and experience Istanbul, immerse yourself in the history, experience an authentic Turkish Bath and marvel at the beauty of the Bosporous.

We arrived at Istanbul's Sabia Gocken airport at 2.30am and our shuttle bus (www.sabihagokcenairportshuttle.com) which we had booked failed to turn up so I would not recommend them. We were told by a nice English speaking taxi supervisor that sometimes they just don't turn up if there are only two people to collect. There were two public buses, one that could have taken us out to Taksim (and we could have to catch a taxi from there to Sultanahmet) didn't start until 5.00am and the "Havas" bus which went down to the water for us to catch a ferry over to the other side didn't start until 6.00am. My advice is to not travel on a flight that gets in to Istanbul airport at 2.30am. We wasted 4.5hours at the airport which was not fun. The ferry ride from the port of Harem to Eminonu only took about 20 minutes but does first stop off at Karakoy. Check before getting off. Prices at the Grand Bazaar were outrageous. Go for a look but don't buy. The shop keepers were very aggressive and really hound you. We found a fantastic little jewelry shop in the main street of Sultanahmet (Silverado, Divanyolu Cad No; 34/A) the man was lovely and only charged me 25 TL for a bracelet that they wanted 120TL at the grand bazaar. For those wanting to see a whirling Dervish without paying for a 'show" can see one at the Cafe Merale in the Arasta Bazaar behind the blue mosque. Everynight at 8.00. A gorgeous place though and can't wait to go back.

column2: “In the shadow of the Blue Mosque”
column3: Reaching the Sultan Ahmet Sarayi Hotel from the airport was an easy ride along 1600 year old city walls and was situated in the shadow of the famous Blue Mosque in city center. Safely walking to the bazarre, the mosque, and local restaurants was easy and convienent. Without the need for taxi or bus, the city is a wonderful combination of old and new, religious and secular and inviting on a cool October night without the crowds of summer vacationers.Highllights would be the standard Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and a Bosporus cruise to see where east meets west but just as enjoyable would be the evening walk into the bazarre or to restaurant row where you are called in by an eager matre'd. The usual service charge of 10% (not a tip) could easily be bargained out of the bill as well as a complimentary glass of wine "for the lady".We stayed for 3 days, but could easily have spent another 3 days exploring more of the eastern side of the city. The old trolleys are still in operation and will bring you up steep hills into the more affluent shopping district.

Arriving at Ataturk airport the city starts off on a good note. The terminal is modern, clean & I found it easy to get through. It's huge & has all the services one would need. We had prearranged transfers to & from NCL's JADE through [--] & were happy to see our name displayed by our driver as we exited the secure side of the terminal. A tour all the way to the ship by a well spoken driver. He gave us the highlights of Istanbul while manipulating his way through the traffic. (I love driving but this is not the place for a North American to have a go at it.) 15+ Million people & half them seem to be out there in the traffic. Beautiful roads, well marked & no one is paying any attention to the rules of the road, nor to the lane markings. No place for an amateur. The city's well know landmarks/tourist attractions are as advertised; or better. You can glimps them in 4 full days or spend a lifetime & not see the whole. People make a city & Istanbul is well made! I must say that I was a little disappointed that the carpet salesmen, & sales people generally, were not as persistent as I was led to believe. "No" or just walking on was enough. Stop; look at something; ask the price; offer much less; and then, yes, you'll see the salesman at work. What would you expect from someone trying to make a living? It's their job & they do hate to lose a sale. Everything is here in huge numbers. It seems there are hundreds of each type of store, (I don't think there can be anyplace with more wedding stores, jewelry stores, etc...nor more restaurants.) Istanbul harbour must rank among the world's busiest. Also, I like all the settees/lounges in the open air cafes/bars/restaurants/clubs. The public transit system is great, very busy, but a pleasure to use. Lots of trams/ streetcars/buses & always another one coming. Buy your transit tokens a few at a time so you don't have to line up every time you want to ride. Turkey is a great country to visit with many foreign (to our western culture) attractions you won't find in a safer setting. We're going to go back and spend some time.

No matter the age, no matter the occupation, the people of Istanbul are charming. From taxi drivers to street vendors, firemen to fishermen, the locals are a sometimes underrated attraction in this eternal city .Of course I could do what every other review writer does and wax lyrical about the culture, the history, the food . . . the food is wonderful!, the sunsets and sunrises over the busy Bosphorus, but that would be running verbally over already well trodden ground.What I love about visiting a new place is meeting the people. In Istanbul there are plenty of people to meet (estimates quoted on the ground ranged from 12 million to 20 million!). And, without exception, the people of istanbul are interested, vibrant, happy, proud and delightful. The male half of the population especially so!Put some effort in and speak their language and you will be rewarded with not only help and information, but friendship and a laugh or two as well.Take the time to wander away from the tourist areas down the back streets and take the time to stop and chat. This is where the memories you will treasure for years to come are waiting.Istanbul is a must for anyone who is human!

Stradeling Europe and Asia over the Bosphorus straight, this town of 15 million has so much to see, learn, and experience, you could spend a lifetime, and still not absorb it all. The former third century christian city of Constantinople and capitol of the Eastern Roman empire, is today the both modern and ancient city of Istanbul in Asia Minor. Steeped in history, but as modern and bustleing as any major city on the planet. Profoundly first world, geared toward an educated populace,Istanbul is a very comfortable city to walk around in, and the accommodations and food availabilites are endless and cover a broad realm of possibilities. Do you want to go on the cheap? There are a seemingly endless supply of hostels. Do you want to go 5 star? That's covered too. The restaurant experiences go from food vendors, to a street in Old Istanbul (Sultanahmet area), nicknamed "backpackers alley", to the elegant and exotic chandler laden palaces where your wish is their desire. If you like kabobs or honey covered candies, Istanbul is the place.On a trip through Western Turkey with my daughter, we started in Istanbul and stayed at the Otel Obelisk (which is actually owned by Best Western to my surprise), centrally located in Old Istanbul (Sultanahmet) and a block away from the Blue Mosque. We found this to be a perfect locale for jumping off and seeing the sights and sounds of Istanbul. Sultanahmet we found from our research, has the majority of the popular sites for travelers, and all within walking distance, but public trams are also available. Easily walkable from our hotel was the Blue Mosque as mentioned, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, the Hippodrome, the New Mosque, Yerebaten Cistern (where From Russia with Love was shot in the 60's), the Spice Market, the Grand Bazaar, and many, many more places that inflame your passion for travel. The Grand Bazaar, which has been around for centuries and was guarded in it's day by the Sultan's guards due to it's importance as a trade center for Turkey, could absorb you for a day of wheeling and dealing before you know it.We found the Golden Horn and the Galata Bridge also an easy hike, which made it easy to reach new Istanbul (Beyoglu), the ferries to cross the Bosphorus, and the Galata district with the Galata Tower at the top of the hill. In new Istanbul we made the trek up the Istikial Cad (talk about an excess of shopping venues, geeesssh), with it's art deco style architecture and hordes of Turks and tourists to Taskim Square. Taskim Square is the central transportation hub for Istanbul on the European side of the Bosphorus, and if you need to transfer from the light rail or a local bus, you'll probably end up there. At the center of Taskim Square is a statue of Ataturk (translated as father of the Turks), and if you spend any time wondering around Turkey at all, you realize how popular he really was, cause his statues or image is everywhere throughout the country.What made it such a memorable destination though was the grace and hospitality of it's people. Charming is the word that comes to mind. They couldn't seem to do enough for you, and the service at food carts, restaurants, or coffee stands was impeccable virtually everywhere we wondered. Don't get me wrong, we still had to fend off the preponderance of rug dealers, but we somehow managed to come through the ordeal "rugless", and happier for it.The sights and sounds are just too numerous to mention, but the experience of Istanbul and it's people is one I won't soon forget. Do I have regrets about the trip? Only one, and that being I didn't have more time to spend in Istanbul.

Those who have not yet decided where and what you can see I advise to visit Istanbul! My trip to Istanbul was short but memorable. I went with my friends and brought a lot of only positive impressions.Special thanks to Turkey TPS - thanks to this company our vacation was successful for 100%. We managed to book a wonderful and cheap hotel through their website. In addition the company offered a free transfer from airport to hotel and back.Tria Hotel fully matches with its 4 stars. It's modern, comfortable and beautiful. Food is delicious, service is excellent. In general, we enjoyed everything, especially the view from the terrace on the roof of the hotel - it took our breath away!Many thanks to our guide Nelly. Arriving in Istanbul, we thought about where we can book excursions. And finally we made it through the company's guide. We've seen the whole city together with friends, visiting the Blue Mosque, the famous St. Sophia Cathedral and much more. Our guide Nelly advised to take a boat trip along Bosphorus - very beautiful, we were truly satisfied. The city itself is very beautiful. In general, do not hesitate - visit Istanbul. I am sure this kind of experience will stay with you for life! I can advise Turkey TPS to those, who decide to go. As for me, I didn't have any problems with them.

Istanbul is a city packed with the world's greatest monuments such as: The blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, the Galata Tower, Dolmabahce Palace, Hagia Sophia (to name a few), all which are so captivating upon arrival.I enjoyed meeting the friendliest people in the world whether it was when i was shopping/haggling, at my favorite hotel or dining.The unbelievable site of the grand bazaar (has 4000 shops) bustling with merchants and shoppers where you hear the flirtatious/comic common sayings of the merchants to lure shoppers to them which was shear comedy to me. A less overwhelming bazaar is the the Spice bazaar, less crowded and better bargaining opportunity (i found). Don't pass up on turkish delight, your taste buds would thank you.One of the pleasures of shopping was taking a break to sip on apple tea offered by the merchants (whether or not you bought from them) - that to me is a social relationship lacking anywhere else in the world.When after a long day of trekking and sightseeing, ending the day for the Hamam (turkish bath) is a must-do in istanbul and worth every cent spent.I enjoyed hearing the eerie wailing of call to prayer through the day, it gave me a sense of reverence.Took the Bosphorus cruise to see both sides of the european and asian side of Istanbul that is beautifully packed with history which cannot be captured on camera.Turkey is a must revisit for me.

column2: “Hidden treasure, a bit magical in fact!”
column3: Loved it, we absolutely loved it. I read a few reviews on this site before I left so me and my friend knew what to expect in terms of real life experiences.The weather was perfect, we stayed quite near the central attaractions so walked everywhere, we haggled and haggled and haggled so walked away with a few bargains too, and the Sofia was just amazing, I have never seen anything like it. For me it summed up the East meets West theme. It truly is a fusion of different cultures / religions and a good mix of types of travellers.As two girls we felt comfortable and safe except in the evenings when the carpet sellers really wanted that sale. But we were quite firm with them in our 'no's so that really wasn't a problem in the end. In fact I'd say we were pretty savvy! So a great place to go if you fancy something different from the run of the mill destination. Lots and lots to see and do ! One thing though I'd say watch the traffic, they drive pretty fast and make up their own lanes, reminded me of Italy.

Do you seek the unique and exotic? Then, Istanbul is the place for you. This old and complex city of 18 million people literally has a foot in two camps as it straddles the Bosphorous Strait between the Black Sea and the Sea of Marmara having a foot in Europe and one in Asia.With a rich and deep history as Byzantium, Constantinople and now Istanbul this city built among the hills has everything a tourist seeks; great history, wonderful sites, great food and fascinating shopping. I spent a week along with my fellow travelers on a Rick Steve's tour and found it an enchanting place where another week could easily have been spent exploring all its nooks and crannies.Being my first visit to a Muslim country and having left New York on September 11, I felt this trip was particularly poignant for me as I sought to learn and understand more of the Islamic culture.The Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia are a must see as is the Spice Market, the Grand Bazaar and Topkapi Palace. Staying in the "old town" - Sultanahmet puts you in easy access of everything. If you don't want to walk then use the public transportation system which is not difficult and inexpensive.No trip to Istanbul would be complete without a visit to a Turkish bath where all of your weary muscles will be kneeded into a relaxed state making you never want to leave.

i was there for 4 days.for me who comes from Isfahan city (Iran) which is full of historical sightseeing,there is nothing different,because i think Isfahan is more beautiful but in Asian mode.Istanbul is more like Europe .but something that i really love about Istanbul is that you can find everywhere bunches of tourists.so if you want people of the world come to Istanbul.be careful in restaurants;in each table ,different nation

Istanbul is a great city. Its a true meeting point of the east and the west. It has something to offer for every taste. History, culture, sightseeing, shopping, dining and nightlife. Its a complete package for a vacation.I have just returned after 9 days in Istanbul and I am truly exhilirated. It is a trip I will remember for a long time to come.My favorite part of Istanbul were the ferry rides accross the two sides of the Bosphorus and to the small nearby islands. But I also greatly enjoyed almost all other attractions at Istanbul.

In August 2009, I spent 5 days in Istanbul, Turkey. There is so much to see in the city and 5 days was barely enough to get to the basics.Our visit occurred during the first week of Ramadan, and at first we feared that food would not be available during daylight hours. It turned out that the only reason you knew it was Ramadan is because of the large gathering of people at a park between the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia.We visited the Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque, Spice Market, Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace, went to the town of Sile and a beach in Agra.Notes to other visitors:Topkapi Palace - I know many opt out of this due to an additional fee, but I highly recommend visiting the Harem, it is definitely worth it. You get a little more insight into the daily lives of the sultans of Turkey.

Istanbul is a very beautifual city. It is a large one withs historical sites wherever you go. Thransportaion is very easy and Turkish people are very kind. It is a really enjoyable touristic city.There, you are in Asia and Europe in the same time...

If you want to take your husband to a country he will enjoy and tell all his friends about, book a trip to Istanbul. By day, see all the opulent mosques, private harem quarters and The Grand Bazaar. By night, have a wonderful, always reasonably priced Dinner Show to see world-renouned Belly Dancers and Folk Dancers, often rated the best and most beautiful in all of Turkey.The beauty of the city is mind boggling, as it splits between Eastern and Western culture and philosophy, divided by the Bosphous River and Bridge. Marvel at architecture and lush gardens far different than our own in the States.It is an explosion of colorful spice markets, the beauty of the winding Bosphorus River, and the actual ornate tomb of Alexander the Great! From the roasting chestnut stands that permeate the city air, to the haukers with their unusually bright and beautiful wares,be prepared to feel as though you have landed on another planet; we did, and loved every minute. Oh, and buy your husband a Marshaum Pipe...believe me, he will cherish it!

I really enjoyed Istanbul much more than I thought I would. I had the usual concerns about travel to a principally Muslim country at a time with higher-than-normal tensions, but soon forgot them in the wonder of discovering this city.Istanbul is huge- about 16 million people, so don't expect a small-town experience. The turkish Lira is the official currency, but we found most taxi drivers and shop owners are willing (happy) to take Euros and Dollars. Most attractions are signed in english. Walking on the sidewalk in front of the Dolmabace palace, an elderly turkish gentleman gave me facts about the palace in broken english when he saw me looking at the architecture.While looking at the Blue Mosque, a man gave us some history and explained the current and past customs as we were looking through a guidebook. (True, he happened to have a store, but we didn't feel pressured to go.)Don't miss the Basilica Cistern- we never would have gone if not for a friend who recommended it, and are so glad we did.A trip on the Bosporus is a great way to see some of the amazing houses and palaces along the water.The Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar are great. Don't go to the Grand Bazaar if you are pressed for time- the Egyptian (Spice) Market has many of the same items, and is a smaller, more manageable size, but if you have time, the Grand Bazaar is a don't miss experience. The shops are all very similar, but the sheer number of them is overwhelming. Don't stick to the main halls, the small 'alleys' have a much more original feel. Also, don't worry too much about finding the same entrance- we didn't have any trouble finding a taxi at a lesser-known entrance. The Egyptian Market is an easy downhill walk from the Grand Bazaar, if you want to do both in one day. Do take a minute just to close your eyes and breathe deeply in the spice market- WOW!Last- visit a hamam- a turkish bath. It was a great experience, and my skin GLOWED when I was done!

Spent a day and a half in Istanbul as part of a eastern med cruise. We loved it, but we lived in Turkey for 2 years and didn't do the normal touristy things. Would highly recomment you do all you can in the time you have. The blue mosque, the covered bizaar, topkapi palace, Taksim Square, the fish and spice markets ets. Take a dinner cruise on the bosphorus and see the sights. Many outstanding museums and excellant shopping and dinning. You simply have to eat their and not necessarily in upscale touristy places. The cruise ships have some excellant excursions that will expose you to the country and its cultural in a way you'll never forget.

My husband and I spend two weeks in Istanbul and are still glowing from the experience. From the stunning beauty of the historical sites to the incredible hospitality of the people, we have never been to a place that impacted us as much as Istanbul. It was a marvelous combination of old world tradition and modern, contemporary culture. We would recommend that Istanbul is added to your list of "must see" places.

column2: “Rast Hotel - an outstanding hotel ideally located for the tourist”
column3: My wife and I spent two weeks at the Rast Hotel located almost ideally in the Sultanamet district, only a very short walk to Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, and Topkapi, and a short walk to the Grand Bazaar and Sulimaniye Mosque. The tram which can take you almost anywhere in Istanbul stops about 100 yards from the hotel. From the breakfast room you overlook the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi, the Bosporhous, and Sea of Marmara. The rooms are comfortable and, by Sultanamet standards, large. The staff is efficient, curteous, and very helpful. Mr Tarik Paksoy, the reservations manager, is a master problem solver. The breakfast is excellent and the view breathtaking.We have nothing to complain of. The only improvement would be a chest of drawers. All the hotels in the Sultanamet area have small rooms by international, business hotel standards as space is at a premium. But you get location, location, location at the Rast. You could get more space at the Kempinski or Swiss Hotel, but you would pay a lot more and be far away from everything you came to Istanbul to see. We would go back to the Rast in a minute. For the travel on vacation to experience Istanbul, the Rast is an ideal hotel.

If you are the adventurous traveller,this destination is a melting pot of cultures.modern or old it is all there.there are two main bridges that connect two continents and one of which is one of the biggest suspention bridges in the world.There is Aya sofia,the biggest cathedral ever built in its time for a 1000 yrs.over 1500 years ago it was built by the byzantinians and they made a point in the centre inside this magnificent structure believing it was the centre of the earh...you can apparently park 77 buses inside, if you so wished that is!?..I spent roughly 12 years in this wonderful city, most of my childhood and teens.it has its sad stories and history but it is a city which was and still is torn between eastern and western cultures.its real istanbulian people are cultured.It was the final destination for orient express,the train station haydarpasa was built by a german kaiser.it still is in my opinion one of the most beautiful stations in the world.you can still catch trains there to many locations.Too many to mention.And ofcourse the bosphorous where you can still fish if you like.My favourate was between cengelkoy and beylerbeyi.you can still find little stalls along the way where you can get any kind of rod and reel,lures and advice for any budget.I bought a telescopic casting rod at such a place...I still have it at my home in london..There are the princes islands, if it gets too much in the city.I would deffinately recommend you get a travel card.except it doesn't come in the shape of a card but a key ring(akpil).It entitles you as much as 40 percent off on all public transport including ferries,buses,trams,cablecars,trains.It does not include sea taxis.there are sea buses for fast travel but i leave that choice up to you.The ferries were built in England in the fifties and still chugging along.mostly well maintained.There are the whirling dirvishes.A religion described as in one word:tolerance..Originally from an ancient city konya Turkey,the whirling dervishes are a must see.A totally peaceful and captivating experience.There are as many as 100 hamams in istanbul so i can recommend many but it depends who you are with,traditionally women and bathed separetely but as it is a country of a secular kind,ask arround and find the one you want.I use to go to a hamam in bakirkoy with my father and my grandfather.It was a small hamam and not touristic.I like the one Keith Floyd went to but it's impossible to tell which one it was.the food is great whether its street food at sirkeci or restaurants in sariyer.just follow your nose and tastebuds.kapali carsi (the grand bazaar)is enchanting.Turkeys national dish is imam bayildi(translates as imam fainted).the story goes, it tasted so good the imam who first tasted this dish fainted.it is simply auborgine stuffed with vegatables cooked in olive oil.Turbot,rack of lamb,fried mussels are my favourate.There are many tasty variety of kebabs in the city .the best I had was in kuleli on the asian side near a military base.no alcohol was allowed,funny enough not for religious reasons but simply the council had banned it for the soldiers from the military base was getting drunk in the area.it has a roof terrace with marble tables with barbecues set in the middle of them.no need for patio heaters at night.you can cook it yourself or they will cook it for you in front of you.you pick the cut of meet,marinated or plain in a butchers style glass fridge unit downstairs when you come in..There are two airports,one on europian side Ataturk hava limani and one on asian side Sabiha gokcen havalimani.Places to say are widely available.sometimes you can haggle if you are on a budget but I managed a few times even with top hotels..its fun.taksim square is popular.You can go down istiklal caddesi and find buotique hotels,pansions etc.very interesting bookshops with cafes and bars built in,for the intelect.the old flower market is a must see with fish restaurants and live classical turkish musicians at your table.the food is hit and miss so be careful but you have to go there for the experience.From there you can walk to beyoglu and find interesting places.my grandfather back in the day had a workshop making game pieces like rummicub,dominos etc.it is the old quarter,it had its ups and downs but it is now clean..I am sure you can get deals anywhere but if you must stay in luxury, the marmara hotel is 5 stars ,it caters for all your needs,it has a covered rooftop restaurant bar with live music.when i was there it had a famous band off the tv.the views are magnificant,the service first class.ground floor has a pattisserie to die for and most istanbul high society are to be seen there .I saw a couple of balerinas who were pointed out to me:)but yet it was so informal.I was shown a few rooms which were exquisite.@$160 a night.The night life is everywhere you go, in walking distance whether its theatre,cabaret,comedy stand up,live music of many kinds,night clubs,intimate music venues etc.the receptionist will help you which is good but meet people, keep an open mind you will find many gems...ortakoy is a good spot for food,architecture,nightclubs,cobble streets,right on the waters edge looking over the many ships going back and forward to russia.Bebek,a suburb of istanbul is the chelsea of istanbul with its wonderful restaurants and cafes.One cafe i went to the name escapes me was sunk in to the bosphourus so there was a glass and table against it.you could litteraly see in that glass where ,half bosphourus,halfskyline and views.I sat there having coffee and cake whatching under the bosphourus at the bottom half and top half, skyline of asian side of istanbul.little further on, Emirgan.beatiful park, a gem with natural caves,mantions.watch out for pink mantion....There have been times when I traveled to istanbul exausted my finances and stayed in a,well?£3 a night pansion in kadikoy which was awful but as i say Istanbul can be forgiving ,if you are open minded.it's addictive....

Istanbul could be one of te best trips you visit or one of the worst.I have just got back and have to say I had a relly good time. I did a lot of research before i went which really helped.The grand bazaar is not the same of how it used to be, people are much more arrogent and don't smile much. They have a much more meaner look to them. Even when you try to be friendly they sometimes just ignore you.The sites are amazing and worth the trip in themself but i have to advice, if you live in istanbul, dont bother getting the exersions but rather just get a map and do it yourself (Top palace, Blue mosque). blue mosque is in istanbul (City centre) and Top palace is 5 - 10 min walk from Blue Mosque or 1 stop on the tram.

Whatever you do schedule at least four days in Istanbul. It is one of the best cities I have ever visited. As a recommendation, hire Lale Kosagan for a private tour. She is the best. Her websites are - tourguidesinturkey.com, privatetoursininstanbul.com,toursinistanbul.com. She gets over 95% of her business via recommendations of customers. She can get you to see the real Istanbul and with a private driver and vehicle she keeps you away from the crowds and still gets you there. Lale can get six days in four,

We had a fantastic time when we visited Istanbul recently. One word of advice would be to stay in accommodation away from the tourist areas and either walk or catch public transport to see the sights. That way you really get a feel for how the locals live and also you pay lower prices. If you are thinking of going - then do - you won't be disappointed!

We visited Istambul a few years back and found it to be a really great place to visit for a long weekend - or longer if you can. Sultanahmet is the best place to stay - being central and also very close to all the major sites - Blue Mosque and Aya Sophia etc. Stay if you can in one of the converted merchants houses in the area - Yesil Ev also does excellent food and the Rami has a lovely terace from which you can watch the sun go down and enjoy some wonderful food and wine (yes really Turkish wine isn't half bad) We found a meal to cost approx £15 per head and for that you can eat royally. The Grand bazaar can seem a little intimidating unless you are an expert shopper, in which case if you prefer something quiter, try the Spice Bazaar nearby (but don't look too closly at the back where they have some exotic pets - very sad!) Also I would recommend a trip on the Bosphorus, even if it only to the Asian side Uskudar and back and you really cannot miss the Topkapi Palace. However once you have waited to get in, don't forget to join another que to get a ticket for the Hareem on the left hand side. As with any Moslem country I would suggest the ladies do not go around in short shorts or strappy tops too often as this can lead to unwanted attention, and certainly of you wish to visit any Mosques then take a couple of light shawls to cover up. All in all I would heartily recommend Istanbul and can't wait to get back myself!

Had a great vacation in Turkey, final destination was Antalya how Istanbul was far more exciting this was possibly due to Antalya having the same sort of enviroment as my home country. Istanbul is a must for those who are looking for great food and shopping.The hotel rooms are small but well equipped. The Blue mosque and other landmarks are also great to visit.Shopping is good but one must be careful in the markets as pressure is put on tourists to purchase goods. The market is a full place to go to but the quality of goods especially hand bags and leather items are no where near those found in reputable shops. The jewellery shops have great designs. bargaining is expected in the market.Highly recommend Istanbul as a fun destination to visit

Istanbul is one the most beautiful cities I've ever seen.The tour was fascinating.Thanks everyone for this nice trip.I recommend everybody to see this wonderful city.I'd like to be there again. Alessandra

We were always put off from visiting Turkey, safety, etc. We were travelling two females, with a 13 yr old and had the most memorable holiday. We felt safer in Istanbul than in many other countries we visited. 11 glorious days. Spent a week in Antalya, gorgeous.
