Had my hamam bath there. privately done, clean and no ambarrasment or crowds of naked people. The hamam attendant was a male - (A handsome turkish delight, but I politely requested a female. ( oh oh do I regret )It was still a Fantastic experience.Tons of lovely places to see, the natural beauty stunning, water all around you. scenic. Wonderful ,kind people who go out of their way to help. We were treated like VIPs, in most places, something I dont experience back home.IstanbulSultanahmet- lovely place to stay, easy for sightseeing, nice admosphere, and you feel safe. We were out till after midnight every night.Taksim, - buzzing and the place if you like nightlife, clubs, etc. We stayed 3 nights in Taksim and 9 nights in Sultanahmet. In Taksim, I was always alert, as there are many shmucks and you are always on the lookout for pick pockets. So we very much prefered the more relaxed admosphere of being in Sultanahmet. In the end, we decided that our desicion to spend more time in Sultanahmet was a good one. By the way, just a short walk from the Sultanahmet tram stop, is a great restuarant called CENNET (They have two, go to the bigger one).. Lively, there are ladies making pancakes in the front of the restuarant and live singers every night at about 9.00pm. We ate there many times, and one night were lucky to catch a belly dancimg show. Fun and lively, and great food. Not expensive.Beware of the beggars. They are very annoying and work with the Mafia. Ascertain the situation. If you see an old man or woman sitting at the station, looking tired, by all means, open your heart and wallet. Be weary of the ladies sitting with babies, and young kids begging. They are the con artists. Instead of giving these kids money, my teen would buy them an ice cream to enjoy, as they were clearly tired and being exploited to beg.We bought more than we should in some places just to support, especially the people sitting on the pavements in Sultanahmet area, selling their wares.Food- great, we ate freely off the streets, Donors, Patso- a sandwich with hotdog and fries and salad, kumpur - lovely baked potato, the burgers in Taksim, yum.Turkish ice cream and buy Turkish delights. We still enjoying them at home now.As ladies travelling, we felt 100 per cent safe, except in Taksim. I found these on a site and used them alot in Taksim."Bırak beni!" "Leave me alone!""Dursana!" - "Stop it!""Lütfen beni takip etme?!" - "Can you please stop stalking meBe cautious and dont flash expensive stuff. I made a point to carry a smaller bag and dress down.But I said Cok Guzel (choke goozel) more (it means very beautiful). And thats what Turkey represents to us.Take comfy shoes, and its a fun destination, wrapped with culture and scenic landmarks. My teen didnt want to leave. She had an absolute blast and shopped to her hearts content.Antalya was magic, loved it, and we have decided to visit Turkey again and explore, theres so much beauty and we just cant wait.Have Fun

A few tips on istanbul after spending 8 nights in August. Firstly the weather was great-most advise is keep clear in August. Well most of the time it was a nice 27-28 degrees and for a few days 33 but with a strong breeze from the Bosphorous.Secondly be careful where you stay if you like sleep-noise can be a problem especially from competing mosques at 5 in the morning!car/taxi transport can be difficult due to traffic but tram is wonderful, clean and fast and cheap (all journeys 1.5 lira). Watch out for taxi metres that are switched to a trick rate-we paid 22 lira for a metred journey and 10 on the way back?If you can afford it, stay in the old city to see the big sites where you can walk to most things and then move onto a Bosphorous side hotel for pool and relaxing (Ciragen palace is wonderful)

Those of us who rely on budget airlines to get our travel fixes have become accustomed to getting dumped off in some forgotten backwater miles from the perimeter of our destination city. Few, however, would expect to be left in an entirely different continent from their resting place for the evening.But in hindsight this was perhaps the most fitting introduction to Istanbul, a sprawling city of contrasts which spans both Europe and Asia — in its geography as well as its psyche.The first of many surprises in this predominantly Muslim city is the Sabiha Gökçen Airport, named after of the world’s first woman combat pilot, who fought for the formation of the modern Turkish republic in 1923. From here it’s a 45 minute bus journey though Istanbul’s Antolian side to the ferry terminal at Kadikoy, then a 20 minute trip across the mouth of the Bosphorus (the sea channel which cuts the city in two) finally arriving at the historic centre at Eminonu port.Tired and weary from this arduous trek across land and sea, I wanted to save the big-draw tourist sights for the next day and find my hotel. But taking a moment to look up from my print-off map, I couldn’t help gawk at the majestic minarets of the Blue Mosque, peaking through the evening haze, encircled by wandering gulls. Completed in 1616, this building apparently raised a few eyebrows in the Islamic world as its beauty was seen to rival that of the Grand Mosque in Mecca. Not hard to see why.Just a short walk away from the mosque was my hotel, the Deniz Konak, in the heart of the Sultanahmet district of the city. Like many of the hotels in the area it seemed to be kitted out to look like the harem quarters of the nearby Topikai Palace. No matter, it was extremely comfortable and friendly as well as being perfectly situated for sightseeing.The Empire BuilderFew places, even Rome, can match Istanbul for such rich and varied history. Indeed it was Istanbul (then called Constantinople) that succeeded the eternal city as the capital of the new Byzantine Empire in 330 AD. It then ushered in the reign of an altogether different empire in 1299 - that of the Ottoman Turks.Nowhere is this history more evident than the Hagia Sofia. This remarkable domed building started life as a Christian church in 532, was converted to a mosque in the 15th century and now serves as a museum. The authorities currently have the contentious task of deciding whether to scrape away the Islamic calligraphy (beautiful and historical in its own right) to reveal the much older Byzantium Christian mosaics which were painted over.How not to haggleNo trip to Istanbul would be complete without a visit to the Grand Bazzar, the world’s largest indoor market, selling all manner of hookah pipes, baklava and fine rugs. After seeing the exquisite Ottoman miniature paintings in the Topikai Palace, I was desperate to find some of the replicas that I’d heard were produced in this labyrinth. However, nothing can prepare you for the experience of entering this place; miles upon miles of endless stalls which appear to tunnel deeper and deeper revealing yet more nooks and crannies along the way. It’s really quite disconcerting.Finally I found a shop that sold these elusive miniatures and immediately fell in love with one that depicted an Islamic astronomer peering through a telescope into the heavens above. I began to barter in earnest, but the canny stall keep had my number already. He assured me that the example I had picked out was not simply a copy but a 300 year old original from when Istanbul was a key centre for astronomy. When I balked at this (having seen the real ones in the palace through several inches of glass, watched over by a surly security guard) he simply replied that some had escaped the authorities when the palace was converted to a museum. I walked away around 40 euros poorer.The modern face of IstanbulChosen as the joint European capital of culture 2010, Istanbul has enough high-brow entertainment to keep the most sophisticated and discerning traveler happy. In April it hosts the Istanbul International Film Festival, considered one of the most important events in the cinematic calendar. Meanwhile, the collection of the Istanbul Modern Art Museum is growing impressively and frequently displays exhibitions of renowned Turkish and foreign contemporary artists. If it’s shopping you’re interested in the city boasts several world class malls including the Akmerkez, previously awarded the "Europe's Best" and "World's Best" awards by the International Council of Shopping Centers, and the Kanyon Mall (2006) which won the 2006 Cityscape Architectural Review.Istanbul is not a place you would expect to find bustling, characterful pubs, but this is exactly what awaits you in the 19th century Meyhanes or winehouses on İstiklal Avenue in the Beyoğlu district. But for more lively fare it may be worth heading to the Ortaköy district, where in the summer open air night clubs such as Reina and Anjelique pump out loud music along the banks of the Bosphorus.Confidently European and proudly Asian, officially secular yet overtly Islamic — Istanbul is clearly full of contradictions; but it’s this split personality which makes it one of the most enticing city breaks on offer.

column2: “Things to buy in Isanbul and Bursa”
column3: I am pretty particular about my purchases because I don't want my house to look like a hodgepodge of different trips.There is a smaller bazaar just a few yards down from the blue mosque. Here you can pick up what I consider a great steal--I purchases old kilim pillow covers for $7.00 each. They come in all sorts of colors and look old. They look chic on white muslin couches, if you have those. I also purchased a Kilim runner--again at a reasonable price. I might have gotten a better price on e-bay but I got to make a choice in person.I look for certain jewelry in the grand bazaar--that is BEZEL set stones that you do not find as much over here. BEZEL set stones are very chic and I picked up a lovely ruby/silver set ring. I only look for the BEZEL in gold or silver. I also bought the standard evil eye bracelets but I bought a bunch to group on one hand.In Bursa, I bought a number of Pashminas and I don't care if they are from China or not. I wear Pashminas a lot and do not want the super high quality expensive ones--however, I also don't want the cheapies either. At Bursa I was able to find just the weight and texture I wanted and the price was great --$10.00 each. The ones I order from e-bay are hit and miss on quality. I think the pashminas all over the major Turkey tourist sites can be fantastic deals. Just get an eye for feel and color. Like I said there is more of a selection and I don't care where they are from because you will not see this selection at home and I don't know when I'll get to china.At Goreme I hit upon what I consider a super buy. These are quartz elastic bracelets (more like a cuff). I got one in emerald and another in pale pink. These are also very chic and I already had the pashiminas--bought earlier to match.Many people on our trip bought rugs in the thousands of dollars. If you have the money to do that I would say go for it. It will be a real regret if you don't. I already have some nice rugs, but the choices there and the quality were fabulous.Ceramics are another matter and I really don't find any of the ceramics that "blendable," and they all seem to say "bought on my trip to turkey." Same for the lamps. I also think they are a bit ticky tacky.

You will find plenty of classic places to visit in Istanbul. You should visit them all as they are truly great sites. We went to a fairly new transport museum on the Golden Horn and though it sounds dull it is pretty good, and should keep children happy and a break from the continuous cultural and historical sites that wear down our kids.The trip up the Bosphorous is worth it for a cheap day out. The restaurants at the end will sting you though...the food is good but expensive.For a fantastic view of the city go to the 17th floor of the Marama Pera hotel in Taksim. It is breathtaking. A night time stroll in the Taksim area is also amazing with what seems to be the whole of Istanbul being on the streets. Eating around this area is also excellent..though a little too lively. If you have young children I would not bother eating in these areas as they are so busy.

My husband, daughter and myself went to Turkey in September 2007. We flew into Istanbul as a kick-off to our big OE and were immediately blown away by the friendliness and warmth of the people we came into contact with, from our bus driver to the concierge and counter staff at out hotel, the World Park Hotel. My husband was unlucky enough to suffer with a bad back on the plane and by the time we reached Istanbul from Auckland NZ was in absolute agony. The hotel staff arranged for us to go to the local emergency hospital, and when we arrived back at the hotel, we found that my 17 year old daughter wasn't well on top of this so the concierge sent the bellboy off to the nearest emergency chemist (at 10.00pm) to get some medecine to calm her tummy down.On top of the friendliness of the people, the sights, the history, the markets and in fact everything in Istanbul is just wonderful. It was a truly magical and special part of our trip. If you get a chance to go there, definitel take it!

Istanbul is a city for the ages. Stay downtown near the Sultanamhet old quarter if you can. The US dollar goes far usually 1:8 turkish lira so you get a lot.We stayed at Mavi Onur guesthouse really just for backpackers. Big room but like muck of Europe, bathrooms are funky!!!Next door though was the Rose Motel, just a short walk from the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia etc. Nice rooms, decent baths that were clean and only about 50$ US a nite for two people. Had nice lounge bar downstairs and great upper deck on sixth floor where you could see all across the Bosperus and into the old town.Food was very inexpensive and very good. Typically we paid less than 10$ US for two if we were picky. Even expensive places with rooftop decks and great service were only say 5-7$ US for a drink and oh the views....Do avoid the tourist bars that seem a bit higher and not worth it. Most Turkish people are quite nice and speak some English also French and German common too.The food is to die for in Istanbul. Great seafood, wonderful traditional Turkish cuisine and very similiar in taste and flavor to Mideast and Mediterranean. We could always count on kebabs, doner kebab (sandwiches), Turkish burgers (really very good!), lamb, hummus, some couscous, great yogurt, try the Aryan yogurt drink if you like buttermilk, lots of simple sugar and honey deserts (but dont call it baklava, thats greek!), and always a simple italian pasta and tomato meal to be had. Interesting korena and asian food occassionally as well. Very good flat bread something between nan from India and pita from Greece. Usually cheese, fruit, bread and strong turkish coffee for breakfast. Watch out for Nescafe, its everywhere in the Aegean be sure to get the local strong stuff if you like that. Turkish tea was fabulous, especially the light fruity stuff in the afternoons for quick pick me up.MUST SEE-give yourself a full day or hopefully several days to see the old Golden Horn area. We took the tram around (very cheap maybe a 1.25 US$ for complete ride). Also took a tour bus (yes the big red city tours-expensive about 30$ US but worth it with 4 hours of on off points) to see the main outer walls, that was great. About 12 miles of them across the old peninsula. Take a ferry boat (mostly tourists) out along the waters its cheap (7-10$ US) and the views are amazing for a 1 hour ride. Any good tourist city map from the main plaza near the mosques will get you all you need to know, where to pick up etc. It is a very navigable town. The markets are ok but go to the little side markets not the main markets, they are mostly tourist traps with no bargaining.We bought lots of dyed cloth, bedding, spices etc. and maybe spent 70-80 $ US but came back with gifts for about 20 people! Nice gifts too, not junk. Oh yes, there is a little store front with a big interior right beside the Blue Mosque and across from the German Fountain on the old circus maximus area. Once inside it opens up to large store area with everything a frugal tourist could ever desire. I came back with Wall posters, pictures, lithograph paintings, kid gifts, turkish coffee makers, etc. etc. etc. and wow the most expensive thing was my 30in by 40in pictures and posters at 5$ US each!!! NEVER have I ever been happier shopping.Call to prayer 5 times a day of course but you can continue on with your business they will accomodate you. Great high end antiques as well if you have the money. Of course carpets galore for very reasonable if you bargain, and lots of knock off ladies accessories or guys stuff from shoes and watches to purses and such, for very cheap. Got T-shirt for 3-10$, bought hats for the Fez hats (actually a north African origin but Attaturk made it official for Turkey Republic back in 20s) for .50cents US. Watch out for old switcharoo, US dollars to Turkish Lira to Euros, to British pounds. You will lose that game everytime to these experts, insist on what price is in and what you will pay in, never take change back in another currency than what you paid. Most street sellers or big tourist bazaars use this like at the Grand Bazaar. I would avoid it though just a walk through is good for the experience.Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Underground Cistern, circus maximus area, streets and shops of Sultanamet, Golden Horn, Bosperus, Topkapi palace, archaeology museum, Walls of Constantinople, restaurants on sea, rooftops or in walls, the palaces across the Bosperus, a ferry ride, all of this is right there and most of it is 2,000 years old and older. You have to go if you love history and archaeology, great food, an exotic yet very safe destination, and one where the US dollar and Euro are very strong. The Turkish people are a delight 75 million strong, 15 million in Istanbul, meeting place of Europe and Asia, great food, good beer and wine (cappadocia especially).Its about 20 minutes to airport you can get any hotel shuttle for about 10$ US. Well run airport. Plenty of nice yet cheap hotels and eats if you go to the coastal edge of Sultanamhet, you can walk to everything in just a few minutes or go jogging along the coast. Just walk around and check em out, no need to reserve when we went and that was June. It does get a bit wet and cool in winter, some snow dusting not much.I would avoid the larger and more expensive hotels downtown in Sultanamhet, they are just not worth it and can be a bit snooty. We stayed at several but could not recommend them for what you get.Take your spouse its romantic and fantastic...If you get a chance, tour all around Turkey it has amazing stuff the shipwreck museum in Boduiem, Izmir, Antalya, Konya, of course Cappadocia, Lake Van, old Hittite ruins near Bogazkoy and capital, Catal Huyuk one of the oldest sites in the world. Its amazing how well these folks take care of other peoples heritage, Turkish hospitality might be just as advertised. Bring gifts, like Calendars with pics from where you live, you will have lots of chances to converse with locals, even pick up a bit of Turkish!But do not miss Istanbul, you only need a few days...I like it as much as Rome, Athens, Beijing, Singapore, Hong Kong, Mombai, Dehli, Mexico City, Lima, Rio, you name it. Now is the time with the dollar so strong. IF turkey gets in EU then that opportunity is gone. Thats what happened in Ireland, Portugal, Greece, etc. Their bid to get in is still some years out and its only 50/50 at best since many Europeans worry about a "Muslim" country. But not this one, better than Egypt and Morocco if you ask me.SlainteCiao,Safe Travels

In Ataturk airport your will be approached by numerous persons seeking to sell you transport by bus to downtown. Beware! The cost is very likely to be higher than taxi fare. My wife and I chose to take a bus run by the "Murat" company, which has a counter in the airport. The convinced us to book (and pay for) a return trip as well. You may decide to accept one of these buses to get from the airport, but based on our experience, do not book a round trip. In our case, the return pick-up never came. Repeated calls to the Murat office got promises that the driver was stuck in traffic and would be there "in less than ten minutes." When getting our airplane became in doubt we took a taxi. We saw no traffic jams on the road to the airport that would explain the delay of the Murat driver. When we got to the airport, Murat paid the taxi (less than we had paid Murat). That should give you some idea of the excess price we paid.The Metro is the best way to go, but beware that if you have to change to one of the other routes to get to your destination, the downtown trains are very crowded and luggage can be a real problem. If you only have a backpack or small bag, Metro is the way to go!

column2: “Istanbul - suggested itinerary for a long weekend”
column3: IstanbulI found an itinerary written by someone on the web and have adjusted it a bit from our 4-day trip in July 2009.Our starting point was the UK.Hotel. I feel duty-bound to recommend the Sirkeci Konak hotel, right in the heart of the historic peninsula and slap bang next to the palace gardens, even though I want to keep this little gem to myself. Excellent and delightful ! I hope you will stay there. If you get it right, they might even meet you at the airport (though it didn’t work for us as we took ages to get through immigration).You need a Visa. We didn’t have one and were turned away from Istanbul passport control to get one. Easy to do but the downside was that we had to queue for passport control all over again, so remember to go to the booth first! It’s easy to find, on the left as you approach passport control. Costs £20, accepts $ £ Euros but not TLira.It's usually best to obtain the majority of your Turkish liras in Turkey rather than before you leave home, as the exchange rates outside Turkey are usually not as good as those inside the country. It's easy to obtain liras while you travel in Turkey by using your home bank ATM card, or exchanging cash US dollars, euros or GB pounds. If you want to pay your hotel in Euros, some ATMs will dispense Euros.Transfer to hotel. I would recommend a taxi for about £40. We got sucked into a ‘shuttle bus’ which was actually a private coach; expensive and we had to wait for it to come back to the airport from a previous run. You can easily get the metro and tram if you are confident about where you are going (!) but it is dirt cheap. You would need a few Lira to purchase your jetons for the rides.Day 1: Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia & Hippodrome (Friday)Morning flight to Istanbul's Atatürk International Airport (IST), and transfer to your hotel. Have lunch in a simple local restaurant, then take a walking tour of Sultanahmet, the heart of historic Byzantium/ Constantinople/ Istanbul:the Hippodrome, heart of Constantinople’s political and sporting life. Park called the At Meydani (Horse Grounds). Beneath the little park at the northern end of the Hippodrome is the Yerebatan Saray (Sunken Palace Cistern). Above the hidden cistern is a stone tower that was once part of the city's system of aqueducts.Ayasofya (Hagia Sophia), Church of Divine Wisdom – most important church of Christendom for nearly 1000 years. Now a museum which you pay to enter.Blue Mosque The mosque (built 1603-17) is the masterwork of Ottoman architect Sedefkâr Mehmet Aga. It's built on the site of the Great Palace of Byzantium, on the southeastern side of the Hippodrome. With its six minarets and a great cascade of domes, the mosque is a worthy sibling to Ayasofya (Hagia Sophia) just a few minutes' stroll to the north. Dress code - if you are showing a bit of thigh or shoulder, you will be given large scarves to wrap around you. As far as I recall, it is free to enter. Allow time to sit on the carpet and soak up the ambience.If you arrive too late for all of the above, it’s on your doorstep and you will get to it easily later, so chill out on a rooftop terrace instead!Day 2: Topkapi Palace, Grand Bazaar, Istiklal (Saturday)Get to Topkapi Palace before its doors open (usually 9am) and go straight to the Harem to assure your place in the guided tour, or just go at your own pace and read the information panels. I think you had to buy another ticket just for this part but it is worth it! After the tour, stroll the palace's spacious grounds and four courtyards at your leisure. Don't miss the Treasury in the 3rd courtyard, with its incredible gems, gold, and works of art. If there is a big queue, go in another door and backtrack to the beginning. Perhaps have an early lunch in the palace's Konyali Restaurant overlooking the Bosphorus and Sea of Marmara. In the afternoon, walk or ride the tram along Divan Yolu (Road to the Imperial Council, once the imperial road from Constantinople to Rome) to the Grand Bazaar for shopping ( Beyazit Square, a dozen restaurants in the bazaar, bazaar closed Sunday), or take a taxi to the Kariye Müzesi (Church of the Holy Savior in Chora) to see its splendid Byzantine mosaics. In the evening, stroll along Istiklal Caddesi (La Grande Rue de Péra) in Beyoglu to find a cosy cafe, bar or taverna for a drink, then dinner.We did Topkapi - Blue mosque - Grand Bazaar - flake out in the hotel - dinnerDay 3: Bosphorus Cruise (Sunday)Hop aboard a ferry (6 hrs) for a cruise up the Bosphorus to Sariyer near the Black Sea. After a seafood lunch, ride south stopping at the Sadberk Hanim Museum, Rumeli Hisar castle, and/or Yildiz Palace and Park. Stop in trendy Ortaköy for seaside tea and snacks, then taxi to Taksim Square for some strolling and window-shopping in Nisantasi or along Istiklal Caddesi (the city's most popular strolling, shopping and snacking street, antiques).(Or take a TurYol cruise (1.5 hrs, TL9, non-stop) from west (inland) side of the Galata Bridge on the south shore of the Golden Horn). N.B. sit on the Port side of the boat for the best views. Grab a fish sandwich with the locals on the Galata bridge before or afterwards.Spice market next to New Mosque on Sundays. Less overwhelming than the Grand Bazaar!Day 4: Lots of Possibilities! (Monday)If there's time before your board your homeward flight, visit the Archeological Museums, There are actually three museums here: the Archeological Museum, the Museum of the Ancient Near East, and the Tiled Kiosk (Çinili Kösk)), the Museum of Turkish and Islamic Arts, or the Egyptian Market (closed Sunday, but there's a big flea market outside on that day); or search for art and antiques off Istiklal Caddesi; or have tea at the Ottoman-Victorian Pera Palas Oteli (built for Orient Express travellers but closed for renovation in 2009); or hop aboard a ferry for the one-hour intercontinental round-trip/return cruise from Eminönü across the Bosphorus to Üsküdar, Kadiköy or HaydarpasaIf you only have half an hour to spare at any time, you can go visit the Cistern underneath the stone tower between the hotel and Galata Bridge. Pay to enter but worth it.Other info:Istanbul fish sandwiches are still being served daily at little restaurants beneath the Galata Bridge, and also in the traditional boats tied to the quay. Just go to Eminönü, then to the western (Golden Horn) side of the Galata Bridge. On the bridge's lower level you'll find several small restaurants with low tables and chairs. Waiters will cajole you in with shouts of Balik ekmek! and Buyrun! ("Come on in! Help yourself!") . ‘Proper’ fish restaurants here too.Eminönü is Istanbul's crossroads. Located on the south side of the Golden Horn at the southern end of the Galata Bridge, it's a major transportation nexus for trains, trams and buses, and the Eminönü ferry docks are always busy.It’s where the boat trips depart and the nearby sights are: the Egyptian (Spice) Bazaar, the Yeni Cami (New Mosque), Central Post Office (Merkez Postanesi), Rüstem Pasha Mosque and Sirkeci Station. It's a major shopping area and has been for centuries. The Byzantines bought their fruits, vegetables and grains here a millennium ago.Mosques: Avoid visiting a mosque at prayer-time, that is, at or within a half hour after the ezan (call to prayer) is chanted from the minarets at sunrise and sunset. Avoid visiting on Friday late morning through early afternoon, which is when the weekly group prayers and sermons take place. All visitors to mosques remove their shoes before stepping onto the mosque's carpets. This is a practical, not a religious, requirement: Muslim worshippers kneel and touch their heads to the carpets as they pray, so they'd like to keep the carpets clean. Walk around or behind worshippers. Wear modest, conservative clothing which exposes a minimum of flesh. No shorts or sleeveless shirts on either men or women. At the most popular mosques in Istanbul (such as the Blue Mosque), attendants may provide robes to wear during your visit if your normal sightseeing clothing is too informal. (No charge for use of the robe.) Women should wear a dress or blouse and skirt (at least to the knees), preferably with elbow-length or longer sleeves, and a headscarf, or a hoodie (unless it’s cold, don’t bother carrying this especially as you can ask for scarves to wrap around you). Men should wear long trousers and a sleeved shirt.A walk from the Grand Bazaar north downhill on Longmarket Street (Uzunçarsi Caddesi) (Longmarket Street) through the Tahtakale district to the Golden Horn and the Egyptian (Spice) Bazaar (Misir Çarsisi), 30 minutes plus browsing time. You get to see the exquisite Rüstem Pasha Mosque, one of Istanbul's finest architectural gems, which few tourists visit.Transport:You'll need to buy a tram token (jeton) to enter the tram platform. Look for a booth with the sign Jeton Gisesi (Token Booth). 2 tram lines. One takes you to the airportTünel is Istanbul's little 19th-century two-station underground train connecting Karaköy (Galata) and the southwestern end of Istiklal Caddesi. It's convenient and funInaugurated in 2006, the Füniküler (underground funicular) connects Taksim Square and Kabatas on the Bosphorus shore. At Kabatas you can board a ferryboat, sea bus, or the Zeytinburnu tram.Two lines of Istanbul's Metro system are in operation (map). The most useful for foreign visitors is the light-rail line connecting Atatürk Airport and Aksaray Square via Istanbul's mammoth Otogar (intercity bus station)Taxis – make sure the meter is on, switched to daytime rate. Turks don’t tip.Going home (it had to come to an end sometime). Take the tram next to the palace wall in the direction away from the hotel. You will need to change to the metro half way but it is easy. Allow about 45 minutes.

My husband and I, busy medical doctors, yet avid, adventurous and enthusiastic travelers, had recently an absolutely incredible trip to Turkey. My husband was most impress by the website, Turkeytravelplanner (http://www.turkeytravelplanner.com/). After reading all the suggestions at that most helpful website, he contacted Backpackers Travel Agency (http://www.backpackerstravel.net/) for suggestions about how we could fit into our tight schedule all the wonders we wanted to see during our one-week vacation. He got a reply from Tahsin Unsal who not only had excellent suggestions what to see and how to get around within our time limitations, but who also made all possible customized accommodations to the itinerary according to our wishes. We ended flying to Ephesus, then traveling overnight to the unbelievable underground- and cave cities and valleys of Cappadocia, and finally taking a flight to explore Istanbul.Tahsin’s arrangements for us in Turkey proved to be amazing – with details polished to perfection. We were picked up from hotels and airports without ever waiting even a minute. The tour guides were extremely knowledgeable and friendly and the accommodations were just what we wanted. Per our request, Tahsin made a individualized itinerary for a private half-day tour of “Jewish Istanbul”. What a unforgettable morning! In addition to the synagogues and The Jewish Museum, we made stops on our way to scenic overlooks, cemetery, an important Orthodox church – even to have a peek into a very old, historic Turkish bath!Tahsin was a personification of what we experienced of the Turkish people: extremely friendly and helpful in a very unassuming and sincere manner. The country was modern, and very European, friendly and easy to get around, yet full of history, full of wonders, full of affable and welcoming people. I have only two questions remaining in my mind: why did I not go there already years ago, and when can I return there to explore it more!Thank you so much, Tahsin, for arranging us this unforgettable, wonderful experience – made to perfection!Kristiina AltmanJeremy Altman

column2: “Indeed a city, where East MEETS West!”
column3: I was selected for a 4Days/3Nights FAM trip organized by Turkish Airlines and didn't expect much from the Turkish Business Metropolitan city of Istanbul.....the then Constantinople. Frankly speaking, I have forgotten my history classes readings 'bout this historical and well kept, preserved city of Europe or Asia ....why not both.In just simple words, I have fallen in LOVE with ISTANBUL!Gosh, it has everthing one is looking for....the night life, shopping, history, culture.....what not. It is indeed a must see destination. The people are so friendly and the food, wow, lots of seafood, the Kebab, Turkish Delights, choco....you just ask for it, and you will get it and for a good price.TRUST Me....have seen many places but by far, ISTANBUL is a great city. No wonder Napoleon The Great once said, If given the chance to select the world's capital city, I would go for the then Constantinople, now ISTANBUL.BessufekadTravel Consultantwww.ethiobesttours.com

Just got back from a great vacation in Istanbul. Wonderful city. We stayed in an apartment in Sultanamet, walking distance to Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Grand bazaar. Highly recommend apartments "Suite Home", comfortable and well appointed. Superb location. Good food at Rami, Hamdi, Doy Doy and Amedros. Cemberlitas Hammami is great. Dervishes at the Print Museum. Go, you'll love it!

We spent one night here and it was one night too many. The place smelled like cats, the bathroom paint was peeling off and it was skin-crawlingly, awfully, filthy. Upside is the location - right against the Topkapi Palace wall near the entrance to Gulhane Park, just a few minutes from the tram and all of the Sultanahmet sights - but there are many many hotels in this area and I have to believe that any one of them would have been better.They seemed to be doing some work to renovate the top floor so maybe there are some improvements on the way.
if you will go istanbul look at the plusistanbul.comit is very good and fantastic site.

To buy something worthwhile at a normal price in one of the bazaars is almost impossible; at best, a few souvenirs can be picked up there. North of the Grand Bazaar there are many shops selling much humbler produce. Little of this would seem worth taking back though – it’s the kind of garments and other trinkets they sell here in Belgium in Turkish shops and on markets. Prices in the posh shopping districts offer little advantage, if any, over those in Europe.However, there is one district in the old city that offers what appears to be quality fashion at reasonable prices. Some items carry the famous European brands and look like them too. Others carry local brand names, fantasy Italian brand names or are unbranded. This district is situated to the South of Ordu Caddesi near the Istanbul University.Be prepared to bargain there too – but from a more reasonable starting point often known in advance. Being able to speak Russian is a huge advantage – especially if you don’t speak Turkish… Many shops actually refuse to sell you single items, they appear to cater to who-knows-what kind of small post-Soviet shopkeepers. Occasionally they bear the word “wholesale” in the window but more frequently the russian word “optom”.What’s authentic there and what is not? I have no clue. Are the items genuinely of the quality that they appear? Not always in any case, so buyer beware – but I think we picked up lots of bargains: leather items, fur coats, shoes… We also avoided serious rip-offs (goose down comforters with almost no weight of down in them). Who shops there – can it really be JUST for Russian tourists? And isn’t that a bit odd?There are also some normal shopping malls out of town (Cevahir in Mecidiyeköy, Akmerker in Etiler, Kanyon…), these we didn’t reach so I can’t say what the shopping experience there would be but I imagine it would be more reliable and organized, prices presumably would be at least similar and probably lower. But maybe I’m wrong. Russian-language assistance would probably not, though, be provided (I do speak enough Russian to communicate).If you want to buy carpets and kilims in Istanbul, it surely isn’t the best place but it may be an opportunity you don’t have at home. It is absolutely indispensable to be really clued up on all the technical details in advance. There are buyers guides available – you can order them on Amazon, but there is also an English-language bookshop near the Blue Mosque at the beginning of Divan Yolu which is well stocked in all sorts of interesting material with a local slant – it will cost you much more but it’s convenient and pleasant browsing. Anyway you’ll certainly save from having these guides if you do intend to make a purchase.For some reason all those carpet stores are unable to provide any evidence for their long stories about the carpets they try to sell. I wonder why…Shops in the touristy districts displaying prices were a rarity. Unsurprisingly, those few who did, were doing great business. Elsewhere, we found all the hassling really tiring and it put us off the shopping experience, so we ended up buying almost nothing other than clothes in the district mentioned earlier.The Arasta Bazaar near the blue Mosque is much more hassle-free than the Grand Bazaar and an altogether more pleasant experience, though real bargains are unlikely.Don’t let the hotel take you by car to shops or restaurants, that’s yet another tiresome scam. For some reason, they can’t just tell you the address and let you go by yourself.Obviously the Turkish government has little vision or desire to reform the tourist experience, which is a pity as the city has great potential without any need for scams.For my full Istanbul review and links to photos see:http://caelumnovum.wordpress.com/2009/05/17/impressions-of-istanbul/

Istanbul is an amazing place , spent five days there and had so much to see and do , took my mother and we enjoyed every day visiting the many historic places and going round the city.only down side i would say is that it is not the best place for ppl with mobility problems. my mum has slight mobility problems but the problem was that Istanbul is a very hilly place . some of the streets are very steep and even though we stayed in the sultanahmet area where alot of the attractions , many of them are uphill and can be troublesome if you have a mobility problem.Overall there is so much to do the ppl are lovely , loads of places to eat, relax, visit and will definatly go back .it is one of those places where u can do as much or as little as you want.

For the most part, taxi drivers in Istanbul are friendly, honest and fast! (though don't expect seatbelts). But there are some real rogues and it's hard to tell them apart from the good guys. (The taxis are all yellow).So, from bitter experience, here's some tips.Try to get one from a proper stand, at railway station, outside hotel etc. If that's not possible, look for one with a logo on the door, of the taxi company or where it's based. Write down the taxi number when you get in. All of this makes it easier to make a complaint if you do get ripped off.A common con is for the driver to say that there's a big football match on and he has to change his route and tariff. Hard to argue with (unless you know the local fixture list) but best to get out and look for another taxi.They will also ask if they can drop you round the corner from your hotel/destination, again using heavy traffic as an excuse. Insist on going right to the front door - this makes it harder for them to pull the other major ruse - the 50/5 YTL note switch (you hand them a 50, they switch it - very quickly - with a 5 and claim you've given them the wrong note).if any of this happens to you - get the number, call the police and make a complaint.

column2: “Stay clear of the Kalmar Resturant in Istanbul's Kumkapi Seafood area”
column3: My family and I spent our Easter vacation in Istanbul. We are a well traveled family and have enjoyed many culinary experiences throughout Europe and the middle east. My father loves seafood and was especially excited to visit Istanbul's famous Kumkapi Seafood Market. I would recommend the area to any seafood lover, but would advise you to stay clear of the Kalmar Restaurant. Our hotel coordinated for transportation and dinner at a restaurant called Kalmar which is right in the heart of Kumkapi. Kalmar's appeared to be clean and inviting, but the service was subpar, the food marginal, and the restrooms were filthy. Unfortunately we had ordered before we could get up and leave, but three other couples did not make that mistake and left after exchanging words with the restaurant supervisor. I recommend the Kumkapi area to all, but it's best to take a taxi/walk and choose the restaurant of your choice.

After finishing with customs, there are many people outside who will ask if you want a ride into the city. Move past them and just go straight out to the taxi line outside. We paid US$25 into the city while most of the folks inside were quoting double that. The taxi did accept US dollars. The exchange rate was $1=1.58 TL while we were there. The exchange places in the city did not charge a commission. We arrived at midnight into Istanbul so we took a taxi. However, if you are into public transportation (like we are), you can take a train into the city for 1.40 TL one way. For instance, going to the airport after our trip (we stayed at the W Hotel), we caught the tram from Kabatas all the way to the end of the tram line, Zeytinburnu. From there, we changed to another train that took you right into the airport. All this for 2.40 TL per person. It was very easy and painless. One hour travel time.Overall, one of my biggest surprises was the friendly nature of the people. I have to admit that I went with some reservations but I felt safer and the people more approachable than either Paris or Rome. I never felt like I was going to get pickpocketed unlike Paris and Rome. Very helpful and friendly citizens.Once you learn the tram line, you can take the tram to all the tourist stops like Sultanhamet and the Spice Bazaar, etc... Again, it's extremely easy to use.We did a trip on the Bosphorous river through Senkron travel agency at the Arasta Bazaar (right next to the Blue Mosque). The boat ride was on a private boat with about 25 of us. We paid 30 euros for adults and 15 euros for kids. They accepted US dollars and they spoke English very well. The tour started at 9am and ended around 2pm after various stops and including the Bosphorous river ride. I'd recommend these guys and the day trip, as well. The city itself is very beautiful and we very much enjoyed our visit. After a while, I got sick of eating the same gyros and kebabs, but that's just me.

I just stumbled on this website dedicated to Istanbul restaurantswww.istanbuleats.comIn the Fall when I was there, a friend in Istanbul who considers himself a real "foody" actually took me to three of the places reviewed on this site. Great little hole in the wall places where the food is good and really cheap.The ones from the site that I have tried are:Pera SisoreFiccinPando (for kaymak)I look forward to getting back to Istanbul to try a few more of these places.Happy trails,-Jerry in Chicago

column2: “Visa Warning but great experience in Istanbul”
column3: When you arrive at the airport, get your visa (£10.00 cash - check out how much in dollars and euros) BEFORE you line up to go through passport control or you will be sent back. Try and get off the plane as quickly as possible - queues can be horrendous.This minor little hitch aside, Istanabul is an amazing place - very friendly and helpful people. Use the trams - very cheap and easy to work out, they will take you round most of the central part of the city - buy the 1.40 token before you get on.Take the 1.40 turkish lira boat over to Hydrapasha Railway Station just for the fun of a cheap tour across the habour - have a glass of wine in the station restaurant and watch the football on the wide screen tv. (Warning - if you are leaving on the overnight train to Ankara etc, there are very few places to eat near the railway station - we had to take a taxi to a shopping mall, but the station restaurant looked fine.Restaurants like to know if you are in town for a while - worth saying yes as they will make an effort to retain your custom.Rami Restaurant highly recommended (good) in all guide books but doesn't take credit cards (most unusual).Most of the hotels in Sultanahmed have wonderful roof gardens/bars which you can visit for the cost of a cup of tea.If you are feeling flush have tea in the Four Seasons - about 11 lira each but a wonderful experience.gb

Istanbul (or Turkey for that matter) was never on my list of 'must sees', but now I've been I can't wait to go back.What a wonderful place and people. Everywhere you look history is staring you in the face. From the magnificent Topkapi Palace with it's beautifully tiled exterior and interiors to the fabulous underground water cistern with it's decorative columns and huge schools of fish.Not forgetting the Grand bazaar overflowing with tourists and locals alike. All ducking and weaving from the on going cries of the stall holders.Variety is key in Istanbul; be it the myriad of ancient buildings, the colourful decorations of the buildings - both inside and out, or the people themselves. Predominately Muslim but a mix of traditional and modern views and lifestyles all living in harmony and very welcoming to foreigners of all faiths.If there is one place I would recommend this year, Istanbul is it.Enjoy!

column2: “My favorite Place in the World!! So Far...”
column3: Istanbul, such a delight! We spent about 5 days in Istanbul and loved it. From the wonderful sightseeing, Fantastic Hotel (Angels Home Hotel) excursion to Ephesus, the cozy little bar we found, spectacular food (kebabs) to the unforgettable night out in Taksim, Istanbul has it all to offer. The people are genuine (when not trying to sell you a rug) and the nicest on the planet. I have always told myself that I will visit places only once, but will definately be back to Turkey! A must go to any cultural enthusiast!! Thank You TURKEY!!

First I must thank all the wonderful TAs who gave such great info and advice. I know our trip was greatly helped by all who had gone before and made such wonderful suggestions. We knew about the $20 cash visa payment and were ready at the visa window while others were in wrong lines. We stayed at the Zynep Sultan hotel -- and couldn't be more pleased with the location and the reception staff. It is sooo close to all the "Must sees", but is off the main street to reduce noises. We went to several restaurants that had gotten good reviews-- Hamdi down near the spice market was very good, but our FAVORITE was Albura cafe near Aya Sophia and the Four Seasons hotel-- we went there 3 nights during our week stay. We did the Princes island ferry trip-- very nice-- including the horse and carriage ride. We ate at Ali Babas restaurant right on the water and found in Ahmet not only a proud owner of a wonderful restaurant, but he went to the ferry docks, to find us and to return a scarf that I had left at lunch. The Bosphorus cruise was relaxing-- not quite warm enough in March-- the weather could have been kinder-- mostly in the 43-48 F range , with occ showers and one downpour day. The Aya Sophia was still undergoing construction- and most of the mosaics are gone or covered. My husband was disappointed in Topkapi-- it seemed less opulent than we imagined-- but treasury rooms have amazing gems. I enjoyed the harem-- we used Rick Steves guide books-- very helpful for self guided tours. The Grand Bazaar was overwhelming-- sensory overload-- the spice market less frenetic-- and the spices were an eyeful. We had the best interactions with the people. You have to ignore the "carpet salesmen", but people came to offer help when we were looking lost and always had a smile . I will try to do more specific info about the hotel and restaurants in future reviews. For now again thanks to my TA friends who were so kind as to share for the enjoyment of others.

I traveled with 3 other women to Istanbul and then on to Cairo for a Nile cruise. I was a little concerned about proper dress and being women alone in this country. We stayed at the Arcadia Hotel right in walking distance to many attractions and the Blue Mosque.The people were helpful and always respectful. The Spice Market can be a bit intimadating but if you respond nicely to them they become less pushy and will take no for an answer. They were always helpful with directions and anything you might need. We hired a private tour guide which I would strongly suggest in order to get anything out of the Mosque tours. There are many tour groups that have 50-75 people and they all follow their guide around who holds up a tour sign. We were very pleased to pay about 25 dollars a person for the day to have a small group, be lead to a real local restaurant and actually hear all the information about the Mosque, Hippodrome, etc Nice to ask questions and learn about things as well.The food was beyond excellent. No one ever even got an upset stomach, it was delicious.I regret not spending more than 3 days in Turkey and touring down to the shore for a longer time. Gorgeous country.

Oh... We just love Istanbul. We fell in love with the city and its people the minute we arrived (except for some scam which you will read later). Our family took a holiday in Istanbul in March 2009 (end of winter). The airport was quite decent, although not as grand as KLIA, DXB or LHR. One thing for sure, the exit was very easy and you find taxi just a few meters away. Anyway, we were greeted by the driver from Historia Hotel and our guide whom we have booked much earlier. They are just so friendly and warm towards us.The next 8 days were just marvellous and awesome with my most favourite times spent enjoying the Islamic Art and culture left by the Ottomans. The building architecture and designs are just magnificient. The scenery and views, people and sights are just wonderful. Turkish hospitality is second to none. We had the privileged of being hosted by 2 Turkish families, one on the Europe side and the other on the Asian side. And I must say that they were just wonderful, I really felt at home and being pampered like a king. The Simsek and Gunther families are not only my good friends now, but I consider them to be my relatives, brothers and sisters.Our holiday in Turkey could have been just perfect except for 2 occassions with the scam at a fish restaurant (The Fish and Cheap) and some leather purchases at Grand Bazaar (Pera Leather) - this is the Hate part - . Please avoid these 2 places as they are crooks and will do everything to cheat you including giving their soul to Satan.Nevertheless, I must say that we had a truly wonderful and quality family time together in Istanbul, oh yes not to forget the great hospitality of the Historia Hotel which we stayed in, and thank you zillion times to our guides whom we have now considered as our brothers and again to the families of Simsek and Gunther for their warm companionship and hospitality.We would surely return to Istanbul to explore other parts of Turkey.

column2: “My favorite place in Turkey is Istanbul”
column3: The whole city is so exciting and magical. The people are lovely, so kind and friendly. The sights are much to beholden. So much history.I have been many times, and I still find new and interesting places to go to.I will never get tired of this place.The shopping is brill, and the main shopping street the Turkish people go to is the best. So many different things to see and buy.If I was told I could go only on one holiday for the rest of my life, it would be Istanbul

From the European side all you see is a hill covered with antennae. But this hilltop park is one of the highlights of any trip to Istanbul. Catch a ferry to Uskudar and hail a cab. 20 minutes or so later you are atop the hill. Follow the footpath and prepare yourself for jaw-dropping views of Greater Istanbul, the Bosphorus and beyond. I visited on a weekday and there were only a handful of other visitors - at weekends I understand it becomes very busy.It was the second day of Ramadan and just after 1 the slightly annoying piped music was turned off and the call to prayer began. The haunting sound floated up from every mosque in Istanbul, from Europe and from Asia, from every side. Even for someone non-religious like myself it was a deeply spiritual moment.And unlike every other sight in Istanbul - it's free!

column2: “Very friendly people but be aware of some scams”
column3: ScamIstanbul is a great city. There are very friendly and helpful people. Most of all, it is very secure city. Its food is excellent and there are lots, and lots of things to see and do. However, I want to advice travelers of a scam very common in the Taksim square area. This part of town is the commercial area. A lot of shops, cafes, night clubs, bars and so on. There is an important street there (Istiklal). It is a pedestrian street. During the night, this street is full of people since there is a lot of night clubs. Usually, the scam is done by two well dressed, middle age men. They target single men that look obviously outsiders. I was approached by two gentlemen. They asked me the time in Turkish, when I told them I did not speak Turkish, they asked me where I was from. They look extremely well dressed, have strong command of English language and moreover, very knowledgeable of world affair. I kept walking but they kept beside me having a very nice conversation. Finally, after a few minutes of our conversation, they asked me if I could join them for a beer in a bar near by. I was reluctant but finally I accepted. They scored me to a very nice bar. It was a basement of a building, underground. When I went down the stairs, I noticed that one of them left. I thought he may have gone to the restroom. The other gentleman took me to a table, we sat down and a waiter came. We ordered each a beer, after a few minutes, a beautiful woman from the Eastern Europe sat down next to me and the other man asked me if I would buy a drink to her. I immediately realized that it was a set up to meet hookers. I refused to buy a drink and asked for my bill. To my surprised I was charged 40 Turkish Lira (around 20 Euros) for one beer. I got very angry and made a scene. The owner, afraid that I would make a big scandal, allowed me to pay only what I thought it was fair for a beer (10 Turkish liras). I left the place. Besides, this incident, Turkish people are very friendly and very helpful. Fortunately, I caught the scam very early. I went back to the same area three days later and once again, two different gentlemen approached me in the same street, I started laughing but they never understood why. They probably thought I was crazy!! So, if you are single man walking on the Taksim’ area, be aware of this scam.

column2: “You wıll go back agaın..and agaın...and agaın...”
column3: Istanbul ıs a place you fall ın love wıth.Number one thıng I want to mentıon ıs the people.... the most ımportant factor that makes a cıty what ıt ıs... the people who lıve ın ıt....If you have been ın London or Athens.... downtown.. you come accross people rushıng on theır way, talkıng on theır mobıles payıng no attentıon to who or what ıs ın theır path.... well forget all that ın Istanbul.... you need to take a step back and breathe the cıty ın... nobody wıll knock you out of theır way... nobody walks fast, nobody talks on theır mobıle.... and ıt ıs a 15-17 mıllıon people place....Ask for dırectıons and you wıll be amazed..... ın theır bad Englısh they wıll try to do anythıng for you... ıf they can take you there.. trust me they wıll.People are so nıce ıt ıs scary... walk ınto a small shop ın one of the not so central areas.... you get served tea or Turkısh coffee wıthout beıng expected to purchase anythıng.... you do get the hustle of people tryıng to pull you ın theır lıtle busıness but you just smıle and go on... nobody wıll grab you from the hand...You need to understand ..... the people here are maınly poor but they do not cry over ıt or bother you or have a face lıke ıt ıs the end of the world.... they are nıce because they feel lıke ıt... because ın theır poor lıves.. beıng nıce makes them feel better....Now.....food!!!!If you lıke your meet stop readıng and go to Istanbul.... they really know how to cook well all sorts of meet....If you are a vegeterıan lıke me... ıt wıll be a bıt harder to fınd a place to eat some real food.... ın addıtıon to that be prepared for a hard tıme communıcatıng..... I nearly kılled the waıter ın the Galata Tower when he would not lısten that I do not want any chıcken......TransportatıonIstanbul ıs a bıg cıty.... more or less you can go ın most places by publıc transport and ıt ıs all layed out nıce for you.... you wont get lost even though everythıng ıs ın Turkısh.... ıf you are lost do not be afraıd to ask dırectıons... everyone wıll help...Shoppıng....Need to pay a bıt attentıon there.... never pay the fırst prıce gıvenalways bargaın but do not over do ıt... those of you famılıar wıth Egypt... thınk of ıt as a down versıon of that....A good ıdea ıs to walk only ın shops that have prıced ıtems so you have a start and do not get robed....Nıghtlıfe.....It ıs dısco tıme ın Turkey..... get rady to get back to the ´80s ın some really bad clubs wıth names lıke Malıbu or somethıng else bad!Restaurants are everywhere but the really good ones are rare..never eat at the Galata Tower for the love of god.... the vıew ıs amazıng..... the whole Istanbul as far as the eye can see.... but both food and servıce are the worst I met ın here yet (I am stıll ın Istabul)....Those of you who come from the UK and are used to everythıng beıng sterıalızed and super clean do not even get on the plane..ıt ıs a dıfferent country... dıfferent rules.... good old fashıon handmade food.... not super clean but super tasty...Photography....If ıt ıs your hobby... get some serıous gear and lots of memory cards.... ıf you are stayıng for a week, there ıs no chance to see everythıng so here´s a top lıst-Agıa Sofıa-Top Capı-The blue mosque-Galata Tower-The harbor area (take a tour boat... ıt´s good)-Taksım (don´t go clubbıng there)...and you´ll fınd many many more places to shoot some gıgs ın photos..I hope that was hellpfull.... thank you for yoıur tıme!John

From palaces to pussy cats (everywhere!),From towers to teas,From interesting residents to rugs,From sea waters to mediocre wines,From cobblestone streets to streetside cafes,From Nescafe instant coffee to Starbucks' real stuff,We experienced it all, from Dec. 3 to 10! We trammed, we vanned, we bussed, and we walked up and down, up and down, through busy markets and vacant streets. In so doing we met some fascinating folks in the vicinity of our hotel in the Sirceci area, near the largest must-see tourist attractions and the wonderful Metro line.We arrived at the airport most distant from our hotel, got instructed on what bus to take, then which ferry to catch, then where to walk to reach our hotel---all from the hotel reservation sheet. We had decided to take a cab at the last moment, but the cabdriver pointed out we were just two blocks away!The Grand Seigneur Hotel was mediocre in our estimation, but the clerks were most helpful in answering questions, even in their halting English. Lighting was poor when I needed to put on my make-up. We had a "suite" for a reduced rate since it was off-season, but we liked our last night's room almost as well. The young Turks ran to meet our needs and wants. Breakfast there was sliced tomatoes & cucumbers, olives, boiled eggs, a balogna-like sausagecheeses, breads, cakes, many jams, often yogurt, Nescafe coffee or tea, cereals (but no milk except for coffee), and "omelet" upon request---merely scrambled eggs spread out on a plate.We tried wines, I drank a beer often, and we used bottled water in our hotel and elsewhere. We were healthy, happy and always open to a new adventure each day.Highlights were the Golden Horn and Bosphorusday-long river tour, which included half a day on the water and half a day in a bus, stopping at the Dolmabalce Palace, a cable car ride down a mountain after wandering through a cemetery, getting sight of Istanbul from many perspectives, both European & Asian. We visited a lot with our fellow travelers, from Pakistan, India, Cuba and the U.S.We extended from the original five nights to seven so we would feel unrushed and relaxed. It was a great experience time-wise, culture-wise, and all ways. Sara (Val's wife), Salmon, Idaho

After studeing and living in Istanbul for half a year I can't do anything but love the city. Split in two by the Bosporos you have one Asian and one European side. Though both true Turkish, you can see the difference. Traveling from one side to another by both is both relaxing and interresting. In the tourist areas you have for example the Blue mosk (Sultan Ahmet) and an old egyptian Hippodrome.Taxim Square is the main center with shopping and dining. To walk down Istiklal street on a Saturday night you really understand that there is 15 million people in Istanbul.The nightlife is great with everything from small places with good food to nightclubs with international DJ's.A great city with an very interesting history.

column2: “The most underrated city in the world.”
column3: Positive comments: Turkey is by far the most exotic country in the world. A must see. I've been to Istanbul two times and stayed there over a month in total yet I couldn't see mostof the things I wanted to see. Me and my husband are from different cultures, I'm European, he's American. We both LOVED Istanbul. The city is like the mix of western and eastern culture. Hip hop artists and bellydancers perform on the same stage, you can catch an Eric Clapton concert in a concert hall that comes from another century. It's one of the oldest cities in the world, historical places are absolutely fabulous. You can find churches, sinagogues and mosques on the same street. People are very helpful. There are all kind of restaurants, clubs, bars and shopping malls. I didn't know the city was THAT touristic, during our holiday we saw people we weren't expecting to see (Sting, Shakira, Tom Hanks... they were all on vacation). Me and my husband want to live there in the future, it was that good.Negative comments: Istanbul is one of the most populated cities in the world. Naturally the traffic is awful (especially between 4-7 pm) and some parts are dirty. Unlike most Turkish people, taxi drivers can't speak really English. The first time I visit Istanbul it was winter, it was too cold we couldn't even go out from our hotel much. So if you're planning a trip, do it when it's spring/ summer. If you're looking for a "beach holiday" Istanbul is not the right place. Good, sandy beaches are far from downtown.

I have visited this city and after visiting 22 countries this is for sure our fevorite place,it has everything ,where east meets the west and so much history,modern city with contrast,5 star hotel like maslak Shereton made our trip more memoriable,my kids loved it ,food was fantastic,people were friendly,we went to city Antalya,and it was the best resort town we ever visited,most of the resorts were 5 star and l played Golf in Belek,great new Golf courses.this is a uniqe country and very modern, not we expected at all.l have told many of my friends and elatives and show our pictures we have taken,no wonder 27 million international visitors came this year alone,we will come back ,there are many placeses we wanted to go but was not enough time.Takman's

Well, you get ripped off from the airport, the taxi driver to the hotel, the hotel itself (book you in another one with less comfort), the restaurants (overpriced) and the shopping..Never again. They need to change the mentality before applying to join the EU

Istanbul was the capital for two empires (Ottman & Bezantyn) both in a one Squre Km. therefore it is a place that every one must see. When in Istanbul you must see the trio- (SultamAhmet, Hagia Sofia (Santa Sofia) and Topkapi Saray (palace)) then Minaturk is a place that sums turkey as a whole, also takining the 7.5YTL = 5$ trip accross the bosfourus.Other than that shopping in istanbul comes in two forms modern which is exactly like and (if not less) other city in the world, and the old where (if interested) you shop for spices and artifacts. Overall Istanbul visit (in my openion) shouldn't be more than 2 nights/3days. but Turkey has alot to offer so spread your visit to Turkey.

Istanbul - it is one of my favorite city in the world .I know better the asian side with his quartiers Bostanci , Kartal , Pendik , Tuzla . I pass also the european side , I been many times in his Ataturk airport . I saw Dolmahace palace from the bridge and Besiktas center and seaside of Marmara sea . Istanbul is 1001 nigths of Sherezada . Must be visited and feels directly on your body .
You can find every thing you need. Romance, history, Excitement, Luxery, cheap things, wonderful hotels, mahnificent views, etc...Just go....

column2: “Interesting place, but too many people hassle you.”
column3: Istanbul is an interesting place to visit. We visited the Blue Mosque, make sure that you have your shoulders and legs covered and shoes that can be easily removed. There is no charge for entering the Blue Mosque, but it is a nice gesture to give them a couple of lira on the way out as a donation. It is a beautiful mosque and looks brilliant at night when lit up.Visiting the Grand Bazar is a must. The atmosphere in there is great and it caters for all tastes and cultures. It can be very annoying at times when people hassle you and won't leave you alone. Shop owners are often rude to you when you ignore their requests / orders to go into their shop and NEVER go into a shop if you feel uncomfortable. One of the ways sales men try and lure you in is by asking where you are from - don't tell them unless you are prepared to be drawn into a conversation and hassled into buying something from them. When buying from them NEVER deal in Euros, only deal in Turkish Lira. They use Euro basically to make their prices look better and the Euro is not the currency of Turkey. Shop owners never put prices on their goods, so i suggest you make your offers by starting with a phrase like this - "I will give you a good price" - then mkae your offer at least 20 - 40% lower than what you are prepared to pay, then you and the seller can work your way from there. ALWAYS inspect the goods thoroughly for any faults before you begin negotiations as obtaining a refund / replacement after the sale is difficult or impossible. If the salesman tries to pass on something that you don't want, then walk away - The majority of shop salesmen there are only interested in selling, not giving the customer what they want, so you have to stay in control. Never let salesmen see how much money you have, unless it is the exact amount you want to pay.If your final offer is reasonable, but not accepted, walk away (Often as you are walking away they will give the item to you for that price.)A word of advice about carpet sellers - be careful and don't take their stories about all carpets being hand made too seriously - most are made by machines in factories. if you are only looking in a shop, then tell the shop keeper that you are looking for something (say a bag) and if they have exactly what you are looking for you will talk to them further. If a shop keeper starts to hassle you, get out of the shop immediately.Restaurants: The best way I can describe the majority of restaurant people is that they are parasites. 3 of the restaurants that we chose to eat at were great. We were not hassled, we were made to feel welcome and the food was great too. We ended up walking out of one restaurant after they delivered one meal and 20 minutes after it was delivered + 3 requests later, my fanta and my mother's meal had still not been brought to the table. If you are walking through restaurant areas, be prepared to be hassled and harassed by restaurant people trying to get you into their restaurant. We encountered people trying to push us into their restaurants. AVOID like the plague the restaurants under the Yeni Galata Bridge (Where the local ferries come and go) The people working at the restaurants are the rudest and most aggressive here.It is worth spending a day on a ferry going down the Bosphorus River, but DON'T buy a BOSPHORUS TOUR ticket, instead, but a 1 way ticket to Sariyer, which is the second last stop. The journey will last about 70 minutes and you will see some spectacular buildings, as well as beautiful mansions along the river. The drinks on board are the same price as on shore and are great quality. When you get off the ferry at Sariyer, if you want to want to visit the Black Sea at Kilyos, walk out of the ferry terminal, turn right when you reach the road and walk about 700m up the road until you see a bus stop with a green or tan coloured mini bus, get on it (1.50 lira) and it's a 20 minute trip to Kilyos. Kilyos is a friendly little village with places to shop and eat where you won't be harassed or hassled. The only down side is that you have to pay 5 - 10 lira to go to the beach.I wouldn't recommend Anodolu Kavagi as it is full of restaurants selling the same food, with the most obnoxious restaurant people I have ever encountered. (Some will even chase you down the street harassing you.) There are a few shops that to be honest just sell junk as well as a large population of mangy cats. If you do decide to visit it, there is a castle that is a 30 minute walk from the town. (Just make sure you get back in time for your ferry.)Turkish people are certainly not lazy people - even the bums on the street offer some kind of service for your donation. Turks may seem a bit disorganized, but they generally get the job done to a good standard. They work hard, most shop keepers start work at 8am and often don't finish until 10pm.Don't go there expecting everyone to speak English. (If this is what you want, then I suggest you find a package tour) I ran into an English woman who complained to me that hardly anyone spoke English, so I pointed out to her that she was in Turkey. If you are trying to communicate with someone, keep a pen and paper handy and write things down or draw diagrams. My mother felt that women were not respected by men in Istanbul. She was often pushed and shoved (even knocked down once) by men, so it is something to be prepared for.In Istanbul, you can drink the tap water, but it doesn't taste nice. Bottled water only costs 1 - 2 lira for a 1 litre bottle. There are many cats and dogs around the city. DON'T touch them and certainly don't let your children touch them. Their behaviour can be unpredictable and many carry diseases. If you see a restaurant with cats around it - keep walking. (you wouldn't eat at a restaurant with rats around it would you...)Scams and Thieves - There are often gypsy children begging in the streets. DON'T give them money as it goes straight to their parents. I carry a packet of sweets and I give them a sweet as I know that the child will get it not her / his parents and it makes me sad to see children doing this.The way thieves get you is they go into a crowded area and bump you trying to dislodge anything in your hand, so keep you pockets zipped up, things out of your hand and if someone near you looks dodgy, then make sure you are behind them where you can see them.A common scam in Istanbul and Turkey is where someone approaches you offering to exchange lira to euros or vice versa. They usually hit more vulnerable looking people such as elderly. Basically, they will offer some stupid rate such as euro for 1 lira (It should be about euro for 2 lira), then talk loads and give loads of figures to confuse the victim. NEVER deal with anyone who approaches you on the street. If you want to change money, check out a few money exchanges, get them to write down what they will give you. When you have decided which one to use, make sure that you get what was written on the card, if not - walk away.The Turkish currency is the Lira. Most businesses write their prices in Euros to make them look cheaper, so be aware of this. personally I don't think businesses in Turkey have any right to deal or display prices in currencies apart from their own.When going to the airport, allow an hour on a shuttle bus to get to Ataturk Airport. If travelling in a taxi, know how many kilometers roughly you have to travel and make sure that the meter goes on. Your hotel will be able to organise a shuttle bus (45 min journey) for about 8 - 10 Lira. When you get to Ataturk AIrport, your bags will be X-Rayed as you enter the building. It is a nice airport - very clean (toilets also), but spend your money before you go to the airport as all prices there are an ABSOLUTE RIP OFF. One cake stand wanted to charge 1 lira for 1 mini mars bar that you find in a celebrations pack.To sum things up, Istanbul is worth visiting - give yourself 2 - 3 days there. Loads to see, interesting culture watch your money and make sure that you stay in control with your money and don't afraid to walk away if you're not happy. It's not a good idea to tell someone where you're from unless you know them as this is how shop and restaurant people draw you in. I have mentioned a few places to see, but there is loads more to see and do. (Museums and galleries don't interest me anymore) One more thing.... - make sure you go to the toilet before you leave your hotel.

Dear Fellow Travellers,My boyfriend and I spent a few days this summer in Istanbul visiting some of the major tourist attractions in the city and taking two quick and convenient side trips by plane to Cappadocia and Ephesus.Our tour operator was www.turkeytravelservice.com and www.allistanbultours.com in Turkey and I must say that they made all the difference in our travel experience.The tour itinerary covered the main attractions in Istanbul, Cappadocia and Ephesus well and most importantly, the prices were very reasonable! That ofcourse, gave me extra money to buy some fabulous jewellry and local ceramics during our travel [much to my boyfriend's dismay!].Istanbul is a lovely city, with so much flavour to offer and during the summer months is overwhelmed with tourists from all over the world, particularly from the US. We made some good friends during the tour with a couple from Britain and New Zealand as well. It was a good vacation, did not feel like returning....!I recommend the Istanbul by Night, Ottoman Relics and Istanbul Classics tour from www.turkeytravelservice.com and the Cappadocia and Ephesus by plane from www.allistanbultours.com.Best luck and enjoyment in your travel to Turkey. Be safe and always haggle for prices - it's fun and gives you more of an accurate idea of the cost of goods.Cheers!MelZar

Fascinating city of Istanbul! Spent two days walking around Istanbul, with obligatory site seeing and just as obligatory in a big city being followed by a man (happens almost in every city). Bangkok crowds pale into insignificance with these! Of my travels, perhaps only Manhattan comes close to the number of people in one place and on such a scale! Tourists are only about 10%, with locals of all sorts. Interestingly although not surprisingly, while there are many people who “look” Turkish, with black hair, dark eyes, dark complexion, there are many who look anything but what a stereotypical Turkish would be expected to look like, being either blue eyed with blond hair, ginger haired, south east Asian, central Asian, Georgian, Turkmenistanish, and many others, all speaking Turkish. Its unexpected, but not surprising given the history and location. Crossing from Asia into Europe and back was surprisingly effortless with no passport control. Walking over a Golden bridge where hundreds of men and one or two women are fishing with long rods off the bridge. Occasionally you see them catch some small fish, and a few had very small silver fish no more than 10 cm in buckets with water, half swimming half floating bellies up. The bridge is double decked, with fishermen and cars on the top deck, pedestrians and restaurants on the lower deck, and ferries and boats underneath. I intended walking on the lower deck, but was dissuaded by swinging fishing lines with many hooks and lead weights. Locals don’t seem to mind though.There are more taxies than passengers and you are more likely to be haled by a taxi than other way around. I had a few rides in a taxi. I used a seat belt in one of them after a 5 minute struggle looking for the buckle that was well buried within a back seat. In other taxies I was not as lucky, but took a philosophical approach of paying not only for transportation but for the thrills of rally-like driving while being unsecured in my seat. One taxi driver was very polite and offered me a cigarette, and when I refused he proceeded to smoke holding the cigarette with one hand and talking on his cellular phone with another hand, all the time gesticulating. Not sure how he managed to change lanes so many times. Other rides that I had taken were on an old tram, on a new tram and being taken for a ride by the concierge at my hotel: I read about the tram from Taxim square to Sultanahmet to where I was going and asked where the stop was, but he insisted on calling a taxi which appeared rather swiftly after his phone call, while later same day I found that a tram stop was near by that would take me right were I wanted.Traffic rules would probably be more appropriately called traffic guidelines as stopping, turning, traffic lights, changing lanes and speed limits are clearly open to interpretation. Pedestrians cross where there are no fast moving cars. Slow moving cars in traffic are not an obstacle. Small trucks and small streets with shoulder to shoulder crowds are not mutually exclusive either I found.There are more restaurants than people eating I thought. Many waiters are in a business of making money more so than in a business of serving. I understand when a street vendor tried to trick me when I was buying a 500ml bottle of water by giving me 25 cent change instead of 50 cent change. I objected with a disapproving sound, and he promptly exchanged the coin for the correct one even though he does not speak English. I went into a café, set down and asked for tea. The waiter – a teenage boy, wrote on a piece of paper “4YTL” and signalled a large glass. I agreed, knowing that he is likely overcharging me.
