I paid and he brought me a glass, and then later another one at the same price. The only debate I had in my mind was whether the actual price was 3 or 2 Turkish lire. On the way out I found out it was 2. I was not upset: for equivalent of $3 dollars I got him to serve me at a self service place. That is cheap for Europe!There are more hotels than I saw tourists (although they all seem to be booked out). Most of the upmarket Hotels are at Taxim Square sort of in a ghetto, on a few blocks sealed from cars except for taxies and delivery trucks, and with security guards at the entrance and road blocks.There are more shops than people buying staff. Grand Bazaar seems an outdated term and should be renamed Bazaar city. While there is a section demarcated by old stone walls, these walls mark no boundary for the shops and sales activities of all sorts continue in all directions in every crevice in a wall and pavement, for many blocks until it flows into another stone-wall-demarcated Bazaar called Egyptian spice bazaar. I have never seen such a concentration of spices in one place, although there was more than just spices on offer.Turkish Ham-am was interesting. I have been massaged before, but have never had a male do so much to my limbs, back and head. Any more than that and I would have felt violated. While I was lying on hot marble, he even walked on my back (I was glad then that he was a skinny guy). Half the customers there were Russian tourists.On one narrow street bumped into a colleague. How could that be?I skipped lunch and had an early dinner in a good restaurant with a view of Bosphorus. The waiter insisted on pouring me a glass of water, for which he charged me later. Stepped into a shop with sweets and asked for two pieces of Baclava, only to be given 3 pieces with a charming smile. Back in my room where before I left I had put a sign out not to be disturbed as I did not want my room cleaned, only to find out that it was rearranged (cleaned would be overstating it), and the sign was hanged inside my door.The attitudes of the local small time sales people to small change are a part of the experience of being here. Poor people will always try to make any money they can, and I take no offence at them trying to rip me off by a few cents. This happens in every country. But I have never encountered it to be so wide spread at every level, from a street vendor to a taxi, a hotel or an expensive restaurant, and always for a few cents, from trying to give me 25 cents change instead of 50 when buying a bottle of water, to giving me change in a respectful restaurant in smallest coins that there are including 5 yeni (5 cents) and standing over me while I pick them up, hoping I will leave a tip, which I did not as they already included 10% service charge on a bill in Turkish without telling me. It sort of spoils it a little bit. On a brighter note, I only stepped on a raker once before, when visiting one of the sites and being told by a local man wearing uniform that it is closed until afternoon, and that I should take a tour of the nearby places instead. He then haled a taxi. While being driven off I recalled the description of this scam from the travel guide and told the driver that I would like to go to a different place. He got very upset and told me to get out, which confirmed my suspicions. Today I had a man tell me that the Blue Mosque was closed. I smiled and stared him in the eyes and he left me alone. I proceeded to the Blue Mosque which was not closedTips:Buy an Akbil for public transport if staying more than two days.Go restaurants recommended in Fromer’s guide were very good.Don’t take a taxi unless you have to.Taxi from airport to Taxim is about 30TLR, and shuttle bus is 10TLR with a long ride.

Istanbul is a beautiful city with great weather. While landing into the airport, one gets to see the Sea of Marmara and many ships and boats all aorund - what a delightful sight!The people are pleasant and helpful and most speak English. There is so much to see and do in Istanbul. It is a reasonably priced destination.I recommend the Grand Bazaar (lots to see and buy here), the Blue Mosque, Sophia HAgia, Underground cisterns, eating on the streets and restaurants around (not in your hotel), walking around through the gardens, a 1.5 hr Bosphorus cruise, Topkapi Palace.Do buy an AKBIL tram billet/ticket to get around in an inexpensive way.Istanbul is very safe and one can walk about till late at night.The attractions are absolute marvels and the sea ia clean and blue.Its a great place to visit.

Istanbul, Turkey.After one good night on the train (it was comfortable!), I arrived in Istanbul with shock. 'Chaos' was the first word that came to my mind. Crowds of people rushing by, traffic jams and vehicle horns here and there ...The official tourist organization was not doing a good job here. There was no tourist information center in an international train station! I could not get a map, could not find any one to answer my questions. Seeking help from the locals was tough, and trying to understand them was a mission impossible.I went on my way to the Blue Mosque anyway, hopefully everything will be sorted out before dark.“If you don't know where you are going, any road will get you there.” ~Lewis Carroll~Hopped on a tram after breakfast and I was standing in front of Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia in just 15 minutes.Wait, I saw a tourist information center right at the park beside Hagia Sophia! Ha! I got a map, some hostel information and a hostel owner, aka scammer. He offered me a cheap hostel room and talked me into stay in his hostel, saying it was high season and all hostels were full. I followed him because his hostel was right next to the hostel I wanted. He first brought me to a travel agency, offered me apple tea and started selling me some over-priced tour package. I left within seconds.The hostel was just 5 minutes walk from the Blue Mosque. After dropping off my backpack, it was already 12:30 pm.I was standing on the street between the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. Geee, how could these two giant things be so close but yet not over-powering the other? I was impressed!The Blue Mosque was solemn and absolutely stunning. Hagia Sophia was as well astonishing. Too bad the dorm was under repair and almost half of the Hagia Sophia was covered by construction materials.I was soaking wet simply walking between the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. It was hot! The 'Sunken Palace' Yerebatan Sarayi did cool me off a bit. The largest underground cistern and pulsing lights effect made this place a good visit for the tourists in summer. However, my camera ran out of battery when I was ready to see the two Medusa heads supporting columns, arghhhh!Okay, I was not going to any more tourist attraction sites for the rest of the day because my camera was dead. What could I do around 5:00 pm without my camera? But wait, I did not need a camera in hamam!The turkish bath was disappointing and the massage was simply a joke. The prices for tourists were three or four times the local price, but they did not even perform the same services on tourists. I was surprised they had the nerve to ask for tip.I treated myself to a nice lamb chop at night in a restaurant.Next morning, I rushed to the Topkapi Palace before 9:00 am to avoid crowds. The palace was immense. The sea shore views were marvelous and the treasures in the museum were breathtaking. I was speechless.The rest of the palace was also magnificent. However, about one quarter of the areas within the palace were closed for renovation during my visit, I wanted my money back.Even more ridiculous was, Harem, being part of the palace, they charge another 10 Lira on top of the palace ticket. It was a robbery! I did not pay.The archaeological museum beside the Topkapi Palace was more like an art museum to me. Majority of the collections were well known and stunning scriptures. 5 Lira well spent!Suddenly I realized it was 2:00 pm when I walked out from the museum. I was starving.I went to the Grand Bazaar after lunch. It had lots of shops!!! I did not spend too much time there since I was not going to buy anything. I quickly walked past all shops to avoid those persisting 'come-to-my-shop-salesmen'.Note to self: start next trip from Istanbul and bring no clothes, buy all clothes there for the entire trip!

Just got back from Istanbul for a 3 night city break. Stayed at Grand Star Hotel in Taksim area and found hotel very good, despite reviews I had read which put me off a bit (other peoples standards are obviously a lot higher than mine). It was clean, well located, nice bathroom, comfy bed, breakfast was more than adequate and had partial sea view from the restaurant. The food places in and around Taksim area, specifically Istiklal Street were excellent and cheap, if you like kebabs and Turkish food and snacks. The sights around Sultanahmet i.e. Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar etc were great and boat trip on the Bosphorus was a great way to see the skyline- mosques etc. The traffic is crazy and taxi's are cheap (as long as you don't get ripped off i.e. apparently they have a habit of wanting to take you the long way round, so you need to know the area etc, so check approximate price first.) I feel I really need to warn travellers to be extremely vigilant regarding taxi's, we were ripped off twice in 3 days, firstly got a taxi and gave driver 50 turkish lira note, he said he didn't have change and caused a bit of commotion eventually taking the change we had. We later tried to spend the 50 lira note (equivalent to approx £20) to find that it was a fake, obviously swapped by the driver. Then when we got a taxi to the airport, the driver told us it was 53 lira, we gave him 55, he then showed us two 5 lira notes and said we had given him this instead of a 50 lira note, we thought it was our mistake and swapped the 5 for a 50, then off he went. But my friend realised she only had 50 notes and we had again been robbed. Other taxi drivers quoted us inflated prices for a journey we knew was close. Another thing about taking taxi's is that the traffic is so bad, it will take ages to get anywhere, so walk or take trams etc. We loved Istanbul and would go back, but please be warned about taxi drivers and always check what money you give them, steer clear of 50 lira notes.

column2: “One of my favorite places in the world”
column3: I went for 9 days several years ago. And I think about it all the time. A great city to visit. I stayed at a cheap hotel about 1 mile from the Hagia Sophia. I would walk and see the sites (mosques, bazaars, etc) all day, eating food from vendors on the street - kebobs, hot pistachios, etc. Loved it! Some of the best food I have ever eaten in my life. At night I would spend a little more and have dinner at a nice restaurant. Learn a few turkish phrases - it will come in handy and they greatly appreciate you trying to speak their language.Go to the bazaars and do some haggling. The vendors will take you by the arm, and walk you into their shop, close the door and sit down and have tea with you. Don't allow them to push you into purchasing anything you don't want. Just be firm and buy what you want. Simple rules for haggling. The price is is always negotiable and you can always get at least 40-60% off the asking price. Shop with cash, it makes things simple, and the vendors hate American Express. They will tack on a 2-3% surcharge for AMEX. If you have any questions, let me know.

We travelled to Istanbul recently and flew into Sabiha Gokcen airport. It cost 50 euro to get into town.We stayed in Laleli area which is an enjoyable 10 minute stroll down to Sultanamet where Hagia Sofia and Blue Mosque and beautiful views of the Marmara sea.If you go to Sultanamet go to the Seven Hills Hotel and visit their roof terrace where you will enjoy the most stunning views of the sea and surrounding attractions.please email me for more info

3 Star Hotels in Istanbul aren't the best but the experience in Istanbul was Great. We toured Hagia Sofia first built as a Christian church approximately 600AD, then was converted to a Mosque during the Ottoman rule and is now a museum. The Citerine's in Istanbul were built using pillars from pagen temples. The Blue Mosque was also incredible. The Sultan's castle and treasures from the sultan's were very interesting. We also toured the Bosphous and took a fairy to the princess islands..

I have spent a great deal of time traveling in Western Europe over the past several years, but this was my first experience away from the more familiar. Not being sure of what to expect, Istanbul ended up being a fabulous exposure to the less Americanized Eastern Europe. The people of Istanbul are warmer than perhaps any who I have ever met. They seemed truly inviting to us as we visited their hotels and restaurants, shopped in their stores, and talked to them in the streets. There are many things to make sure to catch, including the Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, and the Suleymaniye Mosque. What is most engaging in this city, and what you need to save time for is to wander the streets, whether it be through the winding corridors of the Grand Bazaar or Spice Bazaar or the small side streets off the main ways. Make sure to take the time to talk with the people you meet. They will warmly greet you (while also trying to sell you whatever they may be selling) and you can then talk with them about the experiences of their lives and understand the unique culture which is not only preserved in the mosques as it is in the cathedrals of Paris or Rome, but that still lives in the streets in the calls to prayer at the crack of dawn, the ubiquitous presence of the semi-feral cats that wander the streets and hotel lobbies, or in the chestnuts being sold along the streets.

Merhabar! How would you like one of the oldest, most historic and most beautiful cities in the Mediterranean for your birthday? That's what Richard got today -- Istanbul on his big day. We took the shuttle bus into the heart of town, where Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, the Blue Mosqueand the Grand Bazaar are all pretty close together. The guide on the bus points out the highlights as we drive, including the Suliman Mosque and the "New Mosque" which is 500 years old, but new by Istanbul standards. We won't have time to see it all, and we are already vowing to come back to Istanbul. Bus dropped us off at the Bazaar, and we walked about 10 minutes straight up Nurosemaniye Street, to the Blue Mosque. We are accosted many times on the way, in Turkish fashion, by shopkeepers who want to know where we're from, and to lure us into their stores. Finally we meet a very nice young man who speaks excellent English. Richard is very wary of him at first, but he says very forthrightly that he'll show us how to get to the Blue Mosque if we will visit his carpet store afterward. So, we agree -- it's sort of like a free trip somewhere in exchange for listening to a timeshare spiel. On the way, we hear the call of the muezzin, calling people to prayer. Our volunteer guide not only shows us to the Mosque, he gets us in during prayer time, when tourists are not allowed -- he speaks to the guard, and voila! we get to take our shoes off, put them in a plastic bag, and carry them inside. It's fascinating to watch the Muslims pray, bowing their heads to the ground over and over. What a lovely ground to bow to! The Turkish carpet is stunningly beautiful, covered with designs and flowers. The mosque is huge, with verses from the Qu'ran in gorgeous calligraphy on several walls near the top. It has a dome ceiling, gorgeous blue stained glass windows in Arabic design, and blue mosaics on the walls. We wait until the people finish praying and then take some gorgeous pictures.There are steps, and steps, and more steps. Outside the mosque is yet another small bazaar, with a restaurant and about 8 shop stalls. We buy a lovely blue plate, hand painted, for our dining room wall. Then, the obligatory visit to the carpet store. The young man, his work done, disappears as soon as we go inside. He's probably gone off to find other pigeons. We are ushered up four flights of stars, given the customary Turkish apple tea (no tea, really,Muslims don't drink caffein) and shown breathtaking carpet after carpet. If the prices were more reasonable, we'd probably have one, but they begin at $3,000, and finally get down to $1,400, which is still 3 times what we'd be willing to pay. When they leave the room, Richard and I joke about having that gorgeous carpet in front of our fireplace, covered with Pugsley's hair. It just doesn't fit our lifestyle. So, we part amiably, having used their clean little restroom one more flight up.My knees are not liking all these stairs. We cannot get into the Hagia Sofia, because it's closed on Mondays, like all museums in Turkey. We decide we're too tired to see the Topkapi palace, which is another long walk farther away from where we must meet the bus. So, we'll save that for our next trip.We head back, stopping on the way to buy roasted chestnuts (Which I remember from my NY childhood) from a street vendor, and various things at small shops along the way. One shopkeeper has beautiful woven purses, like rug fabric, but he's too high -- we walk away, and he comes down to a really low price, so we about face and buy some, but then he seems angry at us (although no one is forcing him to sell -- it's his price) so we don't buy more at his store. We keep walking, it's not easy on the cobblestones, and we find a little shop with copper plates with handcarved designs. The man in the shop shows us how his carving works, he is very warm, we buy a lot from him, and when he finds out it's Richard's birthday, he gives him an enormous "evil eye" about 6 inches in diameter, with a lovely beaded hanging cord. It's now hanging on the lamp on Richard's side of our bed. His wife is very friendly, too, and gets a big kick out of my few words of Turkish. I guess not many tourists try the language. I buy a silver chain that Richard likes as one of his birthday presents, and he's a happy camper. Finally, we're back at the Grand Bazaar, exhausted. We wander through a bit, but it's way too big -- hundreds, maybe a thousand shop stalls, and most of the merchandize is the brand-name stuff we don't like; like Guess clothing, expensive watches, and questionable fine jewelry. So, back out onto the street, where we finally find an Istanbul T-Shirt for me, and at the last minute before the bus arrives, we find a shop which has Turkish bead bracelets. I buy two, at $5 each, and after we get back to the ship, and I have a chance to really look at them I wish I'd bought 10 more. But, a very satisfying day in a stunningly beautiful city. There are birthday balloons on our cabin door, and a special birthday dessert with a candle and off-key singing for Richard at dinner.I brought birthday cards from home, so now they're magneted to the wall in our cabin.

The trip to Istanbul was a fantastic experience. Grande Seigneur hotel in Sirkeci was at a great location. The staff there were friendly & Polite. The rooms were clean & welcoming. The information they gave us about the place, their advise helped us a lot. The Blue mosque, the Topkapi Palace, the Suleiman Mosque & the Bosphorous cruise are a must see & experience.

I just came back from a fabulous holiday in Istambul, Turkey! The city is the most beautiful place i've travelled to and is unique in every way possible. The history goes back more than 1000 years with influences from the Romans, Byzantine plus Europe, Asia and the Middle East during the Ottoman Empire. Thus the culture and the food is so mixed and varied it'll make your head spin! Turkey is now a Replublic and a very modern islamic country with a national alcoholic drink, rake! It is a city where Europe and Asia meet by a bridge (actually 2) separated by the bosphorous (which is between the Marmara Sea and Black Sea).You need a minimum of 1 week in istambul as there are so many things to do. Must see places are:1) Sultanahmed area - cover in 2 days (a good place to stay)- Haga Sophia- Topkapi Palace- Blue Mosque- Suleiman Mosque - breathtaking!- Bacilica Cistern- Archeological museum - very interetsting- Grand bazaar - a must! Lots of crafts, leather goods, biggest jewellary market in the world, scarfs and all for reasonable prices- Spice bazaar - a must too!- Cemberlitas Hamami - turkish bath2) Dolmabache palace - this has all the furniture still intact and left in the palace so u will get an idea of how the sultans lived during the Ottoman Empire. Includes a guided tour3) Taksin square - a trendy and underground place for shopping and food. Best known for its tiny inner lanes and meals made up of mezze, fish and rake.4) Bosphorous tour (either full day or half day)It is also nice to drive along the bosphorous on either the European side or Asian side. Stop at Ortokoy for coffee and lunch at Emigan.4) Island trip to the Prince Islands by ferry (1/2 day)5) Istambul Modern - art gallery with a nice cafe serving mediterranean foodand many more!!Turkish cuisine is scrumptious! As i mentioned lots of influences from Europe, Middle East and Asia. Food to try:a) Mezze - hot and cold. A healthy meal with lots of salad & vegetables plus raw seafood, hummous, aubergines stuffed wt meat, etcb) Kebabs/ doner kebabsc) Dolma - meat/fish and rice wrapped in wine leavesd) Kofte - Grilled lamb meatballs wt yoghurt and salad - a speciality in Sultanahmede) Borek - a pastry with cheese, vegetable or meatf) Fish sandwichesg) Others - cheese, olives, breadMust also have turkish tea and turkish coffee!A good travel site for turkey is [--]ENJOY!!

Been here? I live here, or I have done for the past two months and will continue to do so until my teaching contract expires in June. Istanbul is a great city, although it has turned out to be more expensive to live here than I thought. (Maybe I was in Thailand too long)It is not an easy city to find you way in, as the signs are not always helpful and not many people speak English. Health and safety are a bit lax here and the ferries and other means of transport are risky, but fun if you are careful.Istanbul is very spread out and spans many bodies of water, which involves taxis,buses, metro, ferries (which stop running after a certain time) even a tramway and a funicular railway!The Mosques are magnificent and the bazaars beautiful. You will enjoyevery moment here.

We took a Mediterranean cruise starting the last week of September, with Istanbul as our starting point. We had 4 days there on our own before the ship set sail and used the services of Vanguard Travel Services ([--]). This was a customized tour package that included transfer to our hotel from the airport, 4 days of guided tours (including all entrance fees and including a day in Ephesus), transfer to our ship, and 3 nights' hotel (Swissotel the Bosphorus). This was a big splurge for us (we were 2 couples) and the hotel is not what we would normally select, but it was part of the package deal and I must say, we were not at all disappointed. We had great tour guides and for 2 days, we had the best tour guide I've ever experienced in a man named Sait. He gave us so much information and history, along with his witty sense of humor, that I felt like I was back in a college classroom. He pointed out things we would see later in our cruise in Greece & Italy that all had origins or connections to Istanbul. He really was quite amazing.Istanbul is a city that, quite simply, took my breath away. The views from our hotel were absolutely gorgeous. The hotel itself definately catered to the business client, and we were consistently underdressed compared to everyone else staying there, but it was a beautiful location and the rooms were extremely nice, and I hope they didn't mind us coming through in our shorts and sunhats. The free buffet breakfast was excellent (I had the yummiest yogurt I've ever had in my whole life there)--better than the cruise ship's! Plus each evening there was a "happy hour" with free appetizers and drinks. I loved the fried Halloumi (I thought that was a Greek dish), among all the other delicacies.Our first half day was a get acquainted driving tour with Yuseph to the various sections of Istanbul as well as the Asian side of things, and then he took us to the Galata district where he grew up, we climbed the Galata Tower, thoroughly enjoying the views from there and then it was time for dinner. Yuseph took us for our first dinner in Istanbul at Haca Abdullah near Taksim Square for a fabulous meal of local foods (I loved being able to walk along the counter and just pick what you wanted and it was so nice to have the guide along that first night to tell us what everything was.) This meal was the favorite for all 4 of us while in Istanbul. We then were given free time to walk around and get outselves home to our hotel, where we crashed in the luxury of our palatial room.Days two and three we were greeted by Sait. We toured the Underground Cisterns, which was really fun, and then it was history lesson time. Sait knew it all and we just simply took in the sights as we listened (and later tried to get the answers right to the pop quizzes he would give us!). We saw the Obelisk of Theodosius, what's left of the great hippodrome, and Chora Church, which by far was my favorite of all the sights we saw in Istanbul. I was stunned and in awe of the mosaics in that church. We also saw the Ayasofya, the Topkapi Palace & Harem, the Blue Mosque, the Kariye Museum, the Giris Museum, and the Dolmabache Palace and the Spice Market. By mid-day our second day I was suffering a severe case of TNS (Travelers' Neck Syndrom) from so much looking up into all the domes. We then had a wonderful private boat ride on the Bosphorus past the Kucuksu Kasri summer palace, all the architecturally quaint and beautiful summer homes, past the town that's famous for its yogurt (wonder if that's what the hotel served for breakfast?), past the Rumelihisari fortress that was unbelievably built in 4 months(!!!), under the Bridge of Fatih Sultan Mehmet and on to a small seaside district just within view of the entrance to the Black Sea for a late lunch at a seafood restaurant --I think it was the Mer Balik Restaurant (good food, great view and they opened just for us--another one of Sait's many cousins, uncles, brothers--wink, wink). Then it was off to the Sabanci Museum for a showing of Ottoman calligraphy arts as well as a display of some very famous abstract art, which was lost on all of us, including Sait (and I'm a painter!!). After that, it was time to do some serious shopping, so off the the Grand Bazzar, where Sait accompanied us to various rug dealers and ceramics shops where he knew the venders (more cousins-heh heh).Said to say, we took leave of Sait, and we were then on our own for dinner which was in the Beyoglu area along a street with so many fish restaurants and people handing you their menus that I can't remember the name of the one we finally decided upon, but the food was mediocre and we were all in shock whenever we heard the prices for fish no matter where we were in Istanbul. Stick with the lamb dishes. Our favorite lunch place was the Pudding Shop right across the street from Hagia Sophia (which shows you how sophisticated our tastes run).Coffee--I have to say a word about coffee. We're coffee nuts (coming from the land of Starbucks) and everywhere we went in Turkey, there was fantastic coffee of all kinds, including Turkish Coffee which I learned to love and soon we were having it for breakfast, lunch & dinner!My favorite sights (not counting all the mosques, etc.): I loved the Spice Bazzar (Bought some special pepper that was recommended to me, some whole nutmeg, a special paprika, and saffron, of course. Also some Turkish delights and Anatolia honey.), the Grand Bazzar was something else and great fun (got a rug, of course, then some tea towels, some cute ceramic salad plates, and some really fabulous neck scarves unlike anything I've seem back home), loved all the fishermen that gathered every evening on the Galata bridge and totally enjoyed the hotel deck where you could watch all the boat activity in the harbor--mornings were amazingly busy. It was a great place to have our morning Turkish Coffee (that was after we had our first complimentary espresso in our room that came with it's own little espresso maker!), our afternoon cappucino, our pre-dinner drinks & appetizers, and our after dinner nightcaps.I appologize for the length of this report, but it's Istanbul...there's no way to make it short & sweet. Our last day there was spent just taking it all in again, enjoying the shopping and back streets around the Grand Bazzar. I loved everything about Istanbul--the people, the sights, the smells, the food, the glorious architecture, the amazing history, the colors, the sounds, THE COFFEE....how do you encapsulize a glimpse of a city that is home to 12 million people with a history like that? Did I mention that Turkey was my favorite on this cruise that took us to Greece, Dubrovnik, Kotor, Amalfi, Sicily, Venice & Trieste? And I won't even go into Ephesus--suffice it to say that it was fantastic and amazing and our wonderful guide Sadat was there to ensure that we learned all there was to learn there, as well. The weather was perfect our whole trip--mid 70's to low 80's--a perfect time to travel this area.

Istanbul is the perfect long weekend getaway and well worth the longer-than-Paris, etc. flight from the States. We had a wonderful time - it is very safe, the food is excellent, the people incredibly friendly and the city rich in history. The typical tourist spots are well worth seeing, particularly the larger Mosques and Ayasofia. If you want to be close to those spots stay in Sultanahmet - mostly smaller, boutique hotels that aren't quite as expensive but don't offer the luxury of the larger, business-type hotels around Taksim Square.

we just returned from our 5 week vacation in istanbul. we are all missing it already. everyone makes you feel so comfortable there. we ate and danced with the turks,as well as made a few friends.my boys swam in the bosphorous,and sea of marmara. we rode the train and bus to urgup and back. it is like night and day riding the public transit system here, as opposed to the united states. my wife and i took a moonlite ferryboat cruise up the bosphorous to anadolu kavagi. the boat had several types of music playing from dance techno on one level to the more traditional music on another level. we chose the traditional music...... it really touched my heart, every one of the turks on the boat were singing the old classics (young and old). we had an hour to enjoy a meal at the many restaurants in anadolu kavagi....wow hamsi, turks really love their hamsi. it was great. the cruise runs may thru sept.on saturdays and stops in eminonu at 7pm( cost is 12 ytl), which is very affordable.

column2: “A great place at a great price”
column3: Very economical hotels and restaurants, especially when compared to western Europe..Plenty of history at every corner..Felt safe at all hours of the day & night..Very much enjoyed all the smaller restaurants that had roof-top terraces with incredible views..Even The Sinbab Hostel had a roof-top terrace with a view like a postcard!..The downside are the ever-present carpet salesmen!! The 3 main markets are NOT to be missed!!

My family and I have visited Istanbul for 10 days in August 2007. My last visit to the city before that was in November 1985. What a difference 22 years make! I have to admit that most of my fond memories of the city and the country are now gone! It is as expensive as any other city in the world; the food did not taste as good as we expected it to be; and some people have been plain rude. I guess, I was not ready for that!!My first experience was when I went to a bank outlet at Istanbul Airport to exchange money. I handed the cashier US$ 1,200. To my utter surprise, I got the equivalent of US$ 1,100 in Turkish Lira. I counted the money, which I rarely do, and realised that there is something wrong, so I asked for a receipt. I pointed out to the lady cashier that I gave her US$ 1,200 and not US$ 1,100 as the receipt said. She immediately printed out another receipt and handed over the difference!!We stayed at the Best Western President Hotel at Sultan Ahmet area. This hotel has a great location. Free breakfast and internet service were included in the rate. They offered free airport to hotel shuttle which was very convenient. I stayed in a presidential suite overlooking the sea which was great and my family stayed in double-room which gave us some privacy. However, the hotel was noisy; breakfast was unimpressive and service was poor. When we checked in no one offered to help with our bags and when we checked out it took about 20 minutes to bring our bags down. We have booked a shuttle to the airport the day before we checked out for 12.30 in the afternoon. It did not show up on time and we were repeatedly told that it was on its way. Our flight was at 3pm, so, only when I started shouting that we were going to miss our flight, did I manage to get some attention from the reception staff. One of them very very rude. He kept saying I had to be quiet and wait until things sorted themselves out. As we argued, another one stepped in and apologised for the delay, told me that the shuttle was not coming and offered us 2 taxies to the airport free of charge.Having been around Istanbul and other parts of Turkey, we found that shop keepers and taxi drivers around Sultan Ahmet area to be the rudest. Indeed, the taxi drivers would take for a ride, so to speak, any time. The older they are, the more stubborn they would be. Driving manners are poor and very hazardous, with very little regard to the safety or convenience of the people in the car or others. It is best that one insist on them using the Meter and put the A/C on.We have been to the usual tourist sights and enjoyed them. Our faviourate one is the Topkapi Palace although, unfortunately, some parts of the Palace were under maintenance and we could not get to see them.We only used guided tours for going outside the City. We used the services of ITS (International Travel Services). They were great. We used them to go to Prince's Islands and Bursa. The programmes were well thought through and the rates were very reasonable. There was never a dull moment during the tour. The only downside is that the buses were not fitted with toilets, so you have to be prepared!We also did some shopping. The city has some nice shopping malls. Apart from a shopping mall named 'Carousel' which was very unimpressive (very small and very crowded), the rest of the ones we visited were good. We highly recommend Metrocity and the gorgeous Kanyon (what a beautiful architecture). Naturally, we loved Istiklal Street.Because we come from the Middle East, we were not impressed with the quality of food or the prices. The only one restaurant that we would recommend is Beyti which, unfortunately, is located near the airport.

We have just returned from 5 days trip to Istanbul, Turkey. From the moment we landed at the airport, we were so happy seeing our hotel driver are already waiting for us. We taken to the hotel in a very nice van. We stayed at Hotel Niles, Istanbul. The Front Desk greeted us once we arrived and give us all the information we needed for that day about the hotel and will brief us later on the places to visit and the transportations. Our room were simple and nice on the 5th floor. We liked the hotel as it is very near to all the main attractions and also another plus for the bus stations and the trams station. Our first day, take a taxi from our hotel to visit Hagia Sofia Museum for only 3 YTL. Hagia Sofia Museum cost 10 YTL and it is a very interesting museum to visit and with its history and from then we walk to the Topkapi Palace which took us about 10 minutes walk. The entrance fee is 10 YTL for the palace. Once you enter the palace, take the left entrance and go straight to the Harem and buy another ticket for 5 YTL per person for the audio guide (dont forget to bring an ID) and you are set to go. We spent the longest time here as it has a lot of rooms and part s of the palace to see. We ate at the Can restaurant in Sultanahment area. It cost us 29 YTL for two plates of white rice, half grill chicken with fried potatoes, one plate of salad, one plate of white bean in tomato sauce and two mineral water with soda and a light coke but the next day we were charged 43 YTL which really surprised us!!! Went back to the hotel to take a nap as the weather is very warm. At 5.30 pm we took a bus No. 61B from the Beyazit bus station to Taksim. It was quite interesting coz you are able to see the shops and some hotels along the ride!! You could also take the tram to Kabatas and then take fenicular for 1.30 YTL to Taksim. We arrrived in Taksim about 35 minutes due to the traffic and we walk to the Taksim Square and cross the road. Here is just like part of Europe. It has a lot of eating kiosk and restaurants plus shops. We tried the hamburgers which cost 1.50 YTL and it is really delicious and it is go if you want to eat it on the go. But our favourite restaurant is Afacan Restaurant in Taksim. It is really a yummy to tummy place to eat. We had our dinner here twice and we were surprised how cheap it was and the service was fanstantics and a clean service. If you go and eat there, please dont forger to tip the server as they really hardworking people. We ate on our first time there, one big mixed salad, two plates of white rice, half chicken, white bean in tomato sauce, one plate of kofta in tomato sauce, two mineral water with soda and light coke for only 27 YTL!! The second time we ate, half chicken, two plates of white rice, one plate of meat in tomato sauce over bechamel, one big mixed salad, one plates of meat goulash, one plate of kofta with tomato sauce, two mineral water with soda, light coke for only 29 YTL!!! We also ate two rice puddings and one mineral water with soda and light coke for only 15 YTL at Saray and bought the dessert to flight back with to Vienna and it was packed nicely for us!!The next day we took a taxi to the Egyptian Bazaar, as my husband like the easy and lazy way but we were unlucky this time as the taxi driver took us for a ride which really upset my husband but the trip to the bazaar make us forget all about it. We bought a lot of t-shirts and we really get it for a bargain for only 8YTL at a shop No. 62 and also the key chains with the evil eyes!!! We went to Orphan out of curiosity but we were disappointed as he was not that friendly to us and ignore us completely instead opt to read his newspapers but one of his workers was happy to serve us, I was curious about the scent of Rose which LL always mentioned one of her favourite!! so i get to smell it and also Ottoman and was told that we could not get it anywhere but we told him no that we can get it in Cairo, Egypt and that silence him cause he knows Cairo, Egypt has a lot of oil scents more that what Orphan can offered in his shop!! and another thing the Egyptian bazaar get its name from the traders that comes from Egypt and also the spices that they brought in from Egypt. After that we went to the Grand Bazaar and we didnt buy anything here cause we find that it is more expensive here then the Egyptian bazaar and most of the people here when you asked for the price the immediately quote you in Euro or Dollar which really annoyed us!!The third day we went to the Domalbache Palace which is really beautiful and the crystal chandelliars are the biggest in Europe and so beautiful not to mention the paintings in the palace. The entrance fee is 20 YTL for the palace and the harem. 6 YTL for the camera. If you wish to come here better come early in the morning as the tour guide take only 35 people in one trip and if not you will have to wait outside under the sun or rain as there were no chairs or place to take shelters!! The garden surroundings the palace is so beautiful with all the big blooming roses with so many colours and the view of the sea and the bridge really make it worth to visit!! After this we again take the fenicular to Taksim and have our luch there at our favourite restaurant Afacan!The fourth day, we went with the tram from Beyazit (1.30 YTL) to Kabatas and from there we took the fenicular only 1.30 YTL till Taksim and take another metro to Metrocity Mall and the Kanyon Mall for 1.30 YTL. We liked the mall as it is very modern and it has a very big food court which offers you all kind of food and the shops also offers some discounts. I bought myself a jean skirt for half of the price at Evans!The fifth and the last day we went to the Blue Mosque and prayed there and taken some pictures of the mosque. It is free entrance and the mosque is so beautiful. After the mosque our last trip is to the Sunken Palace, Yerabatan Sarnici which cost 10 YTL. The moment we entered, we feel so nice and cool and there are a lot of fish in the water, the beautiful pillars and most of all the medusa heads which is so unique! We got out and then shop around the area near our hotel and buy a few things there and went to the airport with transport from our hotel.The trip were really wonderful, we loved the places that we visited, the people are very friendly and helpful and we always feel safe whenever we are in Istanbul. We hope to come back again next time.

column2: “The Old City is a real gem”
column3: So much to see in the Old City, so pick your hotel well. Dating back to Roman time a must see and easy overlooked as its underground is the Basillica cistern. It has 336 marble colums. The water was fed via an aquaduets to the Cistern. A fee is payable on entry 7euro or $8, well worth it

i travelled to istanbul on the 21 December and married my beautiful husband on the 27th.Istanbul is a very beautiful City the people are very nice the food is outstanding. I had the most wounderful time ever, unfortunatly after 10 wounderful days i had to leave my husband and return to england.I will be cming back very soon, how could you resist not going back to a beautiful city.Diane Aygun

Why Travel to Istanbul?Apart from being historically and architecturally spectacular, with a skyline of mosques and minarets surrounded by water, Istanbul is the only city in the world that lies on two continents. There's plenty of sunshine, green and blue space, OK food, good beer, terrible wine, great prices.The Turks are very friendly and not too pushy even when selling a carpet [tho' don't believe every word they say].It's a lot safer than most European cities and the shopping is sensational.And by the way, Istanbul is not Turkey's capital - Ankara is.Sights/Activities:Old City, around Sultanahmet: Topkapi Palace [a huge maze-like palace; to see the popular harem, go in the morning to get a ticket], also check out the lovely Ottoman style street adjacent to Topkapi entrance, Aya/Saint Sofia [ancient cathedral], the Blue Mosque, the Hippodrome [monolith], Sultan Suleyman Mosque, Yerebatan Underground Palace, the Grand Bazaar [and while you're there don't miss a real marble Turkish bath with traditional massage - it's beside the tram stop near the Bazaar]...New City, across the bridge: Galata Tower [great views from the top], Dolmabahce Palace, Istiklal street [popular pedestrian street].Also check the views from the banks of the Bosphorus and Marmaris seas.*Dress appropriately when you visit mosques.Cuisine guide:Turkish meals are a mix of Mediterranean and central Asian cooking with olive oil and spices, and lean towards meze [mixed appetisers, like Tapas, starting with cold meze, then hot meze, fish or meat if you can afford it for main dish, and finally some sort of sticky sweet thing.Old City: for fresh sea food and value for money, go to the lively Kumkapi area. Otherwise the Sultanahmet area has a good selection of mid price restaurants.New City: Çiçek Pasaji [food court] and the adjacent street is a pleasant, good value dining area with lots of great fishy things on offer.Try Musa Ustam Adana or Konak for kebabs. Go to Tugra [Ottoman cuisine] or Safran for a posh Turkish mealIstanbul Travel Guide, the climate:Best: April - NovAvoid: winter [often wet and grey] and Ramadan when fasting people can get irritable and services become unreliable [Oct 15 - Nov 14 '04, Oct 5 - Nov 4 '05].Short Trips:Take the Bosphorus ferry; visit: Uskudal [Istanbul's Asian side]; The Princes' Islands [Kizil Adalar] - resorts with hip restaurants and clubs; Iznik [historic lakeside town famous for tiles]; Bursa [hot springs and ski area].Shopping guide:Souvenirs: Istanbul's massive Grand Bazaar [nearly 5000 shops in 30,000sqm] and Egyptian Bazaar.Also for traditional Turkish tourist stuff such as carpets, leather and jewellery, go to Cagaloglu area or Sultanahmet area in the Old City.Made to measure leather goods can be amazingly good value.Classy, trendy shops can be found in Beyoglu or Osmanbey areas in the New City.Shopping Centres: Carousel, Galleria [Old City], Akmerkez [New City, the best European shopping centre award in '95]Festivals guide:Not a very festive city, but...mid-end May, Theatre Festivalmid-end April, Film FestivalJune 9th - July 3rd, Music FestivalJuly 6th -21st, Jazz FestivalMuslim festivals:Seker Bayrami: a 3-day fesival at the end of Ramadan [see above for dates]Kurban Bayrami: a 5 days festival, March-April.* we strongly advise you to avoid/ make plans for Kurban Bayrami, because banks and offices close for a week, accomodation will be expensive and difficult to get, and travel will be a nightmare.Arts/Culture guide:Museums: The Archaeological Museum , Mozaik Museum, Museum of Turkish Carpets.Galleries: Museums of Turkish and Islamic Art, Museum of Fine Arts, Istanbul Museum of Paintings and Sculpture.Night Clubs/Belly Dance/Live Music: expensive and touristy, but try Orient House in the old town, Galata Tower Night Club, or Saki Restarant in the new town.Check 'The Guide' magazine for event info/listings.

Here is my review of some of the hot clubs in Istanbul...Thurs. night we went to Samdan (Etiler section of Istanbul). This place is one of the "in spots" in Istanbul but it's hard to get in. They got us for a $100 dinner before we could go upstairs to the club. Club is small and smokey (everyone smokes in the clubs in Turkey). There were some famous singers, actors there. Drinks were a lot of money ($50 for 2 cocktails). It was okay but small and not really all that for the price. The music was European techno - not too good.Friday and Sat. nights, the new spot is Nu Terras, in Taksim. This is a restaurant that becomes a club at about midnight. Again, we did the restaurant thing just to assure that we would get in - about $60. Drinks again were about $15 each (and, ladies, men aren't too generous about buying them) The music was Euro disco and hip/hop. The place got extremely crowded with a good crowd 20s-40s. I would recommend Nu Terras.Sat. we went to the newest spot - Cahide- (pronounced Jaheeday) This club is in the Matchka section of Nisantasi. This club is definately hard to get into...we had to beg to be let in. The cost wasn't bad - about $20 to get in, including a drink. If you are afraid of crowds - this place is not for you. Very smoky too. The crowd is beautiful, famous (not that I knew who anyone was). Music is a mix and the crowd is varied in age, tending to be older. This is definately the place to be, you won't read about it in guide books as it is so new.Went to Reina but I think it's more of a summer, outdoor place.Went to 360 in Taksim, which is a restaurant/bar with a view of Istanbul. Great view and decent food but not much as far as a club.Taksim is like the Village in NYC - a lot of bars but a bit of a rough, young crowd.Hope this serves you well.

I have just returned from a 5 night break to Istanbul with a Dutch friend - both of us who live to travel. Our choice of destination was a last minute decision even though Istanbul had long been on our 'must see' lists.What a breath of pure fresh air........the weather was terrible..heavy rain and high winds and, to be frank, we were not sure if a city existed above the 1,40mt barrier of the base of our umbrella sights. Despite this, what made our stay a dream were the people. In a frenetic and bustling working city you see people in their everyday working environment. This is not a classic holiday destination and although many Turks speak English/Dutch/German etc, they are catering as much for Turks as foreigners. Courteous, humble, witty, charming, friendly, helpful, educated, warm...I could go on and on.....The food was stunning in its' simplicity - some thing for all budgets and nothing beyond any budget. Standards are high and although retail prices are not as low as you would expect (i got a particularly low rate of exchange and rates much higher at banks and Exchange Bureaux), definitely a case of you get what you pay for.High standards of hygiene across the board - even the most basic toilets much cleaner than say the UK.Sure, there are a lot of 'tourist traps' but any wise traveller can avoid them and interaction and basic knowledge of language rewards highly.The final day brought sun and a broader vista of the city and the people and a longing to return and discover what we didnt see first time round.Istanbul suffers, in some senses. Logistically, maintenance of this ancient and incredibly hilly city with its' history of earthquakes must be a nightmare and it shows... side roads and pavements are a hazard and the city is certainly not good for the disabled and perhaps young children. Push chairs would be a NO NO!. Culturally and historically extremely rich and rewarding.Do not be put off for any reason travelling to this exciting city - where else could you look out on another continent and three stretches of water (top of the Galata Tower), eat like a Sultan and experience such natural warmth........

Istanbul, and Turkey generally, is about as rich in cultural history as any place I've been. While it doesn't have the real European gaiety of Paris, Rome or Prague, it is a pretty cool place with an extraordinary range of levels of society and cultural practices. Add to that the buzz of knowing you're in the capital of the Byzantine empire, the friendliness and extreme good behaviour of the inhabitants, and the agreeable prices, you just HAVE to go.Taxis are cheap and are a definite option for an airport transfer (don't try that in Prague). If you're travelling light you can catch the train at the airport. Unfortunately halfway you have to transfer to a tram to reach downtown.On the subject of the tram, we stayed at Taksim Square (see my review of Marmara Hotel) from where there is a funicular which connects with the tram; and the tram then goes to Sultanahmet and all the attractions there. It's all quite convenient and economical. Though if we had only been going for pure tourism we would have considered staying in Sultanahmet.And talking of Taksim Square, off that leads Istiklal Caddesi, a long pedestrian thoroughfare which most of the time, and especially at night, is absolutely teeming with life, people strolling, eating those funny and delicious Turkish ice-creams, buying clothes, popping into restaurants or cafes. Don't miss that experience.Eminonu, the ferry terminal, was also a good place to go. You can buy fish sandwiches, or dine at one of the fish restaurants under the Galata Bridge, looking over the water. The proprietors in the restaurants can be a little pushy in trying to get you to dine as you walk past, but once you're in and hooked they ease off the over-attention.I wouldn't get too excited about some of the suburban shopping centres to which the hotels offer to bus you. Go to the covered bazaar and allow yourself to flow downhill from there towards the Golden Horn, where there is a tangle of presumably Byzantine streets full of little shops selling all manner of stuff.The touts and hustlers around the main attractions (Hagya Sofya etc) are a bit tiresome - when you try to ignore them they make out you've offended them. Actually I don't think you are breaking any cultural rule at all by doing so. But of course the amazing attractions of Sultahnamet are probably the main reason for going to Istanbul, and they must be seen at all costs. Afterwards, try a meal at one of the rooftop restaurants in one of the hotels behind the Sofia, with a view of the Bosporus. We went to the Seven Hills, but there were others we could see from there.On the whole the city is not that difficult and feels quite safe. It is also tolerant although, girls, I would be respectful and not wear anything too skimpy. You will certainly have to cover up when visiting mosques (which are innumerable and many of them very grand). Consider having a light head scarf in your handbag.Hope you enjoy it.

For those out there who never considered Turkey for a vacation (as I once thought), THINK AGAIN!My husband had the opportunity to work there for a few months shortly after 9/11. It was pretty scary to think about due to our ignorance about Turkey and it's people. I made a trip over to visit and, I must confess, it was fabulous. I literally "shopped till I dropped" at the Istanbul bizarre; so many wonderful finds. The food was remarkable. I didn't really know what to expect and boy, was I in for a pleasant surprise! Everything is made with the freshest ingredients and only with what is in season (as opposed to us Americans who eat oranges all year round and then complain about the bad ones that we get in June). I was shocked to see how large the figs were---and oh, so tasty!We also went to Kusadasi down on the Aegean coast and stayed at Adakule Hotel. What a find that was, too. In August, we managed to book a seaside room that included breakfast and dinner for the equivalent of less than $70/night! The spa there was wonderful too...take the time for a Turkish Bath; you won't regret it.The people are also very accomodating and kind. We have met some lifelong friends there and look forward to going back this fall for a wedding!

We spent five days touring istanbul in August, 2005 and contrary to many reviews I have read, the instances of being ripped off have diminished considerably.Taxis - with the new YTL in circulation, eliminating six zeros, the chances of having a taxi driver switch bills on you have virtually been eliminated. We bought the Turkish lira from American Express prior to our departure and received the new currency. Taxi drivers were friendly but not talkative. We had one instance where it appeared the driver was goinging to attempt to run up the meter but I was familiar with the route and instructed him which way to go. He gave me a sheepish smile. While taxis are relatively inexpensive, Istanbul is compact and I would recommend walking - you'll see a lot more. Some of the guidebooks recommend taking the busses because they're inexpensive. Those that we saw moved at a snail's pace and were caught in traffic most of the time. If your time in Istanbul is limited, you'll get there faster by walking or by taxi.The Grand Bazaar - maybe it was the heat but aggressive hassling no longer exists. We spent several hours there and there were a few merchants in their doorway inviting us in but that was the extent of any pressure to buy. Another shocking change is that bargaining no longer exists, at least among the jewelry shops. At our first stop we saw a silver bracelet and when I asked the salesman to do better than the quoted price, he replied that that was his best price and that he doesn't bargain. I called his bluff and walked out but he didn't call after me! At the next shop I again asked the owner to do better on a quoted price but he refused to budge. Again we walked out and the owner just sat there! At a third shop the owner agreed to a 20% discount. I don't consider that a big discount but we liked the jewelry and bought it anyway. So if you're in the bazaar, forget about the 50% discount the travel guides suggest.Turkish Food- we were really anxious to try the food but were greatly disappointed. If you're concerned about about your cholesterol level stay away from the kebabs. We went into one restaurant that displayed rows of skewered meets ready to be barbequed and it was 95% fat. I couldn't find any red meat on some of the skewers. We walked out of there in a hurry. Surprisingly, our best meal in Istanbul was "penne arabiata". A "donner kebab" lunch at the restaurant in the Topkapi Palace, overlooking the Bosphorus, was second. We had a number of fish dishes and none were out of the ordinary. One other caution. Nearly everyone smokes and most restaurants don't have non-smoking sections. Be prepared to be enveloped in second hand smoke, even on the streets.The People - We never felt insecure or threatened and we did a lot of walking in all parts of the city. There is a visible police presence everwhere. The people are genuinely friendly and helpful, and most speak english. Because its so cosmopolitan, its usually difficult to distinguish between residents and tourists, unless you're carrying a guidbook.Sightseeing - There are a lot of things to see and those sites that require an entrance fee, will cost you dearly. Three of us spent $95 just to see various parts of the Topkapi Palace. As I recall, the Dolmobache Palace was another $65. Add the Cistern, the Blue Mosque, the ferry ride up the Bosphorus and other sights and we probably spent over $400 for the three of us.In summary, Istanbul is a fabulous place! Its exciting, exotic, and definitely worth a repeat visit.

We have just returned from Turkey. While there, we took a boat ride up the Bosphorus to the Black Sea and return. It was very nice. Lots of old and new sights to see. We stopped for lunch at a small village at the entrance to the Black Sea with many restaurants. We made an arbitrary choice and it was fine. We recommend this as a very pleasant way to spend a day.

Sono stato in vacanza con amici a Istanbul, città bellissima e affascinante, ma fate molta attenzione:-TAXI: quando date loro i soldi occhio!! perche scambiano le banconote date a loro con altre di minor valore, facendovi credere di aver sbagliato( ci siamo capitati più volte, alla prima si crede uno sbaglio, al secondo tassista che c'ho fatto più attenzione abbiamo urlato che chiamavamo la polizia!! al 3 dicevamo già che conoscevamo il trucco).BAR: se prendete una consumazione e vi portano noccioline e patatine, queste non sono comprese nel prezzo e rischiano insieme al servizio di costarvi più della bevuta!

Es una Ciudad hermosa que pertenece a dos Continentes, está unida por un enorme puente que atraviesa el Bósforo por el se puede realizar un paseo en lancha o yate, cuenta con cantidad de Mezquitas entre ellas la Mezquit Azul, Santa Sofia, el Palacio de Topkapi, E Mini Ataturk (tiene a escala los más grandes monumentos de Turkya), el Acuario, los bazares, etc..

Jos olet kiinnostunut historiasta, kulttuurista, majoitu mielummin Sultanahmetiin kuin lähelle Taksimin aukiota. Puhumattakaan Aasian puolta. Se oli Turkissa asuneen työkaverini ensimmäinen neuvo. Siitä kaikki lähti lomallani kehittymään oikeaan suuntaan.Osta Finnairin ja Turkish-Airlinesin käyttämältä Ataturkin-kentältä heti paikallinen matkakortti. Pääset kätevästi paikalle metrolla ja ratkikalla matkalaukkujenkin kanssa muutamalla liiralla, eli 1 eurolla.

Стамбул – это эклектика во всем, там встречается Восток и Запад, древность и современность, это стык культур, религий, традиций. Я очень люблю неоднородные многослойные субстанции, которые сложно разгадать и познать – Стамбул несомненно одно из таких явлений.Стамбул - город мечетей - внутри меня не понравилось, плохо пахнет, но снаружи они очень величественные и красивые; звук имама, взывающего к молитве, раздражающе звонкий, но какофония раздающаяся с разных минаретов создает отдельный колорит.Стамбул - морской город - отовсюду веет морем, чайки вместо голубей на площадях и верандах; корабли (обожаю корабли, они меня всегда завораживают. Корабли - это безумно смело!)Стамбул - кладезь красивой посуды, витражных ламп, разноцветных нежных платков - я потратила много времени на то, чтобы выбрать что-то свое из всего этого многообразия. Теперь у меня дома есть превосходная витражная лампа, она постоянно горит, наполняя комнату уютным восточным свечением.Стамбул - большая кондитерская - обилие наивкуснейших сладостей - я ела их на все приемы пищи))) Хотела попробовать все, но мне не удалось, в меня столько не помещается.Стамбул - это еще много чего, не буду говорить про все, просто это место, куда давно надо было съездить.

Estuve con mi esposo 5 días en Estambul y volví ayer 29/04/2015 nos gustó muchísimo. La recorrimos todo lo que pudimos hasta un paseo nocturno. Por suerte estábamos alojados en la zona de Sultanahmet donde se encuentran casi todos los lugares más visitados, Mezquita Azul, Santa Sofía, Basílica Cisterna, Gran Bazar etc. Recomiendo que visiten Estambul! Su comida deliciosa en cualquier lugar que paren es muy buena!
Foi muito interessante pra mim conhecer esta cidade onde a modernidade convive com um grande passado. Tem muitas atrações que agrada qualquer tipo de viajante.

Istambul, Turquia. A unica cidade do mundo que esta em dois continentes diferentes; Europa e Asia. A parte europeia é mais movimentada e onde estao os principais pontos turisticos e excelente vida noturna. Entre bares, restaurantes, cafes e muita agitação Istambul é um convite a diversao e emocao, durante o dia e a noite.

Я очень люблю Стамбул - многовековой многослойный город с богатейшей историей и интересной культурой. Много культурных памятников, как византийского, так и османского периодов. В апреле проходит изумительный фестиваль тюльпанов в парках. Особенно заслуживают внимание парки Гюльхане и Эмирган.Много древних мечетей, как построенных на основе византийских храмов, так и самостоятельно.Вкусная качественная еда и масса всевозможных ресторанов и кафе на любой кошелек. Правда, неприятно назойливы уличные зазывалы ((Довольно успешно можно совместить музейный туристический тур с интересным шопингом.В незнакомые места (особенно азиатской части) одиноким девушкам лучше не забредать, от греха подальше. В целом, местные жители доброжелательные и открытые.
que cidade é essa? Milenar, moderna, permissiva, islâmica, gastronômica, cosmopolita e com mais centenas de adjetivos que só indo para descrever

Tolle, riesige Stadt mit phantastischer Kulisse am Bosporus. Super leckeres Essen, sehr preiswert, wenn man die Lokale der Einheimischen aufsucht. Kann in Touristenrestaurants aber auch sehr teuer werden, da Abzocke drohen kann. Tolle, fürstliche Süßigkeiten zu passablen Preisen.Ich war insgesamt 4 mal dort, jedesmal war es anders, aber immer schön.
Det er en fantastisk by, og metronom. Jeg kunne bruge fler uger på at udforske denne vugge til historiens fortællinger.

Es como cualquier capital europea, pero con un toque oriental que la convierte en una ciudad especial. Lo mejor es visitar toda el área histórica y tradicional que se ubica en la parte europea. Lo peor es que está llena de turistas todo el año y que, si no te gusta regatear, lo pasas fatal en las tiendas.

column2: “ISTANBUL, HEDEN MET VERLEDEN, DUIZENDEN JAREN HISTORIE, EUROPEES GEVOEL IN KLEIN AZIE”
column3: Bij aankomst op de luchthaven ATATURK, ga je onmiddellijk in de bijstaan by VISUM, indie je er nog geen hebt. Zonder visum is het verloren tijd om in de ellen lange rij van de paspoort controle te staan, want je wordt direct teruggestuurd. Haal je bagage op en neem een taxi naar je hotel. Oud Istanbul, bezoek, De Grand Bazar, Tok-kapi, Agia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Egyptian Spice Market, maak een toch over de Bosphorus of neem de Ferry voor een paar Euro naar Klein Azië eet een visje aan de Bosporus. Bezoek de moderne nieuwe Turkse shopping malls en maak gebruik van de metro, die je razendsnel door Istanbul vervoerd. Istanbul is een metropool, waar je geweest moet zijn, om de oude en moderne stad, met Aziatische/Arabisch smaak te proeven.

Turkey adalah negara dengan kebudayaan yang sangat tinggi. Turkey juga unik, karena sebagian wilayahnya terletak di benua Asia, dan sebagian lagi di benua Afrika. Bila kita mau berbelanja, melihat bangunan dengan arsitektur yang berseni, dan mencoba makanan2 yang yummi... Turkey layak menjadi pilihan.

Стамбул реально город на любителя. В общем он меня не впечатлил..Никак... Я люблю Европу..Очень люблю Барселону, Пальма де Майорку, Гамбург, Прагу ну и Питер, конечно. У всех городов свои лица и своя энергетика. У Стамбула я ее не ощутила... Слишком все намешано. Мне лично сложно было находится в Храме св. Софии,тк этот храм был то православным, то мусульманским... Это не мое...Храмы буквально на каждом шагу... И это тоже сложно... Прогулка по улочкам понравилась больше..но лил проливной дождь( он по моему там все время) и гулять было сложно. Единственное чему поставлю 5!!!! Это турецкий кофе... Вот даже без лишних похвал,он супер!!!! Впрочем как и везде в Турции.

Istanbul är en mycket unik stad. 96% av den ligger i Asien och resten i Europa. Över Bosporen som skiljer stadsdelarna åt kan man krossa via broar eller med båtfärja.Den nya flygplatsen ligger i den asiatiska delen, medan den historiska delen ligger i Europa. Biltrafiken över Bosporen är i rusningstrafik mer stillastående än rullande.Över 3100 moskéer i staden sätter sin prägel. Det är en spännande miljö.

aku memiliki travel agent di bekasi untuk umrah, dan aku selalu booking hotel by expedia, airasiago, tripadvisor dan booking.com aku sangat senang dengan segala kemudahan yntuk berlibur ke turki, stempel visa bisa di airport, hanya bayr beberapa puluh dolar, taxi bus dan tram banyak disana menuju sultan ahmet, area blue mosque dan tempat hiburan disekitar situ, atau mau menginap di taksim, banyak apartement yang baik dengan harga terjangkau, Turki adalah negara yang menyenangkan, orang2nya baik, sopan, hanya wanita2nya yang asli turkiye suka jutek, alias menyebalkan, mungkin jelouse, hehehe tapi turki betul... GREAT

column2: “современный город с богатой историей, но очень грязный”
column3: Крупный современный европейский город с множеством мечетей. Столько контрастов в эом месте. Например, идет, видно набожная, женщина вся укутанная с ног до головы в паранджу, а мимо проходит современная с голым пузом в мини-юбке девушка. Единственное, что мне не понравилось, так это антисанитария. Продавец магазина дорогих ковров на моих глазах выкинул бумажку прямо перед входом в магазин. И везде так: кучи мусора, свалки какие-то. Но если не обращать на это внимание, то все отлично.
Узкие неровные петляющие улочки. Потрясающие виды. Удобное расположение всех достопримечательностей. Много магазинчиков и ресторанчиков. Прекрасный город для прогулок в солнечную теплую погоду.
eine verrückte Stadt, sie schläft nie, immer ist irgendwo Leben, der Straßenverkehr ist ohne erkennbare Regeln, Polizei vorhanden aber hilflos,
Estambul eh uma cidade sensacional, que tem muita historia desde as origens como Bizancio, Constantinopla e Estambul.Valeu muito a pena visitar

Istanbul é cheia de encantos , já fui tres vezes.,a vontade de voltar já começa no retorno ..cidade linda , limpa , povo agradavel , educado e prestativo .As comidas são divinas , as atrações faz-se com tranquilidade em uma bela caminhada , indico uns 5 dias no minimo , e o passeio para a Ilha do Principe vale a pena , vc vai sem stress de trem ate o porto e pega o barco ...bem tranquilo...melhor ir cedo para aproveitar !!

Прилетела в Стамбул на три дня. Город понравился. Повсюду торговые лавки, сладости. Люди вокруг выглядят довольно образованными. Меня так же поразил стамбульский трамвай. Разумеется, стоит побывать на рынке, где можно по смешным ценам накупить множество текстиля и одежды. А еще мне очень запомнилось традиционное блюдо стамбульцев, которое, как шаурма в России, продается на каждом шагу. Это маленькая жареная рыбка (я не рыбак, но возможно это килька), которая подается с вкуснейшей свежей и хрустящей лепешкой, нарезкой из свежих овощей и половинкой лимона! Это просто божественно и стоит около 2$!!!! Стамбул-город, в который хочется вернуться. В нем кипит жизнь и люди очень доброжелательны.

Istanbul es una ciudad que hay que conocer. Las mezquitas son bellísimas, y excepto a la hora de la oración se pueden conocer en detalle. La comida, el ambiente, los colores, la amabilidad de la gente, en todo es una experiencia excelente!

Стамбул!!!! Как много в этом слове, для сердца русского слилось...Много раз бывал в этом замечательном городе, где многое дышит историей, где воедино слились запад и Восток, новое и старое, где есть ВСЕ, как в Греции)))))))))))Город разделен Мраморным морем на две части - Азиатскую и Европейскую, причем Азиатская более "крутая", там находится и "сити" и самые лучшие отели и проч. Европейская более скученная, деловая, в ней "кипит" жизнь, в ней расположены все самые интересные исторические места: Голубая мечеть, собор Святой Софии, подземный дворец, Золотой базар и прочее, прочее, прочее...Соединяют эти части Стамбула несколько красивых вантовых мостов, на которых в часы пик выстраиваются гигантские пробки, т.к. проезд платный((((((((На берегах Босфора с обоих сторон огромное количество ресторанов, на любой вкус!!! На Азиатской части более пафосные и дорогие, а на Европейской - повеселее, дешевле, во многих по вечерам танец живота и живая музыка. По вечерам здесь кипит жизнь!!!В Стамбуле нет нищих - все при деле, кто разносит традиционный чай, кто пакует и таскает коробки для карго, но не сидят с протянутой рукой.Магазины - это отдельная тема: есть качественный ширпотреб, а есть дорогие бутики, с брендовой атрибутикой, с индивидуальным обслуживанием и соответствующими ценами. Огромное количество ювелирных магазинов, где продают огромное количество копий известных ювелирных брендов, есть даже очень высококачественные, и везде можно торговаться!!! Есть огромное количество молов, где сосредоточены и магазины, и развлечения, и фаст фуд и прочее.Запросто можно увидеть вывески - "Бутик оптом", "Шанель не дорого"))))))))))Еда в Стамбуле - это что-то особое, описывать которое можно очень долго. На улице с лотков продают и мидий, и каштаны, и бублики и проч снедь. забегаловок с шаурмой и прочим безумное количество. Есть рестораны и рыбные и мясные, и какие захочешь. Есть дешевые, а есть и дорогие, настоящий гастрономический рай!!!Всем рекомендую посетить этот колоритный и замечательный город!!!

Istambul é simplesmente a antiga Constantinopla, a Roma do Oriente, capital do Império Romano, assim, caminhar por suas ruas é caminhar pela história. Istambul é contemporânea, o super antigo convive com o moderno, glamouroso. Incrível! Quero voltar.
Una de las ciudades más bellas de Oriente.Se puede ver en todas sus calles y edificios el paso de las culturas románicas, bizantinas y otomanas.Maravillosos palacios, mezquitas y parques.

Wenn mann İstanbul Sehen und miterleben will,İch empfehle mindestens eine woche.Es gibt wiel zu sehen . Museen,Old bazzar,Alte U bahn (Karaköy-Galata) ,Rote Historische Straßen bahn(Galata-Taksim platz) Gleiche Strecke zurück zu fuss (Fussgenger zohne) .Von Eminönü Bosphorus Schiff fahrt,Asiatische seite( Kadiköy,Moda) .Haydarpaşa Alte Bahnhof(Von Deutschen gebaut)Es gibt so viel tipps.Kann ich alles hier nicht schreiben .

De esas oportunidades de la vida de irte 4 días con amigos a una cultura completamente ajena a la tuya. Istanbul es como un cuento, su belleza está en las mezquitas y en la vista del agua que divide Istanbul europeo e Istanbul asiático.

purtroppo la mia esperienza è stata decisamente negativa sin dall'arrivo all'areoporto dove, dopo due ore e mezza di volo, sono stato costretto ad una fila di quasi tre ore solo per il controllo dei passaporti, in piedi ed ammassato assieme ad altri passeggeri per tutto quel tempo solo per incapacità da parte delle autorità di gestire il flusso turistico; insomma, già questo dovrebbe indignarci come viaggiatori e pretendere che la nazione si adegui laddove ci invogli (con mille propagande istituzionali) ad incrementare la sua economia col turismo. Mi sono sentito il classico "pollo da spellare", ristoratori che ti cercano ovunque per farti mangiare kebab a 15 euro (manco in Italia) ma istituzioni decisamente ostili. A mio parere è un paese ancora molto retrogrado e ben lontano dal concetto di modernità e democrazia che vuole farci credere anelando l'ingresso in europa. Credo che come semplice turista potrei pretendere di più. Ci sono Stati meno sviluppati e con una religiosità ancora più pregnante ma con un'apertura al turismo più etica ed intelligente. Molto deluso ed indignato

Estive lá em abril de 2013, era uma primavera gelada e chuvosa, mas nada impediu de curtir muito essa cidade incrível! Ficamos 3 dias e meio, mas poderíamos ter ficado mais, há muito para ver e provar. A comida é deliciosa, o chá de maçã é uma delícia e as pessoas são bem simpáticas e acolhedoras. O acesso às atrações é bem fácil, mas num dos dias fizemos um tour sugerido pelo hotel, com acesso a varias atrações e almoço incluso, foi ótimo, recomendo!
comida boa , lugar mais ou menos, custo beneficio bom, o atendimento foi bom, os turcos são muito atenciosos,

Estambul, es una ciudad con infinitas opciones por tomar.Desde sus increibles mezquitas, pasando por su cultura, su gente, sus costumbres, sus paisajes, etc.Es realmente hermosa.Recomendable saber hablar fluido ingles para poder entender y aprender a cada momento, no lo cuando se va de excursión.

Επίσκεψη οδικώς, μια περίεργη αίσθηση περνώντας για πρώτη φορά τα σύνορα και ένα δέος από τους τόσο πολλούς ουρανοξύστες. Αυτές ήταν οι πρώτες εντυπώσεις. Πραγματικά τεράστια πόλη, αλλά ταυτόχρονα μαγευτική καθώς 3 πολιτισμοί έχουν αφήσει το στίγμα τους σε κάθε γωνιά της.Γραφεία για συνάλλαγμα υπάρχουν άφθονα στη πόλη (καλή τιμή είναι 2,80 λίρες), αν μπορέσετε όταν θα πάτε στο Great Bazaar (γιατί οπωσδήποτε θα πάτε) κάντε συνάλλαγμα από εκεί, θα βρείτε και με 2,84 λίρες το ευρώ.Οι Τουρκόφωνοι σε γενικές γραμμές ήταν φιλικοί και μας φωνάζαν Γιώργο, Μαρία και ...Μαζωνάκη(!). Σε αρκετά μέρη, και ιδιαίτερα στη πλατεία Ταξίμ και στο Μεγάλο Παζάρι νόμιζες ότι βρισκόσουν Ελλάδα από τους τόσο πολλούς Ελληνόφωνους τουρίστες.Η Κωνσταντινούπολη είναι η πόλη που πραγματικά δε κοιμάται ποτέ (3 το βράδυ και η κίνηση στους δρόμους είναι καθημερινή πρωί στη Κηφισίας).Στα σημαντικότερα αξιοθέατα της πόλης ανήκουν η Αγία Σοφία(που πλέον είναι μουσείο),το ανάκτορο Ντολμά Μπαχτσέ, το Επταπύργιο και τα βυζαντινά τείχη, το Φανάρι καθώς και το ανάκτορο Τοπ Καπί, το Μπλέ Τζαμί και πύργος του Γαλατά. Η πλατεία Ταξίμ και το τοπ καπι μουσείο που αναπαριστά το 1453 είναι μέρη που δε πρέπει να παραλείψετε καθώς και μία κρουαζιέρα στον Βόσπορο.Τα γλυκα και τα συροπιαστά τους δε παίζονται, μπορώ να πω ότι αν θες να περάσεις καλά και αν σε ενδιαφέρουν κυρίως τα ψώνια και το φαγητό, η Instanbul είναι μια καλή επιλογήΜου έκανε εντύπωση : Οι υπερβολικά πολλές σημαίες παντού και σε όλα τα μεγέθη, σε περίπτωση που είχες ξεχαστεί σε ποια χώρα ήρθες.
estambul es como el agujero del conejo... colores, formas, aromas, experiencias, gente, situaciones.... todo es posible!! y todo es impresionante!!!
Cidade cosmopolita situada em dois continentes(Europa e Ásia).Contraste entre cidade antiga e nova. Contrastes culturais e religiosos, Apaixonante
Tatil günlerinde gidilebilecek yerlerin başında olmalı bence, manzarası ve doğasıyla tam bir sülüet herkese tavsiye ediyorum..
mis a part les embouteillages monstre, et le sempiternel bosphore a traverser de long en large, la ville est merveilleuse !

Minhas primeiras recomendações são: não deixe de provar o borek, suco de romã e tomar um banho turco!!!A cidade se divide em nova e antiga (onde estão as mesquitas, construções antigas e grand bazar) e é possível se locomover com transporte público. Apesar de haver mais homens do que mulheres nas ruas, é seguro para uma mulher andar sozinha (experiência própria). Se for de táxi, negocie o preço antes de entrar no carro (de preferência, peça ao hotel para chamá-lo), e nunca se esqueça de pechinchar nas lojinhas...Durante as pausas para oração, que acontecem 5x ao dia, é possível ouvir o chamado para prece das mesquitas.
İstanbul bütün dünya şehirleri arasında mutlaka görülmesi ve keşfedilmesi gereken en önemlilerinden biridir. Hem binlerce yıllık geçmişi ve tarihi dokusu hem de gizemi ile sizleri çok şaşırtacak
Estambul es una ciudad maravillosa, su historia, sus mezquitas, sus palacios y el bosforo hacen de ella una ciudad inigualable.

Estambul es una explosión de colores, sonidos, olores. Asombra. El mercado,divertido, el acueducto: imperdible, maravillosamente mágico. Sta Sofía,la mezquita azul y el Bósforo, navegarlo en el atardecer es una delicia.
Amei a cidade, tudo lindo e organizado, amei mais ainda conhecer o Grand Bazaar. Ficamos 5 dias e aproveitamos muito!

Κωνσταντινούπολη, η πόλη που ξυπνά αναμνήσεις, η πόλη ανάμεσα σε δύο ηπείρους, η Πόλη (με Π κεφαλαίο)........... που σε κερδίζει με την πρώτη ματιά. Ένα είναι σίγουρο. Με την επιστροφή του πρώτου ταξιδιού, προγραμματίζεις την επόμενη επίσκεψη.

Abbiamo passato una giornata nella magica Istambul. Come prima visita siamo stati nella moschea blu , ci siamo recati nella chiesa di S Sofhia e al gran bazar .Sicuramente necessita di più giorni e probabilmente torneremo per visitarla a dovere

Город пропитанный историей насквозь. Невозможно не восхититься обилием красивых мечетей, разного времени постройки, конечно же особые впечатление остались от посещения Ая Софии, которая поразила своей красотой и сохранностью. Голубая мечеть - шедевр восточной архитектуры, я не видел более красивой мечети. Большой интерес вызвали подземные водохранилища - цистерны, которые выполнены как архитектурный шедевр.

Пишу о городе в целом. Это, определенно, стоит увидеть! Город великолепен. Если честно, я была не очень оптимистично настроена ехать в Турцию, после все того, что читала о русских туристах. Но Стамбул - нечто совершенно неповторимое, этот город влюбляет в себя с первых часов пребывания в нем! (а русских там не так уж и много)Безумно красиво кругом, прекрасная погода, милые и приветливые люди! Все всегда тебе рады, никто не хамит. Турки к женщинам не пристают)) Все чинно-благородно. Немного непривычна их восточная нерасторопность и любовь поболтать.За руль автомобиля в Стамбуле лучше не садиться. Улицы узкие, пробок очень много, а турки ездят как ненормальные, честное слово. Половину всего времени они ездят на задней передаче. Бросить машину посреди дороги и пойти поболтать с кем-то - вообще обычное дело. Так что не портите себе нервы, не тратьте время и передвигайтесь пешком или на трамвае.Если делаете покупку, торгуйтесь до последнего. Если скидку в 50% не делают, смело уходите - скорее всего вас догонят и продадут вещь со скидкой.Еще лучше всего ходите гулять с раннего утра. Торговцы будут вам делать хорошие скидки как первым покупателям, а в музеях будут маленькие очереди (кстати, не рекомендую арендовать в музеях аудиогида, это бессмысленная трата денег, ничего интересного гид не рассказывает). Кроме того, в обед очень жарко, лучше жару пережидать в отеле.Если идете в мечеть, то надевайте не шорты, а штаны. Женщинам на входе выдается специальная закрытая одежда, так что можете идти в чем угодно.Еда в Стамбуле очень вкусная, куда вы ни придете, везде будет вкусно. Турки в еде знают толк!
